en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christine_Ladd-Franklin "Christine Ladd-Franklin (December 1, 1847 – March 5, 1930) was an American psychologist, logician, and mathematician." The Roanoke times., June 22, 1893, Page 2, col. 1 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn86071868/1893-06-22/ed-... describes her as one of the few women who have won well deserved reputations as scientific thinkers and writers. The target of the German/Bulgarian advance in late 1916 and early 1917: "RUMANIANS LOSE THE CITY OF BRAILA; Country's Chief Commercial Centre and Four Other Towns Are Taken by Teutons. BERLIN, Jan. 5, (by Wireless to Sayville.)--Braila, Rumania's chief commercial city, has been captured by the Germans and Bulgarians, according to the official announcement made this evening." query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9C02EFD71438EE... en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Br%C4%83ila The building at far right, "Teatru Regal", still stands and is now called Teatrul Maria Filotti. brailaveche.wordpress.com/2011/03/04/teatrul-rally-maria-...

The caption doesn't match what is written on the negative; seems to have been cloned from the next photo. The Mayflower was the presidential yacht between 1906 and 1929. See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USS_Mayflower_(PY-1)

I think the Mayflower is the anchored vessel to left of the two warships. A launch (just above the end of the pier at right) is heading out. Looking for references to Wilson and the Mayflower in 1916, I found an interesting blog post about an attempt on Dec 2, 1916 by some suffragettes to "bomb" the yacht with petitions and leaflets, during the ceremony to turn on the first floodlighting of the Statue of Liberty. blog.nyhistory.org/the-suff-bird-women-and-woodrow-wilson/ NYT of Dec 2, 1916 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9E00E5DC1230E733A... confirms that Wilson would board the Mayflower from the dock at 80th street. So this photo could be of that occasion. The New York Sun., December 03, 1916 (pages 1 and 6) chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030431/1916-12-03/ed-... chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030431/1916-12-03/ed-... describe the ceremony of the previous evening and lists as being present men seen with the President in neighboring photos. A chapter in Liberty and Freedom: A Visual History of America's Founding Ideas by David Hackett Fischer books.google.com/books?id=uc8KP_QtW-sC&pg=PA421&l... describes the ceremony from a historical perspective.
Other ships mentioned in the Sun article: The San Francisco, Wyoming, Texas, New York.
Thanks for all the links swanq. We'll add this information to our catalog record.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carlo_Tresca "Carlo Tresca (March 9, 1879 – January 11, 1943) was an Italian-born American newspaper editor, orator, and labor organizer who was a leader of the Industrial Workers of the World during the decade of the 1910s. "

Based on page 91 of Carlo Tresca: Portrait of a Rebel, by Nunzio Pernicone books.google.com/books?id=lUPIAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA91&lp... He was accused as an accessory after the fact in a case in Duluth, Minnesota, in which several strikers were accused of the murder of a deputized mine guard who had invaded their home and assaulted them. Never before had Tresca found himself in comparable danger. The trial date was set for December 5, 1916. A chronology for the IWW (Industrial Workers of the World) is at www.iww.org/about/chronology/3 -- the organization was founded in 1916.
Thanks swanq for the links, we'll update our catalog record.

Date on sticker is 12/2/16. This photo was used in The Sunday Oregonian. (Portland, Ore.), December 17, 1916 with the caption: "Training chorus girls to sing with Billy Sunday. Billy Sunday Gets Musical Comedy Chorus to Sing at Revival. Billy Sunday is always doing the sensational thing. His latest stunt during the revival in Boston was to have his musical leader, Rodeheaver, train the members of the chorus of "Robinson Crusoe. Jr.," to sing, with him at his Sunday services. "Admiral of the Fleet John Rushworth Jellicoe, 1st Earl Jellicoe, GCB OM GCVO SGM (5 December 1859 – 20 November 1935) was a Royal Navy officer." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Jellicoe,_1st_Earl_Jellicoe A cropped version of this photo was used in The Sunday Oregonian. (Portland, Ore.) December 17, 1916, with the caption: "Admiral Jellicoe Now First Lord of Admiralty "Admiral Jackson has just succeeded Admiral Jellicoe as First Lord of the Admiralty. He was in command of the grand fleet and Admiral Beatty is his successor in that office." oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83045782/1916-12-17/ed-1/se... The caption is incorrect. Sir Hiram Maxim died November 24, 1916. His death was widely reported.

From his Wikipedia entry as cited by  [https://www.flickr.com/photos/90124154@N00] 
"Sir Hiram Stevens Maxim (February 5, 1840 – November 24, 1916) was an American inventor who moved to the United Kingdom at the age of 41. He remained an American citizen until he became a naturalized British subject in 1900.  He was the inventor of the Maxim Gun – the first portable, fully automatic machine gun – and held patents on mechanical devices such as a mousetrap, hair-curling irons, and steam pumps. He laid claim to inventing the lightbulb, and even experimented with powered flight, but his large aircraft designs were never successful. However, his "Captive Flying Machine" amusement ride, designed as a means by which to fund his research while generating public interest in flight, was highly successful."
Thanks Seuss and swanq. We'll add his full name and since he died in 1916, we'll change the date range.

"Thomas Clarke Rye (June 2, 1863 – September 12, 1953) was an American politician who served as Governor of Tennessee from 1915 to 1919. An ardent supporter of prohibition of alcoholic beverages, he helped reunify the state's Democratic Party, which had been divided over the issue for nearly a decade. Rye is perhaps best remembered for enacting the "Ouster Law," which was aimed at curbing the power of political boss E. H. Crump." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Clarke_Rye

The trains from Texas had come into Jersey City the morning of November 28, 1916. From there they ferried over to 23rd St. in Manhattan: "CITY WELCOMES 7TH BACK FROM BORDER; Nearly 200,000 See Tanned Guardsmen from Texas March Up 5th Av. REVIEWED BY GOV. WHITMAN Women and Children Wait Three Hours at Armory to Greet Their Relatives." query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9406E0DA1F3FE2... chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1916-11-28/ed-...
www.museumoffamilyhistory.com/gus-03.htm indicates that this is the Erie railroad terminal ferry station at the foot of W 23rd St., New York City.

A broader view of the complex of ferry terminals at W. 23rd St. in 1905: digitalgallery.nypl.org/nypldigital/dgkeysearchdetail.cfm... Here they are leaving Manhattan from a different ferry terminal in late June, 1916, when they were sent to Texas.
From his mustache, I think the officer in front is Colonel Willard Fisk. See
I think so. He's on the left in this photo:

Here's a poem written for the occasion, from the regimental gazette: "Back from the Border Hark to the music of bugle and drum See up Fifth Avenue homeward they come! Fathers and mothers and sweethearts are here Hear how they're greeting them cheer after cheer See how much stronger and tanned they have grown Many a hardship these fellows have known Leaving their loved ones tho hearts have been rent Men with a conscience, the Fellows Who Went Man in the club window gazing so hard You who have run down the National Guard Feel you no qualms as you cozily sit Watching those fellows who've all done their "bit "? See how they're marching now, just like one man As only the men of such regiments can! See that boy passing, the fifth, that's the One! Thank God for His mercy; That is my Son! These are the fellows who leaving their all Quitted their life work to answer the call Off with your hats there, and give them a cheer The Pride of the City the Seventh is here! Maud Stoutenburgh Eliot, Nov 28 1916 " books.google.com/books?id=dajlAAAAMAAJ&dq=%227th%20re...

I think this may show the same buildings as another Bain Photo: But the photos have clocks on the opposite side of the street, so I may be wrong. One thing is clear. The clock for the Guarantee Trust (shown in the 1913 Bain picture shown in this comment) was moved a block from near the 43rd street intersection to near the 44th street intersection when the bank moved in the 1930s. See mcnyblog.org/tag/fifth-avenue/

cdm16694.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/ref/collection/p16124coll... is a 1937/38 photo looking north on Fifth Avenue showing some of the same buildings. It suggests that the intersection shown here is of 43rd and Fifth Avenue.

NYT of August 16, 1916 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A0CEEDA1E3FE233A... indicates that the Guaranty Trust Company had just leased offices for its main uptown branch in the big building nearly completed on the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Forty-third Street. That would be on the right side of these photos looking north up Fifth Avenue. So maybe the clock was moved across the street between the 1913 photo and the November 1916 photo.

The document associated with the designation of the clock (now at 522 Fifth Avenue, where it was moved in the 1930s) as a landmark is at www.nycnpc.org/db/bb_files/81---SIDEWALK-CLOCK---522-FIFT... It says that the original location was at the *southwest* corner of Fifth Avenue and 43rd -- consistent with the 1913 photo. It was manufactured in 1907.

It does seem confusing. Was a clock moved in the 30's? Was another clock moved between 1913 and 1916? Were there two different clocks instead of the one in the 1913 picture being the one moved across the street and uptown? Here's a clock in front of the Postal Life Building, at 5th Avenue and 43rd. collections.mcny.org/C.aspx?VP3=SearchResult_VPage&VB... Here's a story about Guaranty Trust's move from 5th and 43rd to 44th in 1920: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9B03E1D6173AEE...

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/artolog]: Good find for the 1920 article. The Postal Life Building has been occupied by Guaranty Trust and Columbia Bank (as mentioned in the 1920 NYT piece). See www.emporis.com/building/postallifebuilding-newyorkcity-n... More contemporary info on the 1920 move at books.google.com/books?id=iQ4wAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA863&l... www.nysonglines.com/43st.htm reveals that the Postal Life Building, built between 1915 and 1917 is now the Israel Discount Bank. Photo at en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Israel_Discount_Bank. I think that would be the building site at lower right of picture.

And the MCNY photo of the Postal Life Building, on the east side of 5th, shows Guaranty Trust's name in the stone facades along 43rd and 5th. So, I suppose what we see in this picture is the second location of the clock In front of Postal Life, then it was moved again to its present location near the southwest corner of 44th and 5th. Street view looking south, showing Postal Life Building on left, a block down. www.google.com/maps/@40.7548378,-73.9800553,3a,75y,233.82... If that's true, the Landmarks Commission document is inaccurate, unless Morgan Guaranty didn't move the clock back across the street until the 30's, which would seem odd.

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/artolog]: I agree that the Landmarks Commission document seems inaccurate. For one thing, www.nytimes.com/1997/06/04/nyregion/morgan-plan-may-aid-f... indicates that the clock was in its current location in 1926, when it got knocked over by a taxicab!

The Landmarks document research looks like it didn't include contemporaneous sources from the period when the clock moved twice.  Unfortunately, the official history is now that the clock moved in the 30's, and that's been repeated in the MCNY blog article.  
Not that anyone is exactly harmed by this, but they should have done a better job.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roald_Amundsen "Roald Engelbregt Gravning Amundsen (16 July 1872 – c. 18 June 1928) was a Norwegian explorer of polar regions. He led the Antarctic expedition (1910–12) that saw the first men to reach the South Pole, on 14 December 1911. In 1926, he was the first expedition leader to be recognized without dispute as having reached the North Pole." The National Library of Norway has an album of portraits on Flickr at www.flickr.com/photos/national_library_of_norway/sets/721...
The Democratic banner., December 05, 1916, Page 7 reported that Amundsen arrived in New York on the Scandinavian-American liner Frederick VIII. from Copenhagen to purchase an aeroplane.

Despite the Nov. 1916 dates on the negative, I don't believe Carnegie visited Berlin in 1916. Note that the porter's cap is "portier," German for "porter." This was Berlin in Germany, not Berlin, NH. mentalfloss.com/article/51198/world-war-i-centennial-kais... reports on Carnegie's visit to Berlin in June 1913 June 16, 1913: Kaiser Hopes for 25 More Years of Peace “Twenty-five years of peace, Mr. Carnegie, and I hope there will be twenty-five more!” Thus Kaiser Wilhelm II greeted Andrew Carnegie, the world-famous industrialist and peace advocate, who had come to Berlin to celebrate the 25th anniversary of the Kaiser’s reign. Carnegie replied with evident sincerity: “Your majesty is the most powerful ally we have in that direction.”

On November 25, 1916, Carnegie celebrated his 81st birthday at his home in New York, see e.g. The Washington herald., November 27, 1916, Page 2 col. 4, "ANDREW CARNEGIE IS 81" chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045433/1916-11-27/ed-....

Thanks to your sleuthing regarding the dates used and Carnegie's actual travels, I can speculate this is one of the cases in Bain where the date on a negative actually reflects the date used or published.  So, while this photo may have appeared when Carnegie was actually in Berlin, it may have also been used a few years later when he had his birthday.

We have seen this courthouse before in the Bain photos, in connection with the lurid Carman murder trial. This photo, however, when compared to the ones from 2 years prior, seems to be of additions to the building made in 1916: "The Old Nassau County Courthouse, also known as the Nassau County Courthouse and the Historic Nassau County Courthouse, is an historic 2-story courthouse building located at 1550 Franklin Avenue in Garden City, Nassau County, New York. Designed by noted New York City architect William B. Tubby in the Classical Revival style of architecture with a grand rotunda capped by a white dome, it was built of poured-in-place reinforced concrete. Then governor Theodore Roosevelt laid its cornerstone in 1900 and it was finished in 1901. Wings designed by Tubby were added in 1916. Later additions and renovations were 1924-1928 under the supervision of architect William J. Beardsley, who had designed the Dutchess County Court House in Poughkeepsie." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old_Nassau_County_Courthouse_(New_York)

David Manning was judge at the court of Mineola, s. article in The Topeka State journal., November 22, 1917, HOME EDITION, Page 7 col. 5, "JURY IS READY". The date on the sticker is 11/30/17.

Manning was a trial court judge in New York from 1912 to 1921, when he became an appellate judge. In late October, 1916, he made a newsworthy ruling in an lawsuit related to the N.Y. governor's race that year. However, this photo is probably related to the murder trial of Blanca De Saulles, which began in late November, 1917, and which he presided over. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9A04E0D9113AE4... From the Historical Society of New York Courts site: "David F. Manning Associate Justice: 1921-1927 Born: around 1857 Died: January 18, 1929 Justice David F. Manning was born around the year 1857 in Brooklyn, where he lived his entire life. He practiced law in Brooklyn before joining the bench. In October 1912, Manning was elected as a Justice of the Supreme Court following an endorsement by the Queens County Lawyers' Committee. In 1921, Manning was designated to the Appellate Division, Second Department by Governor Nathan L. Miller. He retired from the bench in 1927, having reached the mandatory retirement age of 70. Justice Manning served as president of the Brooklyn Bar Association and vice president of the New York State Bar Association. He was married to Mary G. M. Manning in 1879 and had two sons. He died in Brooklyn on January 18, 1929." www.nycourts.gov/history/legal-history-new-york/luminarie... query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9905E2DA113CE7... see notes under
See also photo of him in The Ogden standard., November 27, 1917, 4 P.M. CITY EDITION, Page 5.
Also, there is an 11/30/17 date on the upper left of the negative.
B-59 and Art Siegel,  Thanks for the background information on Manning. We will improve this record with these new details.

"U.S. Passport Applications, 1795-1925 Name: Helen Mary Anthony Taylor Birth Date: 15 Jun 1881 Birth Place: Cincinnati Ohio Age: 40 Residence: Cincinnati, Ohio Passport Issue Date: 2 Dec 1921 Father Name: Wm H Taylor Father's Birth Location: Cincinnati, Ohio Passport Includes a Photo: Yes Destination: Japan, Indo-China, Hong Kong, Ceylon, India, Egypt, Mesopotamia, Syria, Asia Minor, Persia, Greece, Italy Leaving from: Vancouver on "The Empress of Japan", Dec. 21, 1921"

According to Ancestry.com, the 1940 census lists August Marx and his wife (born in 1881) Helen Taylor Marx. cincinnatifriends.org/about/meetinghistory.html provides another connection between Mrs. Marx and William H. Taylor (her father). But so far, I haven't found a Helen Louise Taylor.

But here is a candidate. Helen M.A. Taylor had an older half-brother William Jordan Taylor, who appears to have had a daughter called Helen, born in 1908, and still alive in 2011. See www.tampabay.com/news/humaninterest/good-for-you-dr-helen... YES! www.tampabay.com/news/humaninterest/lifelong-learner-mark... gives her middle name as Louise. So the bookplate for Helen Louise Taylor was presumably made made by her aunt, presumably during or after her aunt's trip to Japan in 1921 or so. Dr. Helen Louise Dexter (née Taylor) died in 2011. The artist who drew this was Ernest J. "Monty" Cross (January 15, 1880-April 10, 1942), who had studied with Howard Pyle. From "The Book-Plates of Some American Authors" by Sheldon Cheney in THE BIBLIOPHILE (July 1909): "It is reported that Jack London, in ordering an ex libris, said that he knew of nothing more typical of himself than the wolf. And E. J. Cross, who received the commission, made a most striking design, on the general model of the famous 'Lobo' head. The added snowshoes are undoubtedly indicative of Alaska, Mr. London's special literary field. The book-plate which marks the volumes in the library of 'The Snark,' the novelist's home on the high seas, is one of the most sought of the ex libris of the present day writers, and deservedly."

A genealogy of truth telling, hard work journalism /writing en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jack_London Who influenced the great American debunking journalist "All governments lie", especially in a time of war.. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/I._F._Stone Who inspired the 'manufacture of consent' author and US intellectual.Who helped free East Timor alongside John Pilger. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noam_Chomsky Who with I.F.Stone influenced the newer generation of whistleblowing , civic journalism , founding editor of the Intercept.He worked for Democracy Now on PBS. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeremy_Scahill

A similar photo was used by The Sunday Oregonian, December 10, 1916, SECTION FIVE, Image 67 with the caption: "Nancy Keen Perkins is to be married to Henry Field, grandson of Marshall Field, of Chicago, and one of the heirs to his millions. Miss Perkins is a daughter of Mrs. T. Moncure Perkins, who was one of the Langhorne sisters of Virginia and niece of Mrs. Charles Dana Gibson, Mrs. W. W. Astor and Mrs. Reginald Brooks. She has been visiting at Mrs. Gibson's home in New York." She was later Nancy Lancaster (9 September 1897 – 19 August 1994), a "20th-century tastemaker and the owner of Sibyl Colefax & John Fowler, an influential British decorating firm that codified what is known as the English country-house look." (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nancy_Lancaster) Her grandfather was Colonel Chiswell Dabney Langhorne (November 4, 1843 – February 14, 1919), an American railroad industrialist (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chiswell_Langhorne). Her mother was Elizabeth "Lizzie" Dabney (1867—1914), who married Thomas Moncure Perkins. The most famous of the Langhorne sisters was Nancy Witcher Langhorne Astor, CH (19 May 1879 — 2 May 1964) (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nancy_Astor,_Viscountess_Astor). www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4445869566/

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ruth_Bancroft_Law "Ruth Bancroft Law (May 21, 1887 - 1970) was a pioneer American aviator during the 1910s." "Law's greatest feat took place on 19 November 1916, when she broke the existing cross-America flight air speed record of 452 miles (728 km) set by Victor Carlstrom by flying non-stop from Chicago to New York State, a distance of 590 miles (950 km). The next day she flew on to New York City. Flying over Manhattan, her fuel cut out, but she glided to a safe landing on Governors Island and was met by United States Army Captain Henry 'Hap' Arnold."
See www.earlyaviators.com/eoliver.htm and www.earlyaviators.com/eoliver1.htm

See for another picture that looks to be of the same occasion. The San Diego Air and Space Museum has lots of photos of Ruth: www.flickr.com/search/?w=49487266@N07&q=ruth%20law

Ruth Law flew a modified Curtiss Model E "pusher" biplane. The story is that she wanted to purchase one of the newer Model R tractor biplanes but Curtiss refused to sell her one because (pick one or more) a) they were backed up on orders with war production b) Curtiss considered the Model R too much plane for a "girl" c) Curtiss was backing his own pilot, Victor Carlstrom. Law's Model E was modified with a larger engine (100hp) and prop (12"!), supplementary fuel tanks, and a short aluminum windshield. Since Law had learned to fly on Wright "wing warping" airplanes the cockpit was retrofitted with lever controls. She broke Carlstrom's record set only 2 weeks earlier. They both left from Chicago hoping to make it all the way to NYC in one hop. Carlstrom made it to Erie, PA (452 miles) before setting down to refuel. Law made it to Hornell, NY (590 miles.) Her brother, Rodman Law was a movie stuntman and might have been even crazier than Ruth. He made parachute jumps from the Statue of Liberty and the Brooklyn Bridge and once tried to ride a giant rocket.
See also report in the New-York tribune., November 21, 1916, Page 7 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1916-11-21/ed-...

In Brooklyn, looking east from the Hudson River. The building with the dormers on the left is the Freight Office for the South Brooklyn Railway. That's now the location of the Sunset Park Costco. The loft warehouse in the center of the photo is still standing. It was one of the original "Bush Terminal" warehouses. The BT warehouse lofts are now known as "Industry City" and this is Building 19 of that complex. The Brooklyn Nets (NBA) are building their new $50 million training facility on the top floor of that building. Modern Google Street view

Although there was (and still is) a ferry terminal at 39th Street in Manhattan, this is 39th Street in Brooklyn. Ferries ran from there to Manhattan (at Whitehall Street) and Staten Island. NYC Dept. of Records has photos of the terminal building (far left) under construction and dates that to 1913 so this was still relatively new in 1916. A closer view of the terminal building from statenislandhistory.com. And if you're wondering if traffic was as backed up on the other end of the line . . . it was.

From OCR of THE TIMES HISTORY OF THE WAR. Page 95 www.forgottenbooks.com/readbook_text/The_Times_History_of... "Between the villages of Biula and Gromnik, for a distance of about fourteen miles, the two armies [Russian and German/Austrian] were facing one another on the western lay almost entirely within the triangle, of which the Dunajec and the Biala are the sides, their confluence the apex, and of which the Zakliczvn-Gromnik road is the basis. About two miles to the south of the river junction, between Bogumilovice and Tarnow, the double tracked railway Cracow-Lwow crosses the Dunajec and the Biala. The big railway bridge across the Dunajec had been blown up by the Austrians during their second retreat in November 1914; the Russians replaced it by a wooden structure, but this in turn was destroyed by our Allies during their retreat from before Cracow about the middle of December. Since then the Dunajec had become at this point the unbridgable borderline between the armies, which slowly settled down to the routine of But as surprise attacks were in most parts impossible on account of the intervening river, sniping became the chief occupation of the troops in that sector. Behind the big eastern pillar of the broken bridge was the post of a Russian sniper, who by his exploits earned for himself among the enemy local fame and the nickname of " Ivan the Terrible "; he finished by becoming in turn the victim of a sniper." The Sunday Oregonian, November 26, 1916, SECTION FIVE, Image 65 printed this photo with the caption: " Louis Agard, the richest Indian in the Northwest, has just marketed a load of stock calves in St. Paul, and he says cattle raising is the only business. He raises only enough grain to feed his stock and even "two-dollar wheat" would not make him change his opinion about farming. Mr. Agard owns 30,000 acres of the richest land in South Dakota, and so many cattle that he keeps no count of them. He is a half-breed and was born on the Standing Rock reservation. Some of his great land holdings he got in allotments from the Government, but much of his land he bought. Recently he sold an entire section of land in McIntosh and still owns much property in that town. He owns in all 19 quarter sections in the reservation and has about seven miles of land fenced."

According to amertribes.proboards.com/thread/1428 "Louis Agard (1864-May 2, 1939) was called Chat, short for Čhatká, or Left-handed. He was the mixed blood son of Frenchman Louis Agard and full blood Lakota Mary Brocell. The father had been with the American Fur Company and was one of Custer’s interpreters on the 1874 expedition into the Black Hills. Chat married Mollie Pretty Woman, called in various records Monica, White Mouse, and Wiŋesteka (1867-1911), and the couple had around twelve children. Louis had settled into stock-raising and his son (called “senior,” as he too had a son named Louis) followed him in this pursuit. “They had a well built place on the river bottoms, just south of the big hill, and Louis (Chat) Agard, the senior, had a large number of horses. He branded LA on the left shoulder” (early settler Louis O. Huseboe in 1972, in Tidball, Taming the Plains, 512)."

Could be the man some of whose papers are held by the Imperial War Museum -- www.iwm.org.uk/collections/item/object/1030013616 Major General G G A Egerton "Chronicle of British troops under his command in Sicily during 1915 -1916, photocopy of a document (6pp) written by him while commanding 52nd Division at Gallipoli (1915) and 24 notebooks kept when Inspector of Infantry, 1916 - 1918." www.gallipoli-association.org/on-this-day/july-13th suggests that one of the Gs is Granville. www.kingscollections.org/catalogues/lhcma/collection/h/ha... names him as Granville George Egerton. www.kingscollections.org/catalogues/lhcma/collection/h/ha... names him as Maj Gen Granville George Algernon Egerton www.rusinsw.org.au/Papers/2008A03.pdf is a paper, "52nd Lowland Division at Gallipoli – A Second Flodden" that discusses the disastrous battle and its effect on Egerton.

From www.gallipoli-association.org/content/men-of-gallipoli/wh... "EGERTON, MAJOR GENERAL GRANVILLE (1859-1951) CB. Egerton commanded the 52nd Lowland Division , Territorial Force, in 1914. He had been commissioned into the 72nd Highlanders in 1879 and subsequently saw active service in the Afghan War of 1879-80 in which he took part in Roberts's march to Kandahar where he was wounded. He saw further action in Egypt 1882 as adjutant of the Seaforth Highlanders at the battle of Tel-el-Kebir, in the Sudan (battles of Atbara and Omdurman) before returning to England where he took command of the 1st Battalion The Yorkshire Regiment (Green Howards). He was commandant of the School of Musketry at Hythe 1907-09 where he introduced a number of innovative training methods to improve rifle shooting in the army. After commanding an infantry brigade in Malta he returnedto command the Lowland Territorial Division . On arrival at Helles his troops, totally unacclimatised and many still wearing their winter serge uniforms, were pitched piecemeal into a series of costly attacks. When he openly voiced his discontent at their handling by the acting corps commander (De Lisle) he was first reprimanded by Hamilton, then removed from his command; he was Inspector of Infantry1916-19 when he retired, to spend the rest of his life waging a campaign against Hamilton's handling of the 52nd Division"

The scene makes me think of a location possibly in Hawaii, because of the structure and barren soil, obvious temperature in the air and the wind...Hawaiian trades, summertime or early September before the weather commits to larger surf and moisture builds up again. Additionally the crossover of cultures, Hakama and Keiko gi with Boat Hats...then the sticks and especially the one held by the middle man...it may be the exposure but it appears to be a boken, the other stick a rattan or bamboo tango...and though the shot is staged both men have their weapons leading...not exactly on the fighting line but near enough...both gedan position...a very difficult position to enter against.

"Admiral of the Fleet Rosslyn Erskine Wemyss, 1st Baron Wester Wemyss, GCB CMG MVO (12 April 1864 – 24 May 1933), known as Sir Rosslyn Wemyss between 1916 and 1919, was a Royal Navy officer. During the First World War he served as commander of the 12th Cruiser Squadron and then as Governor of Moudros before leading the British landings at Cape Helles and at Suvla Bay during the Gallipoli Campaign. He went on to be Commander of the East Indies & Egyptian Squadron in January 1916 and then First Sea Lord in December 1917, in which role he encouraged Admiral Roger Keyes, Commander of the Dover Patrol, to undertake more vigorous operations in the Channel, ultimately leading to the launch of the Zeebrugge Raid in April 1918."
A cropped version of this photo was used in The Bismarck tribune., January 03, 1918, Image 1 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85042243/1918-01-03/ed-....

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A._Piatt_Andrew looks a good bet for Mr. Andrew "Abram Piatt Andrew, Jr. (February 12, 1873 – June 3, 1936) was an economist, an Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, the founder and director of the American Ambulance Field Service during World War I, and a United States Representative from Massachusetts.[" Grenville Keogh may be www.ancientfaces.com/person/grenville-keogh/28312505 The 1897 date of birth seems about right for this young man, already identified by LoC as a driver in the American Ambulance Field Service. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AFS_Intercultural_Programs#WWI So it seems likely that the women were patrons. Indeed, from a site on the history of AFS "By the summer of 1916, the Field Service had long outgrown its connection with the American Ambulance and needed a legal identity---and a place---of its own. It found a powerful ally in Mrs. Vanderbilt, who by now sat on the Ambulance Committee. " And Anne Morgan was heavily involved in aid to the French during WWI. See, for example, www.americanfriendsofblerancourt.org/history/anne_morgan_...

Grenville Temple Keogh was a son of NY Supreme Court Justice Martin Keogh.  Grenville was born 5 Nov 1897 in New Rochelle, NY and died in June 1969.  He served in the American Field Service as an ambulance driver in France where he was wounded twice.  One of his fellow drivers described him as "the laughing, brave-hearted boy we love perhaps most of all."  Keogh was wounded in the arm in 1916 and returned to the States to recover.  

In January 1917, he returned to Europe to serve as a "sous lieutenant"  pilot volunteer in French Aviation.  He served in the eastern theater of the war in Italy, Greece and Serbia.  A story that was printed in various US newspapers in 1918 describes an incident in which a bird flew into the propellor of Keogh's plane, shearing off one of the blades at 2000 feet.  Keogh was able to get the plane to the ground and walked away from the wreck unhurt, though a French observer on board was killed.
Grenville Keogh married about 1919 Emma Mary Pallen.  The couple had six sons in succession followed by two daughters.

The poster on the wall behind the subjects is for a film, "Our American Boys in the European War", released by Triangle Film Corp. in 1916.  It featured the work of the American Red Cross and Ambulance Service in WWI.

December 10, 1916, SECTION TWO, image 30, column 1 oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83045782/1916-12-10/ed-1/se... reports that the Ballet Russe would be coming to Portland, Oregon in January 1917, with Flore Revalles, Ekaterina Galanta, Margareta Frohman, and Olga Spezisewa among the dancers. Goodwin's weekly : a thinking paper for thinking people. (Salt Lake City, Utah), 16 Dec. 1916. Page 36 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/2010218519/1916-12-16/ed-... has a picture of Ekaterina Galanta with Flore Revalles in Scheherezade

She was later known as Ketty Galanta, or de Galanta and Katherine Galanta, acting in movies and the stage. books.google.com/books?id=HdM_AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA1128&... www.imdb.com/name/nm0301620/?ref_=fn_al_nm_1 ibdb.com/person.php?id=41639 There is a 1917 biographical sketch in the Philadelphia Evening Public Ledger for September 22, 1917: "GALANTA DANCED FOR THE EX-CZAR But Since "Imperial" Ballet Is No More She Joins "Wanderer" A Russian dancer who came to America last season with Diaghileff's Ballet Russe and made such a hit here that she never returned to Russia is the principal feature of the ballet of "The Wanderer" at the Metropolitan Opera House. Her name Is Ketty de Galanta, and she has already attracted much attention because of her exceptional dancing and her beauty. Galanta is a graduate of the famous Imperial Opera House ballet, of Petrograd. She has been a dancer since she was six years old, when her parents in Russia entered her as a pupil of the Imperial Ballet. The training is so severe from infancy that now Galanta is an agile, lithe, sinuous and very athletic young woman, who also is the possessor of a pair of great dark eyes which dance and sparkle as she talks. She came to America with Nijinsky, and was dancing in this country when the Russian revolution took place. Inasmuch as the Imperial Russian Ballet is an institution which was sponsored by the Czar and paid for from his private purse, the whole establishment was abolished when the Czar lost his throne. Mademoiselle Galanta, therefore decided to remain in America, and signed a contract with her fellow countryman Morris Gest. who is also a Russian, to dance and act under the direction of the firm of Elliott, Comstock and Gest for the next five years. Her appearance in the ballet of "The Wanderer" is the first step toward ultimate stardom, for her personality is so striking that she is being taught English in the hope that she will become a dramatic star in several years." chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045211/1917-09-22/ed-...

I've recently completed an illustrated biography titled
THE ART OF PEACE on Prince Tokugawa Iesato and Baron Shibusawa Eiichi, who were friends and allies who worked together to maintain goodwill between the East and the West, and achieved amazing accomplishments.

The biography is available on Amazon as an eBook.

The website TheEmperorAndTheSpy.com has more information about THE ART OF PEACE and Baron Shibusawa and Prince Tokugawa.

Here is a link to the introduction to the biography.
theemperorandthespy.com/2019/10/the-art-of-peace-the-illu...

Regards,

Stan S. Katz
Looks like the Maha Chakri, as seen on www.bergstromsservice.se/thaipaviljongen/02/e_index.html and www.navy.mi.th/newwww/document/history/history_rtn/conten...

More history of the vessel is at www.shipstamps.co.uk/forum/viewtopic.php?f=2&t=13230 suggesting that in 1916 she might have been lying in Japan, with the intention of being scrapped. So this may have been part of the Bain series of pictures taken in Japan.

Some more Siamese Royal Yacht info.. According to this article, equipment from the 1897 yacht (presumably the one seen above) was incorporated into a new yacht of the same name built in Kobe in 1918: eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/strait... From this entry, it looks like she was "stricken" (decommissioned?) on June 23, 1916. books.google.com/books?id=V2r_TBjR2TYC&pg=PA423&l... and a further mention from July, 1916, that she was obsolete and to be sent to Japan: eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article.aspx?a... The Sunday Oregonian. (Portland, Ore.) November 05, 1916, used this photo with the caption: "The great King of Slam had a navy consisting of one cruiser. He hadn't much use for it, so he sent it to Japan recently and had it converted into a royal yacht. Possibly he will visit America on it." oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83045782/1916-11-05/ed-1/se... I agree this is part of the current Japan series (4025 8-13).

Several sources refer to the yacht as "Maha Chakri", "Maha Chakkri", "Maha Chakrin" ... , but it seems that the correct name is MAHA CHAKRKRI, see e.g. - www.shipstamps.co.uk/forum/viewtopic.php?f=2&t=13230, cited by [https://www.flickr.com/photos/23103743@N05] - www.agenziabozzo.it/navi_da_guerra/c-navi%20da%20guerra/C... - Marietta daily leader., July 13, 1897, Image 2 with drawing of the yacht - The Sunday Oregonian, November 04, 1917, Section One, Image 2, col. 1, "Yachts Converted Into Cargo Boats" and www.flickr.com/photos/44841559@N03/5470808751/
Thanks for discovering so much information about the yacht and the publication of the photo. We'll add information when we next update the description.
According to The Japan Review books.google.com/books?id=h3szAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA254&l... the Oriental Olympic Games were held in Shibaura, Tokyo in May 1916.

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/23103743@N05] This is curious. The date on the sticker is 10/25/16. And I didn't find any evidence in the newspapers that there were Oriental Olympic Games (also called Eastern or Far Eastern Olympiad) in 1916. There were such games 1913 in Manila (see e.g. The Evening standard., January 31, 1913, Image 2, col. 1 ), 1915 in Shanghai (Honolulu star-bulletin., August 16, 1915, 3:30 Edition, SHIPPING SECTION, Page TEN, col. 3) and 1917 in Tokyo (New-York tribune., July 01, 1917, Page 11 ). Perhaps it were trials for the games of 1917.

BTW: The fourth Far Eastern Olympic Games were held in 1919 in Manila again (The Kentuckian., August 30, 1919, Page 8, col. 4 ), and the next apparently in Shanghai in 1921 (The Bismarck tribune., September 14, 1921, Image 1, col. 5, "TRAMPLE ON TRADITION").

According to "India and the Olympics", by Boria Majumdar,Nalin Mehta, p. 110 books.google.com/books?id=E3ONAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA110&l..., the official name of these games from 1915 onwards was "Far Eastern Championship Games" (FECG). They have a wikipedia entry: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Far_Eastern_Games
Thanks for finding the official name of the games. We can add information when we next update the description.

So these may be trials in late 1916 for the games that were held in May 1917 in Tokyo. The Ogden standard., June 09, 1917, 4 P.M. CITY EDITION, Page 3 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85058396/1917-06-09/ed-... does call them the Oriental Olympic Games.

I haven't had much luck tracking down Gary's wife. But, in 1905 he married the former Mrs Alexander Stevenson Scott who had earlier been Mrs. Townsend of Chicago. See The San Francisco call., December 22, 1905, Page 1 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85066387/1905-12-22/ed-...

Judge Gary's first wife died in 1902. See Barre evening telegram. (Barre, Vt.), 23 June 1902. Page 4, Column 3 (towards bottom) chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn98060035/1902-06-23/ed-... The NYT of December 04, 1905 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F0CE7DB143DE733A... describes his wife as Mrs. Emma T. Scott and the daughter of M.R. Townsend of the northern part of "this state." In contrast to the San Francisco Call article cited above, she is described as a widow! From NYT of May 29, 1935 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F01E7DA173FE23AB... "Mrs. Emma T. Gary, widow of Elbert H. Gary, United States Steel Corporation official, who died on April 5, 1934" Her April 6, 1934 NYT obituary query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9406E1DF173CE23AB... relies on the NYT's report of their marriage and adds no further detail.

This is Margaret Preston Draper (1891-1974). Daughter of General William F. Draper, soldier, politician, diplomat and textile industrialist. On October 25, 1916, she was married in Washington, D.C. to Italian Prince Andrea Boncompagni Ludovici (sometimes Ludovisi) (1884-1972). Much about Margaret and her later life at: www.hope1842.com/drapermargaretwedding.html www.hope1842.com/draperprincesscurse.html www.oocities.org/daninhopedale/draperprincessbonadult.html dlib.cwmars.org/cdm4/document.php?CISOROOT=/hopedale&... Miss Draper was wooed by several titled Italians but her fancy chose Count Boncompagni, whom she has known since her childhood. Miss Draper is enormously wealthy and has homes in Boston and Washington. She has been in New York recently selecting her trousseau."

Brooklyn, apparently (Brooklyn Historical Society Blog): "...Tebo’s yacht basin sat at the foot of Twenty-Third Street. Another article “Tebo’s Yacht Basin Sold” describes the Tebo Yacht Basin as “a Brooklyn hospital for disabled vessels and a famous wintering place for the aristocracy of the sea.” The original owner of the Tebo Yacht Basin was Mr. William M. Tebo, a Flatbush millionaire and philanthropist according to his obituary. He suffered from paralysis for years before he passed away in 1900. Soon after Mr. Tebo’s death, C.B. Haviland and J. Wiliam Haviland Jr., two of the grandchildren of William Tebo, became sole owners of the property. It is unclear how long the Tebo Yacht Basin remained open after that, but this image provides a brief glimpse of it in its heyday." brooklynhistory.org/blog/2012/09/12/photo-of-the-week-fas... This yacht could be what was to become USS California: "Hauoli, a steam yacht, was built in 1903 by Robbins Drydock Company, Brooklyn, New York, and purchased by the Navy as California in August 1917 from her owner, Clara B. Stocker, of New York City. After fitting out, it commissioned at New York Navy Yard 24 December 1917," en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USS_California_(SP-249) www.history.navy.mil/photos/sh-usn/usnsh-h/sp249.htm She had been built as the Hauoli in 1903 for "Borax King" F.M. Smith. She was renamed California, then back again to Hauoli in February, 1918. Some news of the California from July, 1916. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=990DE6D7173BE6...

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/artolog] Your link is going to the disambiguation page rather than the page for the USS California you intended.But I think you are correct in your identification.  The July 1916 NYT piece indicates that she was brought from the Pacific Coast (which accounts for "Los Angeles" in the caption) and strongly suggests that she would have been on the East Coast the following winter.

Fixed the link, thanks. There is another California link in the ownership. Clara Baldwin Stocker was the heiress daughter of pioneer California zillionaire "Lucky" Baldwin. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lucky_Baldwin

Another site with ship details is www.navsource.org/archives/12/170249.htm Lloyd's Register of Yachts, 1917 books.google.com/books?id=x9VLAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA64&lp... confirms that the port of registry of Clara Baldwin Stocker's yacht California was San Pedro, Los Angeles, California.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sidney_Johnston_Catts "Sidney Johnston Catts (July 31, 1863—March 9, 1936) was an American politician and anti-Catholic spokesman. He was the 22nd Governor of Florida." "In 1916, he ran for Governor of Florida as a Democrat. He won the nomination at first, but a recount was ordered and he came in second. " "At the onset of World War I as Florida teemed with a never-before-seen wave of Anti-German sentiment, Catts attempted to exploit this to further his own previously mentioned Anti-Catholic and racist agendas. The governor publicly theorized that the monks of St. Leo Abbey near Tampa (many of whom were either German-Americans or German immigrants) were planning to arm Florida's African American community for a popular revolt in favor of Kaiser Wilhelm II, after which Pope Benedict XV (a well documented pacifist, who was Italian, not German) would take over Florida and move the Holy See to nearby San Antonio and close all of the Protestant churches. This actually caused a fair number of German settlers to move to friendlier parts of the country. "

Charles G. Treat (December 30, 1859 -- October 11, 1941), Major General in the United States Army en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Treat

This and the surrounding pictures were combined to illustrate the following story in the East Oregonian (Pendleton, Umatilla Co., Or.) of October 25, 1916" "THREE NEW GENERALS General Francis H. French, General Charles G. Treat., General Even [sic] Swift The American army, which has the best educated officers in the world (with the possible exception of the German army), now has three new generals. Colonel Francis H. French of the Twenty-first Infantry, has been promoted and will succeed General Granger Adams as chairman of the board to investigate rapid-fire guns, of which the United States will purchase $12,000,000 worth. Colonel Eben Swift, stationed at the army service school at Fort Leavenworth, will succeed General John J. Pershing, who becomes major general in succession to the late Major General Albert L. Mills. Colonel Charles G. Treat, of the field artillery, will become a brigadier to succeed General F. W. Sibley, retired. He is now of the general staff and vice president of the war college." oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn88086023/1916-10-25/ed-1/se...

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Bernhardt 'Sarah Bernhardt (c. 22/23 October 1844 – 26 March 1923) was a French stage and early film actress, and was referred to as "the most famous actress the world has ever known." Bernhardt made her fame on the stages of France in the 1870s, at the beginning of the Belle Epoque period, and was soon in demand in Europe and the Americas. She developed a reputation as a serious dramatic actress, earning the nickname "The Divine Sarah."' "She carried out a successful tour of America in 1915, and on returning to France she played in her own productions almost continuously until her death. "

She was in the U.S. in October 1916. Likely Laura Jay Wurts of Pittsburgh, the daughter of Professor Alexander Jay Wurts. The Honolulu star-bulletin., April 27, 1915, 3:30 Edition, Page 2, col. 2 "GUTHRIE SILENT ON MISSION OR ORIENT AFFAIRS" (according to this article, the wife of A. J. Wurts was a niece of the wife of Ambassador Georges W. Guthrie) reported that Laura Wurts had been a favorite of the younger set during their stay in Hawaii. An obituary of A. J. Wurts is in the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette - 22. Jan. 1932. It mentions his daughter, Mrs. Douglas Chandler. According to the German entry of Douglas Chandler (de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Douglas_Chandler, he has an English one as well (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Douglas_Chandler), but less extensive), Laura Wurts married Douglas Chandler in 1924. She died in 1942 (according to www.whoislog.info/profile/douglas-chandler.html, she died in 1941).

Douglas Chandler was apparently not her first husband, in 1917 Laura Jay Wurts was engaged to Bradley Lancaster Coley (s. The evening world., May 15, 1917, Final Edition, Page 9, col. 1; they married in June 1918 (The Pittsburgh Press - June 20, 1918, p. 23, col. 1 ).

" Laura Jay WURTS was born 16 Sep 1895 in Pittsburg, Pa. She died 1941 in Germany. She married Douglas Chandler 27 Aug 1924 in Bar Harbor, Hancock, Maine, USA." jsdubois28.com/2014/07/27/peter-augustus-jay-descendants/
Lady Haw-Haw?

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/artolog] Not exactly, Lady Haw-Haw would be Margaret Joyce, the wife of William "Lord Haw-Haw" Joyce (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Joyce, en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lord_Haw-Haw).
I skimmed Wikipedia too quickly, Time Magazine called her husband "American Lord Haw-Haw."  I guess she was Mrs. "Paul Revere", though she may have been dead before he started those broadcasts.

Ms. Miner, later Mrs. Hadden was clearly a tireless social activist on behalf of those less fortunate. See, for example, Crossing Over the Line: Legislating Morality and the Mann Act. By David J. Langum books.google.com/books?id=Hb8yvw31wZoC&pg=PA158&l... to discover that in 1916, she published, "Slavery of Prostitution: A Plea for Emancipation" and was secretary of the New York Probation and Protective Association. With her husband, Alexander Mectier Hadden, she was a founder of the Institute of World Affairs, www.iwa.org/pages/Work.html It seems odd that she hasn't warranted a Wikipedia entry.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Percy_Haughton "Percy Duncan Haughton (July 11, 1876 – October 27, 1924) was an American football and baseball player and coach. He served as head football coach at Cornell University from 1899 to 1900, at Harvard University from 1908 to 1916, and at Columbia University from 1923 to 1924, compiling a career college football record of 97–17–6. The Harvard Crimson claim national champions for three of the seasons that Haughton coached: 1910, 1912, and 1913. Haughton was also Harvard's head baseball coach in 1915 and part owner of the Boston Braves from 1916 to 1918."
LOC, it's not clear why the SABR Historical Research Committee dated this as 1915.  It seems pretty clear from the context that this is the 1916 World Series.

The National League Championship pennants in the photo say 1916 on them, strongly suggesting that these are Brooklyn fans at the 1916 World Series. Though the team was known as the Robins in this era, it was also commonly referred to as the Superbas and the Dodgers, as seen on the pennants here, long before the official change to that name around 1932. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_Brooklyn_Dodgers At right is Mrs. Edward J. McKeever (Jennie Veronica Murphy McKeever , (1862-1942)), wife of one of the Brooklyn team's owners. her NYT obit from September, 1942: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9C06E0DE1339E33BB... See also

Annual Report of the Public Service Commission, Second District, Volume 2 books.google.com/books?id=qrVKZUyH9sEC&pg=PA83&lp... suggests that M. V. Woods was General Manager of McKeever's company (at least in 1906).

Brooklyn Eagle of April 14, 1918, page 11 www.newspapers.com/newspage/55293324/ mentions "Mrs. Edw. McKeever, ... Mrs. Jennie Dalton, Miss Catherine Conklin," close together in the Brookyn Society column.

Good catch, this is obviously Mrs. McK.'s box, and these are her buddies (and Mrs. Woods' son, probably). The program being held up behind J. Woods and Jennie Dalton marks this as being from Braves Field in Boston, probably game one of the 1916 World Series, played October 7, 1916. Though Fenway Park was the regular park of the Red Sox, they chose to play the World Series in the National League park of the Braves due to its vastly larger capacity. here's the program: fenwaypark100.files.wordpress.com/2012/03/2012program1916... www.baseball-almanac.com/ws/yr1916ws.shtml

The Brooklyn Robins/Dodgers ownership group, elated to have won the 1916 National League championship after a 16-year drought, and their team's manager Wilbert Robinson, during the 1916 World Series, the first played at Ebbets Field. "Charles Hercules Ebbets, Sr. (October 29, 1859–April 18, 1925) was an American sports executive who owned the Brooklyn Dodgers from 1902 to 1925." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Ebbets "Wilbert Robinson (June 29, 1863 – August 8, 1934), nicknamed "Uncle Robbie", was an American catcher, coach and manager in Major League Baseball. He was inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1945." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilbert_Robinson "Stephen W. McKeever (October 31, 1853 in Brooklyn, New York – March 7, 1938) was a construction contractor in Brooklyn, New York in the early 1900s. Steve and his brother Ed bought half of the Brooklyn Dodgers baseball team from Henry Medicus on January 2, 1912. Together with co-owner Charles Ebbets they built what became Ebbets Field. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stephen_McKeever Edward J. This is former Brooklyn Superbas pitcher Bill Pounds addressing the 1916 team as it left Brooklyn on October 6, 1916 to play the Boston Red Sox in the World Series. Presumably, that's him standing in the second street level window from the left, cupping his hands in front of his mouth. The Sun's account of the parade mentions the stop at the Y, but not Pounds. The sun. (New York [N.Y.]) , October 07, 1916, chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030431/1916-10-07/ed-... The Bedford Branch of the YMCA is still at the corner of Bedford and Monroe in Brooklyn, now the Bedford-Stuyvesant Branch. This building on the corner is now gone, but in the current Google Street View, the building across Monroe still stands, though now boarded up. www.google.com/maps/@40.685264,-73.954288,3a,75y,122.59h,... A copy of this photo that was auctioned had the following description: "This superb Bain image shows Bill Pounds addressing the Brooklyn Dodgers in front of the YMCA as they prepare to head to Boston for the 1916 World Series. A large crowd is gathered in front of the YMCA and cars are double parked in the street. A few police are on hand to maintain control but the crowd appears to be well behaved. Photo has along its top edge, in white “Pounds Addressing Bklyn Team.” To the right, in black, “4010-4.” Reverse has “Departure of Brooklyns from Brooklyn for Boston Oct. 6, 1916.” www.lelands.com/auction/AuctionDetail/28571/December-2005... "Jeared Wells "Bill" Pounds (March 11, 1878 – July 7, 1936) was a pitcher in Major League Baseball. He pitched in two games during the 1903 baseball season." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Pounds

NYT of Oct 2, 1916 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9E06E1DD1630E733A... reports that Tree arrived in New York on the liner Philadelphia on October 1, 1916. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_G._Blaine and en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_G._Blaine#Mulligan_letters "Blaine entered the 1876 presidential campaign as the favorite, but his chances were almost immediately harmed by the emergence of a scandal. Rumors had begun to spread in February of that year that Blaine had been involved in a transaction with the Union Pacific Railroad in which the railroad had paid Blaine $64,000 for some Little Rock and Fort Smith Railroad bonds he owned, even though the bonds were nearly worthless; in essence, the alleged transaction was a sham designed to bribe Blaine. Blaine denied the charges, as did the Union Pacific's directors. Blaine claimed he never had any dealings with the Little Rock and Fort Smith Railroad except to purchase bonds at market price, and that he had lost money on the transaction. Democrats in the House of Representatives nevertheless demanded a Congressional investigation. The testimony appeared to favor Blaine's version of events until May 31, when James Mulligan, a Boston clerk formerly employed by Blaine's brother-in-law, testified that the allegations were true, that he had arranged the transaction, and that he had letters to prove it. The letters ended with the damning phrase, "Kindly burn this letter." When the investigating committee recessed, Blaine met with Mulligan in his hotel room; what transpired between the men is unknown, but Blaine left with the letters and refused to turn them over to the committee." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Penny-farthing "About 1870, English inventor James Starley, described as the father of the bicycle industry, and others began producing bicycles based on the French boneshaker but with front wheels of increasing size, because larger front wheels, up to 1.5 m (60 in) in diameter, enabled higher speeds on bicycles limited to direct drive. In 1878, Albert Pope began manufacturing the Columbia bicycle outside of Boston, starting their two-decade heyday in America. Although the trend was short-lived, the penny-farthing became a symbol of the late Victorian era. Its popularity also coincided with the birth of cycling as a sport."

"A mechanical and aeronautical engineer, not really remembered as a driver, Glover was more behind the scenes, firstly as Mercer team manager, and then found fame by developing the two speed rear axle which would be adopted by Ford’s Model T trucks. While he had been involved in automobile racing, aviation was his main interest. He became head of the Hall Scott Airplane department, before setting up his own manufacturing company, being closely intertwined with Ford. A licensed pilot and engine mechanic, he founded the company, Grand Canyon-Boulder Dam Tours, which was the first enterprise to provide comprehensive tourist services. His background in automobile and machine shops earned him a World War I commission in the United States of America Aeroservice Aircraft Production Department. " Bio above from www.oac.cdlib.org/findaid/ark:/13030/kt2c60364c/admin/ See also www.dmairfield.org/people/ruckstell_ge/ From www.jalopyjournal.com/forum/threads/auto-racing-1894-1944... A few more observations: They are all in the same uniform, with the same star-shaped badge on their lower right chest (left as we view them). I haven't found a good match for the uniforms although www.ottoman-uniforms.com/ww1-turkish-medical-branch/ shows at least one person with the same star. The one thing that differs is the number of apparent stripes in the insignia that is attached to the second button down. In s400910952.websitehome.co.uk/germancolonialuniforms/milit... the second buttonhole is mentioned as being a location for indicating a medal, by wearing the ribbon without the medal itself. Following the medal thread, I find, from www.gwpda.org/medals/turkmedl/turkey.html that the star badge is the Turkish War Medal and that its ribbon was commonly worn in the second buttonhole. So we have six men who were awarded this medal, which was given from 1915 -- indicating that the photo is from 1915 or later. www.ottoman-uniforms.com/ottoman-turkish-orders-medals-an... indicates that the medal was distributed "lavishly" according to the Illustrated War News of Sept 29, 1916.

First date on sticker and negative, 9/30/1916. Related to this story from July 31, 1916: "REBELS BURN CITY Hankow, China, Being Looted by Revolutionaries. FOREIGN INTERESTS LARGE. Robert Dollar Steamship Company Gets Word That Premises Adjoining Its Lumber and Shipping Yards Are In Flames. SAN FRANCISCO. July 3I. Hankow, China, today was in the hands of a revolutionary mob, and great quantities of property were being burned, according to cable advices received here by the Robert Dollar Steamship Company from its Hankow office. No details were received. The Dollar Company's advices said that the .premises adjoining their lumber and shipping yards in Hankow were in flames, but that their holdings were not endangered. The steamship company officials took this to indicate that the German concessions and a portion of the native residence section were burning, as they adjoin the Dollar property. Hankow is a city of 1.250,000 population, in the Province of Hupeh. Large foreign holdings are situated near the Dollar property. Revolutionary attempt was directed by the leaders of the Kuo-Ming-Tang, the radical revolutionary party of China, against the military Governor Tuchun Wang. The rioters started from the Japanese concession. . The demonstration apparently was planned-to frighten the Pekin government into granting the Kuo-Ming-Tang a larger recognition in the government at the meeting of Parliament, which begins tomorrow." oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83025138/1916-08-01/ed-1/se... Hankou (or Hankau or Hankow) has apparently been incorporated into Wuchan, China. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wuhan en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hankou_District See also

There was an Otho Budd, but this is not him. Instead it is Otto W. Budd (Otto Williams Budd, Jr.) of San Antonio, Texas, who was returning on Rochambeau from his work as an ambulance driver in France. The N.Y. Evening Telegram account of the Rochambeau's arrival mentions him, as well as Marjorie Kay "who has been an American ambulance nurse in France for the last four months." fultonhistory.com/Newspapers%206/New%20York%20NY%20Evenin... books.google.com/books?id=RToyAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA338&l... centennialbook.afs.org/Celebrations/WWIDrivers/578

Marjorie Kay is also Margery Kay in some sources and there are a number of news photos of her, mostly in nurse uniform, up to the early 20's. In 2003, the Connecticut state archivist published a biographical sketch: "On July 27, 1949, Marjorie Kay was buried with full military honors in Soldiers’ Field at Northwood Cemetery in Wilson, Connecticut. Before that, mourners had assembled at the Molloy Funeral Home. One can only imagine the stories about Kay that her friends and admirers shared. An obituary in the June 27 newspaper, The Hartford Times, commented that she had led “an unusually colorful life.” Those who gathered undoubtedly knew that she was a fearless Navy nurse in World War I, a model for a famous war poster, a soprano who sang at New York’s Metropolitan Opera, an entertainer, and in Hartford, a dance instructor and talent agency director. We know little about her family except that at the time of her death, her father, Richard Day Kay, a retired jeweler, lived in Hartford. Obituaries mentioned that she was from Detroit. A press release in 1922 stated that she was a “former Detroit Society Girl. When she was young, she and many other countrywomen launched themselves into the first industrial supplied war, so vast and destructive that people referred to it as the “Great War.” Both the Navy and Army had created auxiliary nurses corps before the nation had entered the war. Kay joined the Naval Nurse Corps and at the age of 17 achieved the rank of Yeoman First Class. Yeoman Kay served on the Western Front from May to September, 1916, first at an American Ambulance Hospital at Nevilly – sur – Seine, France and thereafter in base hospitals with Mrs. William K. Vanderbuilt. There were two stories about her bravery. The first contended that she was one of the first American women to drive an ambulance behind enemy lines to pick up wounded. Another said that she was the first woman on the Western Front to fly across enemy lines, most likely with other medics. In the folder about her in the State Archives, there is a photograph of her assisting a doctor in an operation and a medal showing a nurse giving aid to a fallen soldier. Another story relates that when she returned stateside, she was chosen as the model for a Red Cross fund raising poster. She was dressed in nurse’s garb and her hands and arms were outstretched. The only word on the poster was “Give.” She was proud of it, and kept a copy of the poster on the walls of her apartment that her third husband and she shared on Mulberry St. in Hartford. continued From the State Archives: Yeoman Third Class Marjorie Kay Mark H. Jones, State Archivist Portrait of Marjorie Kay as Red Cross NurseVolume 5 Number 2 PAGE 5 The CONNector The CONNector She became a dancer and studied as coloratura soprano. Friends stated that she had sung with Enrico Caruso at the Met. By the mid – 1920’s, she settled in Hartford, that had been a stop along the Keith – Albee Circuit. She opened a dancing school and later directed a successful talent agency. The Hartford Times noted that she was “one of Hartford’s best known entertainers.” The Courant observed that on the walls of the apartment that her husband and she shared hung “pictures of Miss Kay in costume taken when she was on the stage.” The Times emphasized her beauty: “Tall, stately, slim and blond, Miss Kay never lost the beauty that helped bring her success in the entertainment field.” She received a life - long pension from the Federal government for her military service. Among keepsakes from the war, she kept a belt to which were attached “fifty four buttons, collar ornaments, shoulder badges, hat badges and Belt Buckles” from Allied armies and even those of Germany and Austria. Unfortunately we do not know the fate of her copy of the Red Cross poster or the decorative World War I belt. The file on her comes from the War Records Department that operated in the State Library from 1917 to the 1950’s. A man from Florida, one of her two former husband’s or a close supporter, mailed the contents to the State Library in 1952. From the State Archives’ “attic,” we present her for your interest and amusement." www.cslib.org/connector/0403.pdf Billboard also ran a brief obit in 1949: books.google.com/books?id=LfYDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA49&lp...

(1874-1952) — of Binghamton, Broome County, N.Y. Born in Binghamton, Broome County, N.Y., June 4, 1874. Democrat. Chair of Broome County Democratic Party, 1910; delegate to Democratic National Convention from New York, 1912, 1920, 1924; candidate for New York state attorney general, 1916; New York Democratic state chair, 1919-21. His NYT obituary query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9401E1D6153CE23BB... does not mention his wife or children. Le Phare (lighthouse) de France established a facility in Paris in 1916 and later in other cities. The Lighthouse had been a U.S. organization for the blind and The U.S. sponsored the French offshoot which served soldiers blinded in battle. The international organization still exists. See www.lighthouse.org/
This photo is already found on Flickr, with a detailed caption, at where it is described as a postcard.

According to The Sunday Oregonian, December 10, 1916, Le Phare de France was established by Winifred Holt (the text is: "Winifred Holt, a New York woman has returned from Paris to raise money for the support of the "Phare de France" or "Lighthouse" for the blind, which she established there. Since the beginning of the war the "Lighthouses" at Paris, Bordeaux and other cities established under the plans of Miss Holt have cared for 300 blind and 3000 partly blind French soldiers.") See also en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lighthouse_International and en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Winifred_Holt Photos of W. Holt and blind soldiers are already in this photostream: www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/9577523264/ www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/9574728089/ www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/9577522622/

Other articles about Le Phare de France: - El Paso herald., November 25, 1916, HOME EDITION, Cable News and Auto Section, Image 15, "LIGHTHOUSE FOR BLIND IS UNIQUE", and - Evening public ledger., February 07, 1917, Night Extra, Page 2, "HOW SHE MAKES BLIND MEN SEE TOLD BY SOLDIERS' WOMAN FRIEND - Winifred Holt Describes Wonder Work of "Phare de France"".
The organization Winifred and Edith Holt formed in the US was called The Lighthouse. In 2024, its descendant organization is The Lighthouse Guild. See lighthouseguild.org/about-us/our-history/

A little more on Canadian internment camps, though I haven't seen anything on a camp in "Temple, Alberta." www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/internment/ There was a large camp in Alberta: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Castle_Mountain_Internment_Camp Which the Duke visited: www.infoukes.com/history/internment/gallery/page-005.html books.google.com/books?id=0H-PMNunqCwC&pg=PA38&lp...

Mount Temple is in Banff National Park, as is Castle Mountain. I found myself wondering if the camp being visited here is actually the Castle Mountain one. The two peaks are quite close but on opposite sides of the Bow River valley through which Route 1 runs. See maps.google.com/maps?ll=51.3184005,-116.0488198&z=12

www.infoukes.com/history/internment/booklet03/figure39.jpg is from an album from the Castle Mountain camp [ www.infoukes.com/history/internment/booklet03/page-4.html ] and shows "Temple Mountain." It could be the same ridge in the background. And here are pictures from the same album that shows "the duke" -- clearly Connaught. See www.infoukes.com/history/internment/booklet03/page-5.html

In the Shadow of the Rockies: Diary of the Castle Mountain Internment Camp, 1915-1917 books.google.com/books?id=0H-PMNunqCwC&pg=PA37&lp... indicates that Connaught visited Castle Mountain on Sept 14, 1915. It also indicates in a footnote that he visited the camp again in July 1916. Page 78 of the same book indicates that the second visit was on July 17, 1916. "Mr. W. R. Baker, Vice-president C.P.R. was also with the party." Perhaps he is pictured here. C.P.R. would be Canadian Pacific Railway.
W. R. Baker would be Walter Reginald Baker. See westendvancouver.wordpress.com/biographies-a-m/biographie... Photo is compatible but not a clear match.

I think the fact that a Mt. Temple is in the vicinity of the Castle Mountain camp is enough for a fair ID of this as the Castle Mountain camp.
Not to mention the photos of Connaught there.
Humorous aside from Baker's Wikipedia page:
"Retlaw, Alberta, Walter spelled backwards, named in honour of Walter Reginald Baker."
One wonders.. why not just name it Walter.. or Bakersville or something. There must be a story there.

In 1916 Caspar F. Goodrich was a retired Admiral of the US Navy soon to be recalled to service during WWI. He published an article in the Philadelphia Public Inquirier which was widely cited. He was a strong proponent of acquiring the Danish West Indies for US military use. He was also a proponent of universal conscription
In 1916 he was in the newspapers because he married Sarah Hays as well, s. The Hays free press., October 14, 1916, Image 6, with (another) photo.

He was 69 in  1916, so the picture does have to be much older.

Margaret Lawrence Taylor b. May 08, 1916 d. January 26, 2012, in York Harbor, York, Maine. Married Granger Kent Costikyan. 3. Virginia Taylor b. November 03, 1921 4. Hope Taylor Loomis' occupations included stage manager of the Metropolitan opera house, stage director 28, owned his own real estate company and broker. Should be Barnhart. The Craftsman (September 1916 digicoll.library.wisc.edu/cgi-bin/DLDecArts/DLDecArts-idx... featured an article on the New York Community Chorus which says, "Mr. Harry Barnhart, the leader of the New York Community Chorus ..."

A contemporary biographical sketch from 1917: "Harry Barnhart, whose photograph appears on another page, is one of those natural musical geniuses who possess magnetism and power of leadership. He is an American, is about forty five years of age and is not only a dreamer of dreams but a worker of wonders. For a dozen years he dreamed of community choruses and then his dreams came true first in Los Angeles, California then in Rochester, New York and finally in New York City. For nearly two years he has been leading vast choruses of plain people in New York City and opening their souls to the joys of music not merely the hearing of music but the making of it. He began with classes in the public schools; now the New York Community Chorus has the use of the great hall of the City College. Last winter the Chorus numbering eighteen hundred gave Handel's Messiah in Madison Square Garden before an audience of ten thousand. Last June it gave Haydn's Creation in the Hippodrome before another vast audience. The current week it gives a great open air Song and Light Festival at night in Central Park. A thousand children will participate in this festival accompanied by a thousand adults and two thousand soldiers and scores of thousands of volunteers. For Mr Barnhart has the faculty of making people sing who did not know they possessed the power of singing. He makes soldiers sing, he makes baseball fans sing, he can make any crowd join in and thoroughly enjoy a song." The Outlook, 1917 books.google.com/books?id=f5_PAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA82&lp...

Another source describes him as Harry H. Barnhart (1874–1948). www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/03007766.2010.521441... A 1931 article: "The community singing movement, which began in 1912, was launched by one Harry Barnhart, a singer, musician and conductor, who was filling a vau- deville engagement at Rochester, New York. He made a feature of getting the onlookers to join in the chorus of his songs. Finding that everybody wished to sing, and could sing, under proper encouragement and leadership, he set out to develop the idea. With the leave of the Mayor he appeared with tho Municipal Band in the Convention Hall, and asked the audience to sing. They responded enthusiastically. Thus was formed the first community chorus. The idea spread to other centres, and in 1914 many of the community singers met at a great festival at Rochester, forming a trained chorus of 1,500 sing- ers. The American composer, Arthur Farwell, became deeply interested in tho movement, and Induced Mr. Barn- hart to visit New York once a week to conduct a community chorus. Dur- ing this time Claude Bragdon, an archi- tect and author living at Rochester, saw the possibilities of combining light and colour with outdoor singing. Crowds up to 15,000 gathered in a public park, and were led by a trained community singing group. This became known as "song and light." In New York a great chorus was trained which gave Handel's "Messiah" in Madison Square Garden, and three yearly "song and light festivals" in Central Park, with 100,000 persons singing antiphonally across the lake at night time. " trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/29922848#pstart1812626

The site stokowski.org uses this photo with the caption " Michel Penha in about 1920",[though the insciptions on the sticker and the negative say either 7/22/16 or 9/22/16], before the following biographical sketch: "Michel Penha was born in December 14, 1888 in Amsterdam, the Netherlands. He came from a musical family, his father Maurice Penha also being a musician. Penha graduated from the Amsterdam Conservatoire in 1905, at age 16 165. He had studied with Isaac Mossel (1870-1923). Penha also studied with Hugo Becker (1864-1941), perhaps at Dr. Hoch’s Konservatorium in Frankfurt. Michel Penha made his first concert appearance in Amsterdam in 1907 and then toured Europe. He relocated to New York in 1909. From 1909-1918, Michel Penha was active in New York City as part of the Tollefsen Piano Trio 167, led by Carl Tollefsen, at that time first violin of the New York Symphony. Michel Penha also formed the Penha Trio, based in New York City. Penha also performed chamber music recitals in New York. In 1915-1916, Penha toured South America with Chilean composer and pianist Alberto Guerrero (1886-1959) including in Bolivia, Peru, Panama, Costa Rica, and Cuba. In the 1920-1921 season, Michel Penha was appointed Principal cello of the Philadelphia Orchestra by Leopold Stokowski. Penha was Principal cello for five seasons, beginning in 1920, the same season in which Romain Verney joined the Philadelphia Orchestra as Principal viola. Also like his friend Verney, Michel Penha left the Philadelphia Orchestra at the end of the 1924-1925 season to relocate to San Francisco. Michel Penha become Principal cello of the San Francisco Symphony appointed by Alfred Hertz in the 1925-1926 season. In the late 1920s, Penha and Verney were together members of two string quartets, chamber music groups forming an important part of Penha's career. These were the California String Quartet: Robert Pollack first, William Wolski second, Romain Verney viola, and Michel Penha cello, which continued into the 1940s. The other was the Abas String Quartet, with Nathan Abas first, Hubert Sorenson (1910-1971) second, Abraham Weiss viola and (for at least part of the time) Michel Penha cello. In 1938, Michel Penha was a member of the San Francisco String Quartet, founded by SFS Concertmaster Naoum Blinder: Naoum Blinder first, William Wolski second, Romain Verney viola, and Michel Penha cello. Penha in 1930 relocated to Portland, Oregon for a time, although still active in the San Francisco area. In Oregon, he played in the Neah–Kah–Nie String Quartet: Susie Fennell Pipes first, Hubert Sorenson second, Alexander Vdovin viola and Michel Penha cello. In 1951 in California, Penha joined the Roussel Trio of Doriot Anthony (later Dwyer) flute, Harry Rumpler viola, and Michel Penha cello, based in Los Angeles. Penha was also active as a Hollywood studio musician at the MGM Studios166. Michel Penha seems never to have married, and died in Los Angeles in February 10, 1982, age 93." www.stokowski.org/Philadelphia_Orchestra_Musicians.htm He played a recital in New York in October, 1916: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9C06E6DC1F3FE2...

Timeline for Caterpillar tractors is at: www.caterpillar.com/en/company/history.html "Even before the U.S. formally entered WWI, Holt had shipped 1,200 tractors to England, France and Russia for agricultural purposes. These governments, however, sent the tractors directly to the battlefront where the military put them to work hauling artillery and supplies. These tractors also provided members of the British army with the inspiration needed to design the tank. Colonel E. D. Swinton had seen Holt's Caterpillar tractors in action and borrowed their track-laying principle to provide the tank with its form of locomotion. After the U.S. declaration of war, Holt placed its facilities at the disposal of the government. The Holt Manufacturing Company had advantages over other tractor companies due to the relationship it had developed with the U.S. Army Ordnance Department. In fact, bids from the Ordnance department called for specifications of the "Caterpillar type." Holt expanded factories to accommodate production of the large numbers of tractors the government required. Over 5,000 Holt tractors were produced for the U.S. and Allied governments during World War I."
Looks like tractor in photo used in Wikipedia article on Holt Manufacturing Company (later Caterpillar, Inc.) en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holt_Manufacturing_Company#mediavie...

Little Syria was a largely Arab-American but widely diverse neighborhood that existed in the New York City borough of Manhattan from the late 1880s until the 1940s. Also called the Syrian Quarter, it encompassed Washington Street from Battery Park to above Rector Street. The enclave, in its greatest reach, overlapped with the future site of the World Trade Center – the cornerstone of St. Joseph's Maronite Church was found in the rubble after the September 11 attacks. It declined as a neighborhood as the inhabitants became successful and moved to other areas, especially Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn, and disappeared almost entirely when a great deal of lower Washington Street was demolished to make way for entrance ramps to the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Little_Syria,_Manhattan
