Strikebreaker, aka Scab. After God had finished the rattlesnake, the toad, and the vampire, He had some awful substance left with which He made a scab. A scab is a two-legged animal with a corkscrew soul, a water brain, a combination backbone of jelly and glue. Where others have hearts, he carries a tumor of rotten principles. When a scab comes down the street, men turn their backs and Angels weep in Heaven, and the Devil shuts the gates of hell to keep him out. No man (or woman) has a right to scab so long as there is a pool of water to drown his carcass in, or a rope long enough to hang his body with. Judas was a gentleman compared with a scab. For betraying his Master, he had character enough to hang himself. A scab has not. Esau sold his birthright for a mess of pottage. Judas sold his Savior for thirty pieces of silver. Benedict Arnold sold his country for a promise of a commission in the British Army. The scab sells his birthright, country, his wife, his children and his fellowmen for an unfulfilled promise from his employer. Esau was a traitor to himself; Judas was a traitor to his God; Benedict Arnold was a traitor to his country; a SCAB is a traitor to his God, his country, his family and his class. -widely attributed (though erroneously) to Jack London. Published several times in newspapers in this era.

See ithacamovies.proboards.com/thread/177 "The "Beatrice Fairfax" series tells the story of a fictional New York newspaper columnist who gets into trouble while trying to solve her readers' problems. In "Play Ball" Thomas plays the fiancee to actor Nigel Barrie's Bert Kerrigan, a baseball player who is kidnapped, along with Thomas, to prevent his participation at a baseball game. The film includes actual footage of the New York Giants and the New York Yankees at a polo field in New York City. Because of the rarity of the footage of these New York teams, this episode was donated to the National Baseball Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, NY."

I wonder if this series of baseball-related shots at the Polo Grounds was taken at the filming of "Play Ball." Looks like Grace Darling and Harry Fox, lead actors in the serial, were there, as well as these two. Not to mention the managers of the Yankees and Giants, who would never have met to play at the Polo Grounds unless it was the World Series. www.imdb.com/title/tt0201455/fullcredits?ref_=tt_cl_sm#cast LOC has a copy of the film: lccn.loc.gov/97518304 "[Thomas'] first film role was in "PlayBall" in 1916, which was produced and directed by the Wharton Brothers here in Ithaca and in New York City for the International Film Company, owned by media mogul William Randolph Hearst." Hearst was also present in this series of pictures "The year 1916 brought more success with [Thomas'] first film role in "Beatrice Fairfax." She appeared in Episode 10, titled "Play Ball," which featured 18,000 baseball fans plus managers of the New York Yankees and New York Giants baseball teams. That year, she became the Yankees' official mascot. www.post-gazette.com/life/lifestyle/2010/09/26/Olive-Thom...

This photo was published in the Morning Oregonian, September 16, 1916 with the caption "LABOR LEADERS IN NEW YORK WHO DIRECT STREETCAR STRIKE". The names of the persons are below the photo. The evening world., September 11, 1916, Final Edition, Page 2 has another photo of the same group.

from the Oregonian: " LABOR LEADERS IN NEW YORK WHO DIRECT STREETCAR STRIKE BACK ROW C. A. SEVERS, LOUIS FRIDIGER (ATTORNEY FOR STREET RAILWAY UNION). WILLIAM COLLINS, P. J. ROONEY, E. A. RALEIGH, JOHN SULLIVAN, J. P. COUGHLIN, F. S. TOMLIN. FRONT ROW J. R. BUCHANAN, W. P. FITZGERALD (ORGANIZER OF STREET RAILWAY MEN), HUGH FRAYNE, MAURICE DEYOUNG, M. J. WALSH AND OTTO NICHOLS. Frayne was chairman of the meeting at. which the photograph was taken, which included representatives of the brewery workers, printers, machinists, moulders, longshoremen and theater workers. The meeting was held last Sunday to discuss the question of a general sympathetic strike." This is probably the 9/10/16 meeting of the Conference Committee representing New York organized labor described in a 9/11/1916 NYT report, called to discuss a massive sympathy strike in support of the striking subway carmen. Among those named in the Oregonian's caption, the article mentions Otto Nichols of the Brooklyn Central Labor Union, Hugh Frayne, State Organizer for the American Federation of Labor and chairman of the committee, and William Fitzgerald the carmen's general organizer. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9C05E2DF1F3FE233A... We saw Louis Fridiger and William B. Fitzgerald in other Bain photos related to the strike:

William J. Patterson of Pittsburgh, Pa., 1838 - 1926 (according to www.icyousee.org/pa62d/f.html) In 1916, he was elected commander-in-chief of the Grand Army of the Republic, s. The sun., September 02, 1916, Image 1, col. 7 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030431/1916-09-02/ed-....

His badge is not the regular GAR badge but that of a Past Department Commander (two stars.)  Patterson was the Department Commander in Pennsylvania 1898-1899.  

The Maltese Cross below the second bar is fairly unique.  The Woman's Relief Corps (a sort of Ladies' Auxiliary to the GAR) used the Maltese Cross on its badges but I don't think Patterson was a member of the Ladies' Auxiliary.  During the war the Maltese Cross was badge of the Fifth Army Corps.  Patterson's Regiment, the 62nd Pennsylvania, was part of the V Corps and I believe that is what is represented by that badge.

John Raleigh Mott (May 25, 1865-January 31, 1955) was a member of the Mexico American Commission in the Fall of 1916 (at lower left in picture below): In 1946, he won the Nobel Peace Prize. "The Peace Prize for 1946 was awarded to the head of the Young Men's Christian Association (YMCA), the American John Raleigh Mott, who according to the Nobel Committee had contributed to the creation of a peace-promoting religious brotherhood across national boundaries. Mott grew up in a settler family in Iowa, strongly influenced by Puritan ideals, and took a bachelor's degree in history at Cornell University. As a student Mott received a religious call to spread the Gospel, after which he devoted most of his life to the YMCA, to missionary activities, and ecumenical work. As general-secretary of the International Committee of the YMCA and president of YMCA's World Committee, Mott sought to advance understanding and reconciliation. He organized youth exchanges, set up study groups, and arranged international youth camps. Mott was at the same time a leading figure in the field of international Christian student and missionary cooperation, and took part during both World Wars in relief work for prisoners of war. He criticised the oppression of colonial peoples and was a pioneer in the struggle against racial discrimination." www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/peace/laureates/1946/mott... Though there is a date of 1929 on the photo, that is likely a re-use. Mott was decorated by the Japanese in June, 1929. The New York Times ran a photo at that time of a much older Mott. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9806EFD71531E73AB...

This photo was published in the July 24, 1916 issue of Aerial Age Weekly (Vol. 3, No. 19), page 560, with the caption: Frank H. Burnside, Lieut. Anthony Sunderland, National Guard Student, James D. Hill, Instructor, Corp. Chas. Robbins, Ark. National Guard Student at the Thomas School of Flying. Lieut. Sunderland is Mayor of Danbury, Conn. and the first mayor in the United States to take up aviation in the interest of "Preparedness." See: books.google.com/books?id=AHjmAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA560&l... Here's a photo of James DeWitt Hill from 1924 in the Smithsonian's photostream on the Flickr Commons. Hill would perish with fellow aviator Lloyd Bertaud and Hearst New York Daily Mirror editor Philip A. Payne, when their aircraft "Old Glory" (Fokker F.VIIa, reg. NX703) vanished over the Atlantic Ocean in September 1927 during an attempted non-stop flight between Old Orchard Beach, Maine and Rome, Italy. [https://www.flickr.com/photos/smithsonian/4011398902/in/set-72157605338989538] See: www.historynet.com/old-glorys-final-ill-fated-flight-new-... en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_DeWitt_Hill en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lloyd_W._Bertaud

The June 26, 1916 Aerial Age adds further context to the photo: "Thomas Company to Train Militia Aviators An offer to train three aviators free of charge has been received by the Aero Club of America from the Thomas Brothers Aeroplane Company. As the Aero Club has been flooded with applications from the National Guard of practically every one of the forty eight States and from civilians who are anxious to take a course in aviation, this offer of the Thomas Company was very welcome. Following the policy of giving preference to those who asked first, the Executive Committee of the Aero Club selected three officers whose applications were received several months ago. Lieut. Anthony Sunderland, First Lieutenant, Connecticut Coast Artillery Corps and Mayor of Danbury Conn. was the first to take advantage of the Thomas Company's offer and is now training at the Thomas School at Ithaca. Lieut H.F. Wakefield of the Vermont National Guard and Lieut Keeling R. Pulliam of the Kentucky National Guard have been offered the two remaining Thomas scholarships. In the event of the Mexican situation preventing any of these officers from taking the course, the scholarships will be granted to Corporal Chas. T Robins of the Arkansas National Guard and Lieut W.E. Lewis of the Illinois National Guard. The applications from men who wish to learn to fly are flooding the Aero Club. They come from every walk of life, all of whom have one desire: to learn to fly so as to be of maximum service to this country in case of trouble." books.google.com/books?id=AHjmAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA560&l...

The Thomas School of Flying was in Ithaca, NY. See archiver.rootsweb.ancestry.com/th/read/NYTOMPKI/2002-11/1... "An April 24, 1915, issue of The Ithaca Journal reported that a Thomas hydroaeroplane was flying on the lake and that it was being used by pupils in the Thomas Flying School. The Thomases built two wooden hangars along the lakeshore and a small marine railway to launch and retrieve the aircraft. As international pressures built toward World War I, the U.S. Navy ordered two flying boats at $12,000 each. The Thomas-Morse Aircraft Company began the manufacture of land-based planes, especially the popular trainer known as the Scout. In 1916 the peach trees were cleared to make a proper runway for the biplanes and pilots were trained to fly them. Frank Burnside was the first pilot in Tompkins County, having moved here with the Thomas brothers."

The aircraft in the background is a Thomas SH-4, a floatplane derivative of the Thomas T-2 land-based biplane. Linked below are two photos of the type on Page 952 of the September 13, 1917 issue of the British aviation journal Flight: www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1917/1917%20-%200952...
Frank Burnside was living in Ithaca, NY with occupation of Aviator for the 1920 census. See his record in HistoryForge for Tompkins County at tompkins.historyforge.net/people/160352

I suppose this is Miss Detroit I, purchased by Garfield "Gar" Wood in 1916: "In 1916, at the noonday meeting of the Detroit Exchange Club, Lee Barrett secretary of the Miss Detroit Powerboat Association made a plea for some local Detroiter to help out the syndicate and purchase Miss Detroit 1. The man that stood up and said he was ready was Gar Wood. After he agreed to purchase Miss Detroit he left for Algonac to see her. While he was there he bought the yard that built her – the Chris Smith and Sons Boat Company. For the next six years Chris Smith built racing boats under the direction of Gar Wood. With Gar Wood driving and Smith building the boats, they won 5 straight Gold Cups from 1917-1921 and 2 Harmsworth trophies in 1920 and 1921." www.garwood.com/history.htm en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Garfield_Wood There were eventually at least 7 successive Miss Detroit motorboats: www.garwood.com/index.php/gar-woods-at-abm/ see notes under

Psyche V was builit in 1911 as the Achelous. She was a Frederic S. Nock designed/built 75' long Raised Deck twin screw steamer of 43 gross tons displacement. She was powered by a pair of Murray & Tregurtha 4 cylinder 4 stroke gas engines. From September 5-12, 1916 Psyche V and other power yachts of the area (including Ingersoll's Psyche IV) took part in a week of Naval Maneuvers in the New York area. They practiced signalling, sub hunting, mine sweeping. When not signalling, sailing or saluting the owners hung out at the (oft mentioned in this photostream) Atlantic Yacht Club. More pictures of Achelous including interior. Also, lines and layout of Achelous Before being owned by M.S. Bentham Psyche V/Achelous was originally built for Edward Lawson of NY. Lawson sold it to Arthur Zell of Baltimore, who cruised it on the Chesapeake. All articles I've seen refer to MS Bentham, not MB Bentham, but I've yet to find what MS stands for. Bentham was among the biggest vaudeville agents of the day. Bentham sold/donated the boat to the U.S. Navy in 1917 and was himself commissioned a Lieutenant (junior grade) and given command. The boat, with a 1 pound gun mounted on the bow, became SP-9, the USS Psyche V

Barracuda was a 33' long trunk cabin motor launch built in Amityville, NY in 1916 for August Belmont, Jr. From September 5-12, 1916 Barracuda and other power yachts of the areatook part in a week of Naval Maneuvers in the New York area. They practiced signalling, sub hunting, mine sweeping. When not signalling, sailing or saluting the owners hung out at the (oft mentioned in this photostream) Atlantic Yacht Club. Barracuda was offered to the Navy for service in 1917, and was inspected and even assigned Hull no. SP-23, but never actually entered Navy service. Belmont himself volunteered for the Army in 1917 (at age 65!) and served as a Major in the Quartermaster Corps in France. (His wife named a colt born during his absence after him. Man o'War went on to have a pretty good racing career

"Mosquito Fleet" was the term being used in 1916 for the collection of yachts and other small, fast watercraft volunteered by their owners to the U.S. Navy to protect the coast and harbors in the event of war. This group of photos is of training maneuvers held around Long Island the week of September 3, 1916 to assess the capabilities of such a fleet. "More Than Forty Speedy Private Craft Will Hunt Submarines and Go Scouting. The Navy Department's dream of motor boat reserves for service as scouts, submarine hunters, and dispatch carriers will be realized this week, when on Tuesday more that forty of the finest private craft will be mobilized for a week's training with submarines, destroyers, and other vessels of the Atlantic fleet." query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9503E3D91439E2... The LOC Bain collection has many shots of the Maine as she began this training cruise in August:

The Gem, at 146' 6" in length, was by far the largest of the dozens of boats taking part in the preparedness maneuvers near New York in September, 1916. She had been built for William Ziegler, Jr. (1891-1958) in 1913 (His name is sometimes misspelled as Zeigler in sources). He was the nephew and adopted son of a baking powder magnate, and had received a $30 million estate when he reached majority in 1912. In March, 1917, the U.S. Navy acquired Gem as Patrol Yacht SP 41. The Navy returned her to Ziegler in 1919. www.navsource.org/archives/12/170041.htm www.history.navy.mil/photos/sh-usn/usnsh-g/sp41.htm query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B0DE3D81E3CE633A... query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9503E3D91439E2... research.frick.org/directoryweb/browserecord.php?-action=... There is a biographical sketch of Ziegler under this photo of his Manhattan house:

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USS_Florence_%28SP-173%29

I think the good folks at Bain might have been confused by an abundance of Florences. This is not the same Florence that took part in the September 1916 naval exercises. That one was a 45' Elco built (in 1914) boat owned by Matthew Rock. Rock's Florence was the Flagship of group C in the exercises. I don't think this is the SP-173 Florence. It's about the same size - 124' (overall) Herreshoff designed/built yacht launched in 1902 as the Quickstep but the number/alignment of portholes and hawsepipes doesn't quite match (this boat has 7 portholes aft of the stack, SP-173 has 6) I think it more closely resembles a photo of the 154' Florence launched in 1914 for Ludwig Thorwald Petersen (1875-1955) Commodore of the . . . Atlantic Yacht Club. Petersen, who was in the rubber business in Ohio sold that boat in late 1916 to Julian Detmer. Petersen seems to have disappeared from the yachting news after that. This Florence did not see duty during WWI but Detmer did sell her to the Navy in 1942. She was renamed the USS Iolite (PYc-24, then YP-454). She was damaged in an explosion in 1944 and sold off in 1945. Side note: "Florence" made the top ten most popular names for baby girls in the 1890s and 1900s

Sunbeam II was a 43' 'Scout Cruiser' owned by Robert Barnwell Roosevelt II (1866-1929, a cousin of Teddy.) It was designed and built by the Gas Engine & Power Co. & Chas. L. Seabury Co. It was powered by a 6 cylinder 80hp Speedway engine. This class of boats was designed to be adaptable to Navy use in case of hostilities and several were purchased by wealthy preparedness advocates. Details, including layout and interior Sunbeam II was sold to Ralph Slaven soon after this pic and renamed Bobolink and Roosevelt purchased Sunbeam III which was a 53' Scout Cruiser by the same company. RBR II (Bert) was commissioned a Navy Reserve Lt. during the war and commanded the patrol squadron (including Sunbeam III) operating out of West Sayville. Speedway used this training exercise and Sunbeam II's role in it in its advertising

According to this article, 3 Sept 1916, Lt. Wilcox was running the exercise and H.I. Pratt was the owner of the boat, Dodger II. The Navy Department's dream of motor boat reserves for service as scouts, submarine hunters, and dispatch carriers will be realized this week, when on Tuesday more that forty of the finest private craft will be mobilized for a week's training with submarines, destroyers, and other vessels of the Atlantic fleet." query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9503E3D91439E2... Dodger II was a 76' twin screwed trunk cabin yacht of 29 gross tons designed by William Gardner and built in 1913 by Speedway (Gas Engine and Power Company) for Harold Pratt. Dodger II and Gem, being the largest yachts in the flotilla, exercised apart from the smaller boats, searching for mock mines and periscopes off the NJ coast. Dodger II was taken into Naval service in 1917 as a Section Patrol boat (SP-46) patrolling the NY area. Lt. John W. Wilcox, Jr. was a 1905 Academy graduate who had a long and largely successful Navy career, rising to the rank of Rear Admiral, but with a somewhat sad ending: he fell overboard in the North Atlantic in 1942.

H. I. Pratt was the son of American Industrialist Charles Pratt, who was a successful businessman and oil tycoon. Charles Pratt was one of the wealthiest men in the history of Brooklyn, New York. He founded Pratt Institue in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn. "Regardless of his immense wealth, Pratt wanted to give others the opportunity to improve their own lives. He constantly built a number of public projects, such as apartment complexes (including the Astral Apartments) and banks for those who could not afford them. However, Pratt, an advocate of education, wanted to provide the opportunity for working men and women to better their lives through education. Even though Pratt never had the opportunity to go to college himself, he wanted to create an affordable college accessible to the working class. In 1884 Pratt began purchasing parcels of land in his affluent home town of Clinton Hill for the intention of opening a school. The school would end up being built only two blocks from Charles Pratt’s residence on Clinton Avenue." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pratt_Institute www.pratt.edu/

Photo of the Mexico America Commission, convening in Sept. 1916 to address the issues raised by Villa's raid and Pershing's punitive expedition earlier that year. Left to right, standing, are: Stephen H. Bonsal, Attache of the State Department and Advisor to the American Commission, American Secretary of State Robert Lansing, Eliseo Arredondo, Mexican ambassador designate, and L.S. Rowe, Secretary to the American Commission. The six commissioners, three from each country, are in the front row, seated left to right: Dr. John R. Mott of New York, Judge George Gray of Wilmington Delaware, Secretary of the Interior Franklin K. Lane, Luis Cabrera, Chairman of the Mexican delegation and Secretary of Treasury of Mexico, Alberto J Pani, President of the National Railways of Mexico and Ygnacio Bonillas, Minister of Communications and Public Works. This photo was probably taken at a luncheon at the Biltmore Hotel in New York, given the conferees by Secretary Lansing before they were whisked to New London, CT on the presidential yacht to begin deliberations at the Hotel Griswold there. Commercial and Financial Chronicle, 9/9/1916 books.google.com/books?id=p3QdAQAAMAAJ&dq=mexico%20am... A different photo of the same event: chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85054967/1916-09-30/ed-... and adnp.azlibrary.gov/cdm/ref/collection/sn95060914/id/5984 According to the U.S. Dept. of State archive: "Wilson and Carranza agreed to the establishment of a Joint High Commission, which met at New London, Connecticut on September 6. Leading each country's respective delegations were Franklin K. Lane, U.S. Secretary of the Interior, and Luis Cabrera, an important advisor to Carranza. Other representatives from both governments represented the various parties. The Commission issued a statement on December 24, 1916 which stated that U.S. troops could remain in Mexico if their presence was necessary, but otherwise should withdraw. Carranza rejected the agreement, sensing that it allowed for an indefinite U.S. presence. However, the talks sufficed to ease tensions and the U.S. troops prepared for withdrawal and re-crossed the border on February 5, 1917." 2001-2009.state.gov/r/pa/ho/time/wwi/108653.htm

Psyche IV was builit in 1909 as the Triune for Commodore Montrose W. Houck. She was a Luders designed/built 60' long Trunk Cabin screw steamer. She was originally powered by a 50hp Jencick motor, but was repowered in 1914 with a Speedway 4 cylinder 4 stroke gas engine. From September 5-12, 1916 Psyche IV and other power yachts of the area (including Bentham's Psyche V) took part in a week of Naval Maneuvers in the New York area. They practiced signalling, sub hunting, mine sweeping. When not signalling, sailing or saluting the owners hung out at the (oft mentioned in this photostream) Atlantic Yacht Club. More pictures of the Psyche IV as Triune (including lines and interiors) appear here. Robert Hawley Ingersoll (1859-1928) was the inventor of the "dollar watch" Psyche IV is flying the US Yacht Ensign.

(Photographer) Created / Published [ca. 1916] Subject Headings - Baker, Abby Scott, 1871-1944 - National Woman's Party - Suffragists--United States--1910-1920 - Women--Suffrage--Washington (D.C.) - Photographs - United States -- District of Columbia Genre Photographs Notes - Summary: Informal, three-quarter-length portrait of Abby Scott Baker of Washington, D.C., sitting at a desk, facing left, and reading, with papers, books, and a typewriter nearby. - Title supplied by Library of Congress staff. - Abby Scott Baker served in various leadership positions with the Congressional Union and later National Woman's Party, including treasurer, press chairman, political chairman, and member of the National Executive Committee. Eliseo Arredondo (1870-1923) was Mexico's ambassador-designate to the U.S. in 1916. This photo probably came from the beginning of talks by the Mexican American Commission in September, 1916 at New London, Connecticut. Mexico and the U.S. created the Commission after Pershing's advance into Mexico in pursuit of Villa and the subsequent bloody battle at Carrizal, Mexico, with the purpose of trying to settle issues raised by the border war and Pershing's expedition. es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eliseo_Arredondo
Art Siegel:  Thanks for the more complete info on Arredondo here.  We will be sure to check and add the updates to this and the other records for him.

Ignacio Bonillas was another member of the commission: www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/14730107153/ A photo of the commission including Bonillas and Arredondo is in The Patriot., September 30, 1916, p. 1 (chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85054967/1916-09-30/ed-...). The commission held its sessions in the Hotel Griswold, New London, Conn. (s. NYT, September 4, 1916, query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9901EED61E3FE2...). The photos may have been taken there. The Hotel was demolished in 1969, s. "Summer by the Seaside: The Architecture of New England Coastal Resort Hotels ..." by Bryant Franklin Tolles, p. 32 books.google.com/books?id=HZie8msijuMC&pg=PA29&lp...

There's something funny about the SABR dating of several of these Boston Red Sox pictures.  The bulk of them are dated 1916 (The Sox played the Yankees at the Polo Grounds from Sept. 1-4, 1916), the general date these shots appear in the Bain news stream.  They all seem clearly to be taken at the Polo Grounds.
However, this shot is dated 1915 by SABR, and a number of shots of Sam Agnew in the series are dated 1918.  Carrigan managed and Agnew played in 1916 as well as the other years.
The team's road uniforms were the same in all the years named.  Is there a reason to think all these Red Sox shots are not from 1916?

Hachishiro (sometimes Hachichiro) Mikami (1887-1919), Japanese tennis player who made a splash on the U.S. tennis scene in 1916 with Kumagae. He does not have an English Wikipedia page. Here is his page from Japan Wikipedia: ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E4%B8%89%E7%A5%9E%E5%85%AB%E5%9B%9... An obituary in the January 17, 1920 Literary Digest: "MIKAMI TENNIS AMBASSADOR FROM JAPAN TO THE UNITED STATES With the death of Hachichiro Mikami, the Japanese lawn tennis player who developed and brought out Ishiya Kumagae and later toured America with him, lawn tennis in Japan in the Philippine Islands and in the United States loses one of its best liked and most expert champions. "Hashy" as he was familiarly known by the many friends he made on the courts of this country, succumbed to fever in the Philippine Islands. J.P. Allen writes in the New York Evening Post: "Mikami and Kumagae played considerably in the championships of the Orient at Manila in singles and doubles before they ventured to the United States. At Manila they had met and competed against many of the Americans, chiefly from California, such as Maurice E. McLoughlin, Melville H. Long, Carlton R. Gardner, Clarence J. Griffin and others. Edwin Gee the leading figure in the lawn tennis world of Manila believed that the two Japanese would add to their laurels by visiting the United States. He prevailed upon them to make the trip in 1916. [...] The playing of the two, Mikami and Kumagae, furnished one of the features of the season of 1916. Coming to this country direct from Japan, they first competed in tournaments on Pacific coast. Then they journeyed eastward on the way in the sectional doubles at St Louis. It was there that they began to display their real form which became interesting as Kumagae began to bowl over some of the stars in singles in matches later on in the East." books.google.com/books?id=5LI5AQAAMAAJ&pg=RA2-PA120&a... Some Mikami photos elsewhere online from LOC: memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/S?ammem/cdn:@field(SUBJ+@od1(Mikami,+Hachishiro+))

This is apparently a view of some of the damage from the Black Tom munitions explosion of July 30, 1916, eventually held to be an act of German sabotage. A very similar photo is used with the following caption in a blog entry on Black Tom: "This view shows the wreckage of buildings on the pier at Black Tom Island, part of Jersey City, N.J., following the explosion of a munition plant set off by German saboteurs, July 1916. The pier is opposite the Statue of Liberty in the New York Harbor. (AP Photo)" cryptome.org/eyeball/black-tom/black-eyeball.htm See also

The Black Tom explosion on July 30, 1916, in Jersey City, New Jersey, was an act of sabotage by German agents to destroy American-made munitions that were to be supplied to the Allies in World War I. (Source: Wikipedia)
Thanks to both of you for this information.  We'll make sure that some of it gets into each record the next time we update.

The Isaac Peral was a 200' long submarine built at the Fore River Shipyard in Quincy, MA for the Spanish Navy. Launching took place on 22 July 1916. This photo appeared in the December 1916 issue of Pacific Marine Review At the time it was described as the largest submarine afloat, though "afloat" doesn't seem the appropriate term for a submarine.
Seuss and Art Siegel: Thanks for providing us more details about the Isaac Peral.  We'll include some of your information next time we update the description.

Tras la sanción por parte de las Cortes de la llamada "Ley Miranda"( llamada así por la persona que elaboró la ley, el almirante y Ministro de Marina Augusto Miranda y Godoy), de 1915, por la que se aprobaba la compra, entre otros materiales, 28 submarinos, con los que se creaba el Arma Submarina Española, aunque finalmente solo fueron adquiridos 16 de las clases A, B y C, aparte del "Isaac Peral). El A-0 fue adquirido a la empresa norteamericana Electric Boat Company que lo construyó en 1916 en los astilleros Fore River Shipyard de Quincy (Massachusetts). Su construcción era muy similar al submarino norteamericano de la Clase M USS M-1(SS-47), que fue un ejemplar único de ésta clase. El "Isaac Peral" fue entregado a la Armada el 31 de enero de 1917, convirtiéndose oficialmente en el primer submarino que tuvo España en servicio. El mando le fue entregado al capitán de corbeta Fernando de Carranza y Reguera Ese mismo año se añadieron otros tres submarinos adquiridos en Italia a FIAT San Giorgio, de la Clase F, que en España serían la Clase A. En la primavera de 1922, durante la Guerra de Marruecos, participó junto al submarino B-1 y el acorazado "España" en la evacuación, bajo fuego intenso, de los heridos y no combatientes de los peñones de Alhucemas y Vélez de La Gomera. En junio volvió el "Isaac Peral", junto con los submarinos B-1 y A-3 para abastecer el peñón de Vélez de la Gomera. aircraftdrawingsspain.blogspot.com/2020/05/submarino-de-l...

Características Desplazamiento: 492 t. Desplazamiento en inmersión: 653´8 t. Eslora: 57´95 m. Manga: 5´8 m. Puntal: 5´06 m Calado: 4´80 m. Armamento: - 4 tubos lanzatorpedos de 450 mm a proa. - 1 cañón retráctil parcialmente Bethlehem Steel Co. de 76 mm (3"/23) Propulsión: - 2 motores diésel NLSECO de 600 cv. - 2 motores eléctricos de 210 HP - 2 hélices Velocidad: - 15 nudos en superficie. - 10 nudos en inmersión. Profundidad: 50 metros. Autonomía: - 4900 millas a 11 nudos. - 90 millas a 4´5 nudos. Tripulación: 28 hombres. Coste: 3.385.500 pesetas (1916). 1. Fue dotado de un telégrafo submarino Fesseden. aircraftdrawingsspain.blogspot.com/2020/05/submarino-de-l...

The signage on the building to the left, parts of which say "Mersel 191" and "Wisansky 19-" indicates that this was 191 and 195 Duane St. in Manhattan. 1919 and 1920 editions of New York Produce Review and American Creamery Magazine contain ads for Alex Mersel, egg merchant at 191 Duane, and Louis Wisansky, butter merchant, 195 Duane. books.google.com/books?id=ee4-AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA76&dq... As Bain's caption says Washington Street, this is the likely intersection of Washington and Duane, which no longer exists. The site is now within Washington Market Park. The striped brickwork above the awning suggests that it's this building at Washington and Duane, seen in a 1915 photo: digitalcollections.nypl.org/items/510d47dd-37f9-a3d9-e040... If this is a view eastward on Duane from Washington, the elevated railway in the left distance is the IRT Ninth Avenue Line, which ran up Greenwich in this part of town. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IRT_Ninth_Avenue_Line

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Lansing "Robert Lansing (October 17, 1864 – October 30, 1928) was an American lawyer and politician who served as Legal Advisor to the State Department at the outbreak of World War I, and then as United States Secretary of State under President Woodrow Wilson from 1915 to 1920." His wife was the former Eleanor Foster. Their wedding is described in the NYT of Jan 16, 1890 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9D00E3DB143BE533A...

Another facet of the story. He married the daughter of a former secretary of state, albeit one who had served less than a year: "In 1890 he married Eleanor Foster, Secretary of State John Watson Foster’s daughter. Lansing was uncle to both Secretary of State John Foster Dulles and Director of the Central Intelligence Agency Allen Welsh Dulles." history.state.gov/departmenthistory/people/lansing-robert

Romanian conductor and composer (1874-1918) who worked with Isadora Duncan, and lived and worked in New York in the years prior to his death. His death was reported as a suicide at the time his body was found, in September, 1918. "FIND OSCAR SPIRESCU DEAD IN HIS BED; Police Say Music Director of the Strand Killed Himself, But Friends Deny It." query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9805EEDF113BEE... A biographical sketch: "Prominent Conductor's Passing Shocks Many Friends The sudden death of Oscar Spirescu whose name has been closely associated with the musical life of New York during the past two years, first as the conductor of the Manhattan Opera House symphony concerts, then as the chief of the orchestral forces that accompanied Isadora Duncan's performances at the Metropolitan Opera House , and lately as the head of the Strand Symphony Orchestra, will prove a shock to the scores of his friends throughout the country. Born in Bucharest Rumania forty four years ago Mr Spirescu was a graduate of the Paris Conservatoire and a school friend of Charpentier, Enesco and other celebrities of the music world . Returning to Bucharest on his graduation he was appointed the leader of the court orchestra, going later as conductor in chief of the National Theatre of Bucharest. His services to his home city were recognized throughout the breadth and length of Rumania, and the late King Carlos made him a chevalier of the Ordre de Mérite. Mr Spirescu first came to this country as conductor of the Boston Opera Company under the management of Henry Russell. He terminated his engagement after two years connection with the company to resume his position with the Bucharest National Theatre . His second visit found him as the conductor of the Montreal Opera Company. Mr Savage claimed his services next and later he became the conductor of the Cincinnati Orchestra summer concerts. On the eve of the European war he was to go to the Royal Opera of Budapest. The funeral services will be held in Campbell's Funeral Church corner Broadway and Sixty sixth street Thursday (today) at 11 am. The body will be sent to Europe for final burial. Mr Spirescu is survived by a widow who is in this country and by four children by a former marriage who are in Rumania ." The Music Magazine, September 12, 1918 books.google.com/books?id=HO86AQAAMAAJ&lpg=RA7-PA6&am...

This and the next 5 pictures, and another of the "Aero-Maid" statue model, are from the arrival of 3 planes at the New York Flying Yacht Club station at 129th (one source says 125th) Street and the Hudson River on August 31, 1916, on the way to the club's luncheon. The first plane, from Atlantic City, was piloted by Beryl H. Kendrick with his mechanic J.D. Davis. The second, from Amityville, Long Island was piloted by Lawrence Sperry and Ripley Bowman. The third, from Port Washington, was piloted by David McCullough with passenger Robert Edgren. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9F05E6DF143BE6... More on McCullough: www.earlyaviators.com/emccullo.htm To his right, famous early aviator Frank T. Coffyn, here seen another Bain photo: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_Coffyn "R. Edgren" is probably noted olympic athlete, cartoonist and journalist Robert W. "Bob" Edgren (1874-1939). john-adcock.blogspot.com/2012/04/fight-of-century.html www.californiagoldenblogs.com/2012/5/30/3001650/robert-ed... The unidentified man second from right is certainly Lawrence Burst Sperry (1892-1923), early aviator and inventor, mentioned in the Times story as having flown in with Bowman. See photo and bio at: www.marinelink.com/news/engineer-lawrence-aviator369263.aspx en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lawrence_Sperry
handsome men!!!
Another photo of the same group printed in the 9/15/1916 issue of Aviation lists Sperry as second from right. books.google.com/books?id=4zUyAQAAMAAJ&q=ripley+bowma...

And the caption of a related photo confirms Edgren as the sports writer: A cropped version of the photo was used in The Sunday Oregonian. (Portland, Ore.) September 17, 1916, SECTION FIVE, Page 2, with the caption: " The New York Flying Yacht Club dedicated the grounds on the Hudson River at One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street recently, where it is proposed to establish a landing station for aeroplanes and air-yachts. Six of the guests at the function arrived by aeroplane two from Atlantic City, two from Amltyville, L. I., and two from Port Washington. David H. McCulloch, with Robert Edgren, the sporting writer, as guest, came from Port Washington in 10 minutes, a journey that would have taken an hour by train and streetcar. B. J. Kendrick came up from Atlantic City with J. D. Davis as guest. Lawrence Sperry, the inventor, and Ripley Bowman came in from Amityvtlle. Later young Sperry took Admiral Peary for a flight. A trophy called the "Hydro Aeromaid" was displayed at the luncheon. It was offered by the club for a flight around New York." oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83045782/1916-09-17/ed-1/se...

This photo was displayed in The Sunday Oregonian. (Portland, Ore.) 1881-current, September 17, 1916. The caption is: "Whisky flowed in a river through the streets of Girard, Ala., when the authorities broke up $10,000 worth of it which was being sold unlawfully and turned it into the gutter." oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83045782/1916-09-17/ed-1/se...

From "When Good Men Do Nothing: The Assassination of Albert Patterson" by Alan Grady at www.nextreads.com/display2.aspx?recid=4046194&FC=1 "Unlike the more industrialized Columbus, Girard-and indeed all of Russell County-relied on farming and liquor as its principal sources of income. At the turn of the century, Girard was home to two major whiskey warehouses, shipping their stock throughout the Southeast and as far away as New York and Boston. But the whiskey interests met increasing political opposition from prohibitionists, who by 1909 were in the forefront of a move to dry up Alabama. In 1914 they gained control of the legislature, and soon afterward they passed a law prohibiting the sale of alcohol. For Girard and Russell County businessmen, this meant ignoring the law or losing everything they had. They chose the former. Aware of the tremendous unpopularity of the law, local officials reached an unspoken agreement with the whiskey interests. Russell County grand juries routinely indicted violators, who would then pay bond. When the accused failed to show for trial, the county would pocket the forfeited surety. It seemed like a reasonable arrangement, but technically it qualified as political corruption. Whatever it was called, it was the beginning of a long history of selective law enforcement in Girard and Russell County. Unfortunately for the Russell County distributors, local option was not an option. By the summer of 1916, prohibitionist groups were demanding state intervention in east Alabama, and the first great Russell County cleanup was under way. At the direction of the Alabama Supreme Court, Circuit Judge A. H. Alston of Clayton and the state attorney general, Logan Martin, went to Seale, the county seat since 1868, and took over the local judiciary. On August 8, Alston impaneled a new grand jury and instructed it to destroy "for once and all time" lawlessness in Russell County and to investigate collusion between bootleggers and local officials. The resulting court proceedings were swift, merciless, and judicially questionable. Those indicted were brought to trial as soon as the grand jury voted a true bill, usually less than three hours. After the first two indictees received a hefty $2,500 fine, many of the others fled, hoping for a better day to appear before the bar. Alston declared them fugitives and confiscated their holdings. State militia entered Girard on August 10 and began hauling out bottles, kegs, and casks from the warehouses and anywhere else they could be found; these they assembled at the intersection of Seale Road and Broad Street. All day long, militiamen, special deputy sheriffs, and hired laborers destroyed some eight hundred casks of beer and an equal number of barrels of whiskey. Some workers fainted from the fumes, which could be smelled in eastern Columbus, two miles away. Eventually, more than a quarter of a million dollars' worth of illegal alcohol was destroyed during the cleanup, and several prominent citizens were ruined in the process. And as a result of the grand jury's investigation into political corruption, almost every city and county official resigned his office." The 1916 cleanup might have been longer lived had it not been for the establishment two years later of Fort Benning, the U.S. Army infantry-training school just outside Columbus. Even as the recruits were moving into the tents and thrown-together buildings, bootleg liquor was again flowing freely in Girard. Arriving doughboys quickly learned that a good time could be found on the Alabama side and crossed the Chattahoochee in droves. By the time the Roaring Twenties arrived, Martin's cleanup had completely unraveled and Girard was once again living down to its reputation.
Girard is now Phenix City, AL.

This photo was used in The Sunday Oregonian. The caption on the photo is Adele S. Kelley (not Adelle). An Adele S. Kelley was a debutante of 1922, see e.g. the New-York tribune., September 22, 1922, Page 11, col. 4, "Society Notes". chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1922-09-22/ed-... A photo of likely the same woman is in the Oakland Tribune, January 18, 1928 newspaperarchive.com/us/california/oakland/oakland-tribun.... The date on the negative is 4/2/27.

The March 3, 1927 New York Times announced the engagement of Adele Sarpy Kelley, daughter of Mrs. Albert Tevis Kelley, to George Lascelles Maxwell, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Thebaud Maxwell. An April wedding was anticipated, but that apparently never took place, as Miss Adele S. Kelley is frequently mentioned in the society pages in succeeding years. In April, 1933, she married Walter Roosevelt Thompson (Yale '15), president of Dauntless Shipyards of Essex, CT. That wedding was also reported, along with a bridal photo, on May 3, 1933. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9407E2D81438E333A... She then frequently appears as Mrs. Walter R. Thompson, Mrs. W. Roosevelt Thompson and Adele K. Thompson in the Times society pages in connections with charitable activities, through the early 1960's. She was still alive at the time of her husband's death in 1964. www.nytimes.com/1964/05/29/w-r-thompson-72-built-ships-in... As Adele Kelley Thompson, she was a published poet. books.google.com/books?id=QtUvAAAAMAAJ&q=adele+kelley... She is pictured in an antebellum gown at a charity ball in Life Magazine in 1940. books.google.com/books?id=xj8EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA86&dq...

Wadsworths! From my old neck of the woods! (Livingston County, NY) This is Alice Hay Wadsworth. Alice was the daughter of John Hay (Abraham Lincoln's private secretary, later Secretary of State under McKinley & T. Roosevelt). Her husband was Sen.James W. Wadsworth Jr. of the Geneseo, NY Wadsworths. The boy is James J. Wadsworth (1905-1984.) He grew up to be Ambassador to the U.N. The girl is Evelyn Wadsworth (1903-1972.) She grew up to marry Senator (and 1st Secretary of the Air Force) Stuart Symington. Her son James Wadsworth Symington represented Missouri in the House of Representatives for 4 terms. The baby is Reverdy Wadsworth (born 10 November 1914-1970.) He was the Wadsworth who worked the acres in Geneseo. He married Eleanor Roosevelt (no, not THAT Eleanor Roosevelt, but related to her). James W, (Alice's husband) as a Senator was kind of what we would today call a tea partier. He believed that the ONLY purpose of the constitution was to limit the power of government and protect the rights of citizens. He opposed both Prohibition and Women's Suffrage. Alice shared his views and was the president of National Association Opposed to Woman Suffrage.
Seuss: thanks for the very informative background of the Wadsworth family.  We will add the information to the record the next time we update.

This is an interesting photograph for several reasons. First, the California Battalion was actually a Massachusetts unit. Most Union volunteers in California stayed in California, relieving Federal units to return to the main fighting in the east. But some volunteers (true believers in the cause or those with a thirst for action) went out of their way to join a unit that would be directly involved in the action in the east. They put their enlistment bonus money towards steamer fare (via Panama) to Boston and there they became units of the 2nd Massachusetts Volunteer Cavalry. I can't make out the company letter below the crossed sabres on his Forage cap. Might be a "B"? More images of soldiers from the California Battalion are here, including a couple that look like they were taken in the same studio. Second, I don't think this is an ambrotype. The image does not appear to be reversed as one might expect in an ambrotype. The lettering on the cap is legible. While it might have been a prop cap with reversed lettering, I doubt it. Other photos from the same setting have similar, but not identical caps, and they too are legible. Also the buttons on the soldier's tunic are properly aligned with the piping (piping to the left of the buttons). Compare that to the buttons on all the other ambrotypes in this batch. Rather I think this is a Carte de visite (CDV). That might also explain why the original is less sharp than some of the other ambrotypes.

Thanks for the information and the question. I checked with the cataloger who worked with the item, and she said "Not sure why the lettering isn’t backwards on this but it is definitely an ambrotype. The part about the California Battalion being associated with the 2nd Massachusetts Cavalry Regiment is interesting and I made a note in the record about it." The description on the Library of Congress site already shows her adjustment: www.loc.gov/pictures/item/2014646247/

From www.nps.gov/history/history/online_books/gett/gettysburg_... "No history of the Fifth Corps, no matter how brief, would be complete without Frederick T. Locke. At the age of 34, Locke had enrolled on April 19, 1861 in the 12th New York Militia for three months. He was mustered in as Adjutant, May 2, 1861, and detached as brigade major and assistant adjutant-general of the 8th Brigade at Martinsburg, Virginia (now West Virginia), on July 14. He was mustered out with his regiment on August 5. Locke was reappointed as an assistant adjutant-general with the rank of captain and assigned to duty as the assistant adjutant-general, Fifth Corps, with the temporary rank of lieutenant colonel on August 20, 1862. Colonel Locke held this position with the Fifth Corps until he was relieved on August 1, 1865, and mustered out as a captain on September 19, 1865. He was awarded the brevet of colonel of volunteers (August 1, 1864) for brave, constant, and efficient service in the battles and marches of the campaign and brevetted a brigadier general of volunteers (to date from April 1, 1865) Frederick Locke for gallant and meritorious service at the battle of Five Forks, Virginia."

From Tom Daly's Column, Philadelphia Evening Ledger, January 3, 1917. Only marginally relevant, but colorful: They have just as much local pride in the Latin-American countries as they have in any more northern republic. and the residents of the Colombian captital of Bogota are especially noted for the brand of patriotism which will not admit that anything anywhere else can by any possibility be as good as its counterpart In the home town. During an International celebration In honor of Bolivar the Liberator a sturdy Bogotan was away visiting the Venezuelan capital of Caracas. On his return a neighbor dropped in to chat with him about his adventures and observations In foreign parts. "I suppose that they had mighty fine parades and fireworks in Caracas," suggested the stay-at-home. "No better than we have here." answered the returned traveler. "But the public buildings In Caracas," said the neighbor, "they are very splendid, are they not?" "Why, not nearly so splendid as they'd have you think," maintained the traveler, and ours are in much better taste." "How about their new statue of Bolivar?" asked the neighbor. "Ours is every bit as artistlc," asserted the traveled one. "But surely," objected the stay-at-home, "Our statue only shows Bolivar standing, while the Caracas statue Is equestrian." "Tut, tut!" said the patriotic traveler; "it's not nearly as equestrian as they say it is."
Recent photo at en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sim%C3%B3n_Bol%C3%ADvar#mediaviewer...
If Wikipedia is to be believed, the statue dates from 1850, so not nearly as new as the jingoistic Colombian thought. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adamo_Tadolino

According to en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bol%C3%ADvar_Square_%28Caracas%29, this statue was inaugurated on November 7, 1874 and was a replica of the statue in Lima, which was erected in 1859, see es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plaza_Bol%C3%ADvar_de_Lima it.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adamo_Tadolini LOC has a photo of the statue in Lima: www.loc.gov/pictures/item/npc2007019331/

I'll have to correct Wikipedia on that when I get a chance. It turns out a copy of this statue is in San Francisco, CA, a gift of the government of Venezuela. Another odd thing is that the sculptor is listed as Tadolina, Tadolini, and Tadolino in various sources. The Smithsonian has him as Adamo Tadolina. collections.si.edu/search/results.htm?q=record_ID:siris_a...

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/artolog] Don't know about San Francisco, but don't forget Quebec City. [https://www.flickr.com/photos/capitalenationale/2192816993] And Paris, London, Prague, Buenos Aires & Tokyo? And almost New York?

Geez, it's like those Venezuelans have a Bolivar statue factory down there, cloning these things to give away.  [More amendments to Wikipedia required].   And theirs is a copy to begin with.  I think the San Francisco copy sat around for a while before they put it up (in a pretty bad location) because nobody was all that enthused about it.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pagsanjan,_Laguna "Pagsanjan (pronounced 'Pag-sang-han') is a second class municipality in the province of Laguna, Philippines. According to the 2010 census, it has a population of 39,313 people. It is situated about 92 kilometres (57 mi) southeast of Manila."

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Copra "Copra is the dried meat, or kernel, of the coconut used to extract coconut oil. . . . Making copra – removing the shell, breaking it up, drying – is usually done where the coconut palms grow. Copra can be made by smoke drying, sun drying, or kiln drying. Sun drying requires little more than racks and sufficient sunlight. Halved nuts are drained of water, and left with the meat facing the sky; they can be washed to remove mold-creating contaminants. After two days the meat can be removed from the shell with ease, and the drying process is complete after three to five more days (up to seven in total). "
swanq:How interesting! Thanks for shedding some light on the process happening here and the end product. We will add a bit more info to this record.

Destroyed during the war, 1945. Rehabilitated, 1947. Venue of the U.N. Economic Commission of Asia and the Far East (ECAFE), 1947. The U.N Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), 1948; and the First Meeting of the Southeast Asian Union (SEAU) known as the Baguio Conference of 1950. Summer residence of American Governors-General, 1908-1935 and later of Philippine Presidents from Manuel L. Quezon to the present. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nina_E._Allender "Nina E. Allender (1873-1957) was an American artist, cartoonist, and women's rights activist." www.sewallbelmont.org/womenwecelebrate/nina-allender/ Nina Evans was born in Auburn, Kansas in 1872. In 1893, she married Charles Allender, who she divorced in 1905 after he deserted her, and she never remarried. She died in 1957 at the age of 85. "In 1914, [Alice] Paul persuaded Allender to draw cartoons for The Suffragist. While Allender’s hesitated, saying “she painted, and preferred to paint,” Paul convinced her to try the new format. Her political cartoons appeared regularly in The Suffragist (and its successor Equal Rights) until 1927. In 1915, in addition to her position as art editor for The Suffragist, Allender was also named Chairman of the D.C. Branch of the Congressional Union. By 1916, she was labeled the “Official Cartoonist” for the organization."
This photo was displayed in The Washington times., August 22, 1916, HOME EDITION, Page 8 with article "Only Woman Cartoonist in America Draws for Suffrage"
swanq and B-59: Thanks for the additional information Nina Allender. We will expand her catalog record to reflect more about her.

Elsewhere in the Library of Congress online collections is this same photo, in sepia tone, attributed to Harris & Ewing, with the following information: Title Mrs. Wm Kent, wife of Representative Kent, of California, who is actively working with the Woman's Party against President Wilson. Mr. Kent is national chairman of the Wilson Non-Partisan League. Contributor Names Harris & Ewing, Washington, D.C. (Photographer) Created / Published [ca. 1916-1917 Feb. 7] Subject Headings - National Woman's Party - Suffragists--United States--1910-1920 - Women--Suffrage--California - Kent, Elizabeth T - Photographs - United States -- California Genre Photographs Notes - Summary: Informal portrait, full-length, Elizabeth T. Kent, facing forward, standing outdoors, wearing hat with ribbons, fur stole, and dress cinched ay waist with sash and large bow. - Title and information transcribed from item. - Verso: "Please return to Caroline Katzenstein, 35 So. 9th St." - Transcribed from related photograph: "Mrs. William Kent, a member of the Executive Committee of the National Woman's Party, chairman of the headquarters maintainence [maintenance] committee and one of the largest contributors to the party. She is the wife of the former Congressman Kent who recently resigned his post as a member of the Tariff Commission to run for United States senator from California. The Kents are well known in Chicago as well as in Kentfield, Calif., their home, and in the national capital. Mrs. Kent has lobbied for suffrage in Washington, took part in the Woman's Party campaign preceding the presidential election in 1916 and has been active in the campaign for ratification of the suffrage amendment. - Cropped version of the photograph published in The Suffragist, 5, no. 56 (Feb. 7, 1917): 7; The Suffragist, 5, no. 58 (Mar. 3, 1917): 10; The Suffragist, 7, no. 25 (June 28, 1919): 9; and The Suffragist, 8, no. 5 (June 1920): n.p. Medium 1 photograph: print; 7 x 5 in. Call Number Location: National Woman's Party Records, Group II, Container II:275, Folder: Individual Photographs Nos. 209-218 "K" Source Collection Records of the National Woman's Party Repository Manuscript Division Digital Id hdl.loc.gov/loc.mss/mnwp.275002 www.loc.gov/item/mnwp000028/

The pilot on the left is apparently Terah "T.T." Maroney (1880-1929). This picture appears with the caption: "Leaflet Drop Flight with Suffragette Lucy Burns, Seattle, May, 1916. As fever built for the U. S. to enter World War I, Maroney became a pilot in the Washington Navy Militia. "Lucy Burns, as the guest of Flight Lieutenant Maroney of the Naval Militia at Washington, flew to a height of fourteen hundred feet over Seattle, scattering leaflets as she went. When she started, Miss Burns carried a Congressional Union [for Woman Sufferage] banner, but the eighty-mile-an-hour gale soon tore it from her hand. When last seen, it reposed peacefully on the roof of a large Seattle mill." -- The Story of the Women's Party, by Inez Haynes Gillmore. www.helenahistory.org/Terah-Maroney.htm "Lucy Burns (July 28, 1879 – December 22, 1966) was an American suffragist and women's rights advocate. She was a passionate activist in the United States and in the United Kingdom. Burns was a close friend of Alice Paul, and together they ultimately formed the National Woman's Party." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lucy_Burns See also We are being a little cheated here by black and white photography: "Someone asked Lucy Burns, National vice-chairman of the Congressional Union, how everyone recognized her so readily. "It's her glorious red hair." put in Mrs. Percy Read, of Virginia. Yes. Miss Burns has wonderful hair, like burnished bronze. Also she is quick in wit, and has the delightful sense of humor that goes with her radiant locks. But to get that Federal amendment through that is Miss Burns' chief thought. " Morning Oregonian. (Portland, Or.) , May 01, 1916 oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83025138/1916-05-01/ed-1/se...
Art Siegel: Thanks for providing the very interesting backstory to this intriguing image. We will expand the description to reflect some of these details.

Crockett (see photo below right), but according to all other sources (also FACTS AND FICTION OF SPORTS OF ALL SORTS, SPORTING LIFE, September 2, 1916), her name is Cockett (Miss Cockett, Cotuit, Mass. in this publication).

I think she is Dr. Margaret (sometimes Marguerite) S. Cockett (1878-1954). This item from the Cooperstown, N.Y. Otsego Farmer & Republican of Sept. 9, 1921 reports that Dr. Margaret S. Davison, wife of a partner in the Morgan bank, is "doing her bit" for preparedness. Her son mentioned in the newspaper was Frederick Trubee Davison (February 7, 1896 - November 14, 1974), American World War I aviator, Assistant US Secretary of War, Director of Personnel for the Central Intelligence Agency, and President of the American Museum of Natural History (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F._Trubee_Davison). I suspect these three photos of sailing women are from the Atlantic Yacht Club's Race Week.  They traditionally held Ladies' Races in the Star, Bird & Knockabout classes on the first day of competition (Monday - Aug. 21st in 1916) and these boats competed.  The rules called for each boat to be skippered by a woman, but the crewman could be male. 

If "Atlantic Yacht Club" sounds familiar it is the same club that elected J. Stuart Blackton (of the Vitagraph Company) as its Commodore.  I wonder just how many reporters and photographers he had on speed dial?

This boat is identified in NYT of Aug 22, 1916 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9807E3D81E3FE233A... as a Star (not a surprise, given the boat's name). See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star_%28sailboat%29 Like the Vega in a neighboring photo this Star has the pre-1922 rig (a gunter rig).
Seuss and swanq: Thanks for the info, both about this image and the likely connection between the other photos from this event.  We will add more to all of the records.

Another photo with the caption "Miss Katherine Taylor sailing Vega in the race of the star class, Atlantic Yacht Club week." is shown in The sun., September 10, 1916, SECTION 4 PICTORIAL MAGAZINE, Image 33 (chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030431/1916-09-10/ed-...).
This is the pre-1922 rig for the Star (aka Starboat) design. See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star_%28sailboat%29

I can't say anything about Miss De (or Di) Plesso, but I'll say that Saginaw was owned by John K. Birch of Brooklyn, NY and homeported in Bath Beach, Long Island (that's Bensonhurst.) It was a Centerboard Sloop of 37'6" overall length, 27' length on the waterline and drew 4'6". It was designed by S. N. Small, and builit by George W. Shiverick of Kingston, MA. When it was first launched in 1896 it was called Heroine

swanq & Seuss., Thanks for the information. Considering that same NYT article spells her name De Plesso, and then further down, Die Plesso, I think we'll stick with the current spelling until more definitive information turns up.

The former Julia May Moran of Uniontown, PA (1892-1962) sailed from NY in 1916 on her way to marry Count Kasimir Zichy in Székesfehérvár, Hungary. It couldn't have been an easy trip across an ocean and continent in the middle of a world war, and things did not get easier. Following the war and the collapse of the Austro-Hungarian Empire by 1919 she was living with her 2 children in a 1 room 3rd floor apartment in Budapest. Looking at the dates in a genealogy it appears she and her (then adult) children fled Hungary following WWII and ended up in Canada.
Her husband to be:

Continuing the recent yachting theme . . . on August 20, 1916 the 35' Sloop Drifter was rammed and sunk by the French ocean liner Lafayette at night in lower New York Harbor. Aboard was Drifter's owner Augustus S. Meeker, his wife Mary Agnes Meeker, his nephew Malcolm Knox, his friend Henry Haas (note spelling) and Haas' son Harold. Meeker was a lawyer. He sued.

That opinion by the 2d Circuit Court of Appeals was interesting. It must have been pretty horrifying to have an ocean liner splitting your boat in two at night. All 5 aboard the Drifter sued, but by 1920 when the appeal was decided, Mary Agnes Meeker and Henry Haas had died. Malcolm is identified as G. Malcolm Knox in the opinion. The Sun's account of the collision has a few more details. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030431/1916-08-22/ed-... The Brooklyn Daily Eagle's coverage is the most colorful and is accompanied by an Underwood & Underwood picture of the group in the same location. fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%205/Brooklyn%20NY%20Daily%20E... A different Underwood shot was used in The Evening Telegram's story fultonhistory.com/Newspapers%206/New%20York%20NY%20Evenin...

And just to keep things symmetrical . . . Bain neighbor W.G. Sharpe & daughter were aboard the liner when it ran down the sailboat.[https://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/14333009640/]
I'm guessing both pics were taken on the pier.
Seuss and Art Siegel: Wow, what a story! Thanks for putting the pieces together so we can add more details to these records.

It seems likely that the movie is "Britton of the Seventh" as suggested by Seuss in comment with However, the director of that movie was Lionel Belmore, who looked nothing like the slim guy with the light jacket who appears in several of these Vitagraph photos with megaphone and pad of paper (presumably the shooting script). I don't think this is "Britton of the Seventh".  I think we're looking at two different battle scenes for two different movies that were filmed around the same time at the same spot.

Scenes with these big industrial looking guns and soldiers in modern (for 1915, anyway) uniform and sandbagged trenches were likely for Battle Cry for Peace.  The Britton of the Seventh scenes feature an easily identifiable Custer and soldiers in civil war era uniforms with antique long rifles (not exaclty historically accurate, but . . . )

My guess is that Lionel Belmore directed most of Britton in studio in Brooklyn.  I'd guess that most of Battle Cry was filmed in Brooklyn as well by . . . whoever. But since the studio was going on location to film big sweeping battle scenes for Battle Cry ( a big 9-reel feature) they probably tucked in a half day of filming a flashback scene of Custer's Last Stand to drop into Britton (a 4-reel melodrama.)
Same area with horseman and guy with megaphone, different angle: and see

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/90124154@N00] The idea that there are two separate films being shot is an interesting one. Seems plausible to me. civilwar.gratzpa.org/2012/04/the-battle-cry-of-peace/ has lots of newspaper clips about Battle Cry of Peace, including a collage of pictures of cast and crew at civilwar.gratzpa.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/03/FergusonW... I was hoping to identify the guy in the light jacket, but it doesn't look like Wilfrid (or Wilfred) North, the director.

Another hypothesis to explore: Tulsa daily world. (Tulsa, Indian Territory [Okla.]), 16 July 1916. Image 20, Col 5 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85042344/1916-07-16/ed-... indicates that a church in Brooklyn was used for filming an interior scene for "Battle Cry of War" to be a sequel to "Battle Cry of Peace." Joseph Kilgour was among the actors. The director was William P. S. Earle. And William P. S. Earle is a candidate for the guy in the light jacket. Got it!! The sun., September 24, 1916, SECTION 4 PICTORIAL MAGAZINE, Image 39 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030431/1916-09-24/ed-... has a picture of this gun and another with Joseph Kilgour, as a Ruritanian commander.

Then there is still the question of whether the Custer shots are for the same movie. At www.canadaworldwarone.com/2012/05/reasons-why-you-should-... there is a newspaper transcription that includes among a list of reasons to see the movie (which was released in 1917 under the title "Womanhood, The Glory of a Nation") "A Civil War battlefield strewn with hero dead is transformed into terrain peopled with restored armies."

I think swanq has it.  There is reason to doubt that this Vitagraph series is from the filming of either "Battle Cry of Peace" or "Britton of the Seventh".  From the accounts of the plot of BCOP,  I didn't find any that described trench warfare and heavy artillery.  Instead there was a lot about attacks from the air and sea on New York City.  BCOP was also released in 1915, and BOT7th in January, 1916, making their filming a year before the current August/September 1916 spot in the Bain news stream.
"Battle Cry  of War" appears to have been a working title for "Womanhood, Glory of a Nation," released in 1917.  It was also one of the later titles of a re-edited "Battle Cry of Peace."  The idea that the Custer scene is part of a flashback in Womanhood is worth pursuing.

I'm sticking with Battle Cry of Peace for these artillery/trench scenes. The Variety review specifically refers to the "enemy fleet" being out of range of US coast defense guns. These sure look like coast defense type guns. 30 seconds or so of footage from BCoP was included in Episode 4 (Hollywood goest to war) of the old Hollywood documentary series from 1980. You can see it at www.youtube.com/watch?v=yLtXuGded04. The BCoP part starts around the 3:15 mark. Reading the summaries of BCoP and BCoW make them sound like an early, silent, black & white version of Red Dawn. Wolverines! One point that the Hollywood episode makes is the contrast between the pro-preparedness BCoP and the pro-Peace Intolerance put out by DW Griffith around the same time. I have to wonder if the title of the 1917 Womanhood: Glory of a Nation was a deliberate play on Griffith's 1915 Birth of a Nation. Blackton & Griffith seem to be east coast/west coast jingoist/pacifist rivals.

what tips the scale for me is the Sun article from September, 1916 which has the same gun next to the same gnarly tree as in three of the Bain photos. Plus a shot of trench warfare. This gun is probably the secret weapon that saves the day at the end of the film.
I should have clicked on the Sun link. Yep. Battle Cry of War aka Womanhood: Glory of a Nation. This article narrows down the dates to August 18-21, 1916. Some of the pics might look familiar.

The officer to the left side of the frame is Lt. Barnard Cummings. His career is briefly described in an August 1984 National Register of Historic Places Nomination Form (5DV1486) for Pierce-Haley House (aka "Haley-Cummlngs House") located at 857 Grant St., Denver, Colorado. (The house would ultimately be placed on the National Register 3 October 1984). Given the information cited below, it is certain that his first name was spelled "Barnard". focus.nps.gov/pdfhost/docs/NRHP/Text/84000583.pdf Barnard Cummings came to Colorado sometime in the first decade of the twentieth century. He had several careers - one of them, as a homesteader in northwestern Colorado. Cummings worked as a telegrapher for Western Union which led to his being chosen from Colorado by the fledgling air industry to be trained as a pilot. His license to fly was the 525th issued in the United States. When Work War I began he was sent to Mineola Field on Long Island as a first lieutenant in the Signal Corps. After the war, Cummings trained as an attorney and practiced law for a time in Craig. While in Craig he ran unsuccessfully for several state-wide political offices. Barnard Cummings lived at 857 Grant until his death in 1952. The family continued to occupy the house until January of 1984. It has now been converted to offices. Also, here is the site of Cummings' grave at Crown Hill Cemetary in Denver, CO: www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=46354757 Note, the grave is shared with his son, Lt. Barnard Cummings, Jr. (USMA 1949), who is still-Missing In Action (and presumed Killed In Action) from the Korean War. www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=46354783
Thanks for the correction on Barnard's first name. We'll adjust the description in our database, as we currently have it as "Bernard" ( www.loc.gov/pictures/item/ggb2005022525/ ).

Britton of the Seventh. With Ned Finley as General George Custer. Released May 1916, 4 reels. Now lost. According to AFI . . . according to a news item, this film was shot along the U.S.-Mexican border, and Indians from Oklahoma reservations and United States troops appeared in the film.

See also Is Britton of the Seventh (not pictured here) really lost? A modern reviewer seems to have seen it: "What's more fascinating than the plot is the multitude of mistakes made by director Lionel Belmore and Vitagraph's production staff in recreating 1876. For example, Rain-in-the-Face (Logan Paul) uses a repeating rifle to shoot down a couple of scouts (those guns didn't exist back then), and Britton is shown wearing a modern (circa 1916) suit and collar. Such errors were especially fatal in an era where people were still alive who remembered the times of Custer first hand. It makes you wonder why the studio -- trying for accuracy -- bothered to shoot the film in Texas with the help of the Seventh U.S. Cavalry. ~ Janiss Garza, Rovi" www.nytimes.com/movies/movie/86022/Britton-of-the-Seventh...

Their names are also stenciled on the fronts of their uniforms. See comments under J.S. Morgan is also pictured here:

A full account of the training cruise in the October 4, 1916 Princeton Alumni Weekly by a participant, Henry Buxton, mentions other Princeton Alumni aboard the Maine, including F.B. Read, Princeton '10. books.google.com/books?id=chJbAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA8&dq=... This led me to a mention of Read in an account of a Princeton football game, naming his prep school, then to an obituary for Frederick Bliss Read in the journal of his prep school, St. Paul's Academy (Concord, NH): "Obituary: Frederic Bliss Read 1906-Frederic Bliss Read died in Providence, Rhode Island, September 6, 1978, in his ninetieth year. The third of five St. Paul's brothers, he was born in Pawtucket, Rhode Island, December 14, 1888, the son of Charles O. and Mary Bliss Read, and entered the School in the Fourth Form in 1903. He was a natural athlete. "Strenuous in games and very strong," M. K. Gordon wrote of him some years after he won the Gordon Medal in 1906, "he did not overstep the mark of sportsmanship." He excelled in hockey and football and was an exceptional oarsman. He played on the Delphian football team every one of his years at School and was a strong backfield runner on the SPS team of 1905. In 1906, he captained both Delphian and SPS hockey. Filling the position formerly called "center point" on the School team, he was considered the best player of that position the School had seen. He rowed on winning Halcyon Crews for two years, becoming Halcyon and SPS captain in 1906. At Anniversary that same spring, he won the 120-yard hurdles and placed second in both the 220-yard hurdles and the hammer throw. He was a member of the Cadmean and the Scientific Association, sang bass in the Choir, and was co-author of a short play printed in the Horae in the spring of 1906. After graduation he attended Princeton, where his remarkable athletic career continued. During his early years in business, he played amateur hockey, and he kept his hand in at tennis and golf for most of his life. His working career included thirty-five years in the Providence office of Paine, Webber, Jackson and Curtis, as an investment broker and manager. During World War I, he was first assigned to duty as an ensign on a submarine chaser in the Atlantic, and then, for the final months of the war, as an instructor in the Naval Academy at Annapolis. Few alumni have maintained closer or more loyal attachment to the School. He broke the tape in the Alumni Dash at his tenth and fifteenth reunions and was regularly on hand for Anniversary until the year before his death. He is survived by a son, Frederic B. Read, Jr., '36; six grandchildren, and seven great-grandchildren. He was the brother of the late Albert M. Read, '00, Charles N. Read, '04, Malcolm E. Read, '09, and Robert O. Read, '19." archives.sps.edu/common/text.asp?Img=11658&Keyword=&a...

Mary Carnegie (Mary Crowninshield Endicott Chamberlain Carnegie), 1864-1957. "Mary C. Endicott (Chamberlain, Carnegie) was born on 16 April 1864 in Salem, the daughter of William C. Endicott, Sr. and Ellen P. Endicott. She married British Member of Parliament Joseph Chamberlain, father of future British Cabinet Ministers Arthur Neville and Joseph Austen Chamberlain on 26 November 1888, and moved to England. As Chamberlain's wife, she accompanied him on numerous state visits and served as stepmother to his children. She was widowed in 1914 and in 1916 married William H. Carnegie, the Dean of Westminster. Widowed again in 1936, she remained in England until her death in July of 1957." (www.masshist.org/collection-guides/view/fa0021) Her second husband, William Hartley Carnegie: www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/14012219647/ See also - www.westminster-abbey.org/our-history/people/william-and-... - www.jstor.org/discover/10.5224/masshistrevi.13.1.0096?uid... Her father was William Crowninshield Endicott (November 19, 1826 – May 6, 1900), American politician and Secretary of War in the Administration of President Grover Cleveland. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Crowninshield_Endicott

This photo ran in The Sunday Oregonian. (Portland, Ore.), September 10, 1916, with the caption "Mrs. W.H. Carnegie, ex-wife of the late Joseph Chamberlain, has recently married again, being now the wife of Conan [sic] Carnegie, chaplain of the House of Commons. Note that Hy Myers batted right handed.  This is not his batting stance, it's his follow through.  You can tell that he used a closed front foot (pigeon toed) batting stance and then rotated off the rear foot.  It allows a lot of body rotation in the swing, but look at his feet!  If I tried that it's a toss up of whether I'd dislocate a hip or break an ankle first.

I find several mentions of Arthur Classen (without "s") as conductor and music director in the NYT. June 27, 1894 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F04E0DF1531E033A... March 19, 1910 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B0DE3DA1139E333A... Nov 3, 1912 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9906E4D81F3CE633A... He is described as "of Brooklyn."

There is a lengthy biographical sketch of Arthur Claassen with photo in the Bulletin of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences for November 26, 1910. books.google.com/books?id=QlI3AQAAMAAJ&lpg=PA292&... He worked in San Antonio, Texas from 1914 to 1919, which explains why the Texas State Historical Society has a bio of him on their site: "CLAASSEN, ARTHUR (1859–1920). Arthur Claassen, choral and orchestral conductor, was born in Stargard, Prussia, on February 19, 1859. He studied at the Music School in Weimar, and as early as 1878 his youthful compositions aroused the attention of Franz Liszt, who gave him encouragement. From 1880 to 1884, Claassen was opera conductor in Göttingen and Magdeburg. Upon the recommendation of Leopold Damrosch, a disciple of Wagner, Claassen was chosen conductor of the New York Eichenkranz and, in 1890, of the Brooklyn Arion—both male singing societies. [etc.] www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fcl35 A 1911 NYT article names him as "Arthur Claasens", director of the Arion Society, conducting a cantata as part of a Metropolitan Opera program. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9D00E5D61331E2... He is identified with the Arion Society of Brooklyn in newspaper articles calling him Classen and Claassen. His grave in San Antonio, Texas: www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GSln=claass...;

Presumably selling tickets for the National Guardsmen Field Day at Sheepshead Bay Speedway on July 29, 1916. See:
I'm guessing the woman 3rd from right is not a chorus girl, however....
New-York tribune. (New York [N.Y.]), 21 July 1916, page 7, bottom left chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1916-07-21/ed-... has a call for 5,000 New York women to sell tickets for the event.

"One of the exciting bits of theatrical happenings last week was the debut (?) of about 100 chorus girls who aided in a worthy charity by selling tickets for the Field day at the Sheepshead Bay Speedway. The real leader was Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt who is at the head of a vast committee which is looking after the families of the Guardsmen at the border. The proceeds are to be devoted to this relief work. The aim is to raise $50,000, but only the most optimistic expect to secure so large an amount. Girls from the Winter Garden, led by the beautiful Peggy Lorimer, were the leaders in luring coin from unsuspecting Individuals, while those from "Step This Way" and "Very Good Eddy" were close behind them Of course there were many society folks selling tickets also, but who would buy from them when so many stage beauties were begging for the same cause? " The Sunday Oregonian, August 13, 1916 oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83045782/1916-08-13/ed-1/se... According to the NYT account "Actresses Day", when 200 actresses from the 3 shows named above sold tickets in the financial district, was Wednesday, July 26, 1916. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9A02E6DC1E3FE2...
