Selache Maxima refers to a group of aquatic beings but not basking sharks in particular, though the signage at that time may have been used in such a fashion.

According to species-identification.org/search.php?search_for=Selache+... and www.marinespecies.org/aphia.php?p=taxdetails&id=148867, Selache maxima is a synonym for Cetorhinus maximus, which is the scientific name for basking shark en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basking_shark The Richmond times-dispatch., July 30, 1916, Image 50 has a similar photo of a shark with the caption "A Shark Caught at San Pedro, California. It Weighed Twenty Tons, and Two Children Could Sit in Its Mouth." chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045389/1916-07-30/ed-....

This photo was possibly taken from the Brooklyn Bridge, see similar photo in The Evening herald., August 24, 1916, Image 1, chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn99063812/1916-08-24/ed-.... A cruise of three battleships with civilians on board started in August 1916, see NYT, August 5, 1916, query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9F03E3DB1E3FE2... The sun., August 15, 1916, Page 7, chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn99063812/1916-08-24/ed-.... The battleship Maine: www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2162984429/

The second of four (so far) USS Maines, this one in service from 1901-1920. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USS_Maine_(BB-10) This might have been taken from one of the masts on the ship. Apparently, the Maine with her civilian trainees was not underway until at least August 16th, according to this New York Sun article of 8-15-16: "PREPARATIONS have been completed at the Navy Yard for the cruise along the Atlantic coast of about 1,000 civilian. The battleships Maine, Kentucky and New Jersey are in readiness for the citizen sailors. Owing to the inability of many who have signified their Intention of joining the cruise to reach the city until late to-day, the departure may not he made until to-morrow morning. The photograph shows the citizen sailors aboard the Maine filling their dunnage bags. The three ships' will be under the command of Rear Admiral Helm, commander of the Atlantic reserve fleet Officers designated by the Secretary of the Navy will instruct the voyagers in drilling, handling of guns, fire control system and other essentials. The battleships will steam to Gardiner's Bay, where they will anchor for a week. The cruise Is expected to last about a month." chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030431/1916-08-15/ed-...

See also (taken about the same time) I don't think these photos were taken from the Brooklyn Bridge as the Maine sailed away for its training cruise. It seems like this is when the press was aboard prior to sailing. Would they have allowed all that unpacked equipment on deck as they left the Navy Yard?

Mathewson played 635 games with the Giants and one with the Reds. This must be from the last week of his career.

Though he only pitched in one game for the Reds, he managed them for 3 years, starting July 20, 1916. The Reds came into New York to play on July 26, 27 and 28, 1916 and this photo probably dates from then. This is when Giants fans first saw Mathewson in another team's uniform. Buck Herzog had come over to the Giants from the Reds as part of the trade that sent Mathewson to Cincinnati. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christy_Mathewson#Three_years_with_... www.baseball-reference.com/players/h/herzobu01.shtml The New York Times' account began this way: "More than 12,000 fans deserted the Giants up at the Polo Grounds yesterday and switched their affections over to Christy Mathewson and the Cincinnati Reds. They rooted hard for Matty to beat his old boss, McGraw, and Mathewson's debut here while not decorated with festival ceremonies was a great success." query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=990DE7D7173BE6... query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=990DE7D7173BE6...
Christy Mathewson, as player-manager for the Cincinnati Reds in 1916. See comments under
Christy Mathewson, as player-manager for the Cincinnati Reds in 1916. Taken at the Polo Grounds. See comments under

All old guys were young once.  He was a pretty good outfielder.  His fame came, of course, as manager of the Yankees for 12 years where he "had the horses."  People often forget or do not realize that in his 13 years as manager of the Dodgers, Boston Bees, Boston Braves, and the Mets, he didn't have the horses.  With the players he had on those Yankee teams between 1949-1960, it would have been hard not to win 10 pennants.
A good pitcher, but does not belong in the Hall of Fame.  Had some quality years, however.

George Van Horn Mosely, Sr. , not to be confused with his son George Van Horn Mosely, Jr. 70 Years ago today Mosely fils led the 502nd Parachute Regiment jumping into Normandy on D-Day. Mosely pere is less fondly remembered. Though he retired from the army as a Major General in 1938, he is mostly remembered for his extreme antisemitic and neofascist views.

From the National Portrait Gallery (UK) where they have 22 portraits of her: "Roshanara (Olive Craddock) (1894-1926), Dancer The daughter of an English mother and Anglo-Indian father of Irish extraction, Craddock learned to dance as a child in India. She came to Europe in about 1909 and adopted the stage name Roshanara after a legendary Indian princess. She danced with Loie Fuller's company and in 1911 appeared in London in Oscar Asche's Kismet and took the role of Zobeide in Scheherazade with the Ballets Russes at Covent Garden. She joined Anna Pavlova's company in 1912 and eventually settled in America, where she died from appendicitis aged thirty-four." www.npg.org.uk/collections/search/person/mp55949/roshanar...

The newspapers wrote that her father was an English army officer in India. E.g. „... Roshanara, who is the daughter of an English army officer and all Anglo-saxon, despite her Indian name and her dusky beauty ...“ (The Sunday Oregonian. (Portland, Ore.) 1881-current, August 20, 1916, SECTION FOUR, Image 45, col. 3, oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83045782/1916-08-20/ed-1/se...). See also satiric article about her in The Washington herald., May 09, 1916, Page 11, last column, "NEW YORK DAY BY DAY", chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045433/1916-05-09/ed-....

Here's a lavishly illustrated article by her from October, 1915 telling American women to "Dress on the Floor, Work on the Floor, Eat and Sleep on the Floor and Lose Your Fat and Gain a Figure, Advises Roshanara, the Celebrated Dancer" chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045389/1915-10-10/ed-...

This is the old Million Dollar Bridge over the Fore River. It opened in 1916. Its replacement, the Casco Bay Bridge, opened in 1997 and the Million Dollar Bridge was demolished that same year.

This photo was depicted in The Sunday Oregonian. (Portland, Ore.) 1881-current, September 10, 1916, SECTION FIVE, Image 60 with the caption: " A million-dollar bridge has just been completed connecting Portland, Me., with South Portland. It was begun In December, 1914. It is 4000 feet long and supported by nine harbor piers, one of which cost $26,000. Its girders are the longest in the world. There are 1,500,000 pounds of steel in it and 105 miles of one-inch rods. The 60,000 barrels ot cement used in it If piled on end would be 20 miles high." oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83045782/1916-09-10/ed-1/se...

Aftermath of the Black Tom munitions explosion of July 30, 1916. That's Ellis Island in the background: "Now a section of Liberty State Park (along Morris Pesin road including the park office and Flag Plaza), Black Tom was originally a small island in New York Harbor not far from Liberty Island. Between 1860 and 1880, Black Tom was connected to the mainland by a causeway and rail lines terminating at a freight facility with docks. The area between the island and the mainland was filled in sometime between 1905 and 1916 by the Lehigh Valley Railroad as part of its Jersey City facility. By the beginning of the twentieth century, Black Tom was serving as a major munitions depot. Before the United States entered the First World War, American businessmen would sell their supplies to any buyer. However, by 1915, the British Navy had established a blockade effectively keeping the Germans from being able to buy from the American merchants. The German government, on July 30, 1916, orchestrated the sabotage of freight cars at Black Tom, which were loaded with munitions for the Allies in Europe. The wreckage after the Black Tom Explosion. According to a recent study, the resulting explosion was the equivalent of an earthquake measuring between 5.0 and 5.5 on the Richter Scale. Windows within a 25-mile radius were broken, the outside wall of Jersey City’s City Hall was cracked and pieces of metal damaged the skirt of the Statue of Liberty (it is because of this explosion that the Lady's torch has been closed off to visitors). Most of the immigrants on Ellis Island were temporarily evacuated. Losses were estimate at $20 million and seven people were killed." www.state.nj.us/dep/parksandforests/parks/liberty_state_p...

To get an idea of the force of the explosion, that's the Ellis Island castle in the background. Since the powerhouse smokestack is to the right of the castle, and the east and west castle towers are nearly in line, that indicates that this picture is taken EAST of Ellis Island. Black Tom Island was a good mile the other side of Ellis Island Would you believe . . . Google Street view? goo.gl/maps/WZBT6
Amazing.. I  suppose that means that shells and debris fell all over Ellis Island as well.

This is Ichiya "Ichy" Kumagae (熊谷 一弥 Kumagai Ichiya?, 10 September 1890 – 16 August 1968), a Japanese tennis player and the first Japanese Olympic medalist. " In 1916, he travelled to the United States with Zenzo Shimizu to compete in the US Open, marking the first participation of a Japanese in one of the Grand Slam tournaments. Kumagae spent a total of three months in the United States, during which he competed in 60 tournaments. He did not lose a single match on a clay court, and lost only four matches on grass courts, rising to the U.S. rank of No. 5." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ichiya_Kumagae This is probably taken at the U.S. Open in Forest Hills, N.Y. , which began August 28, 1916.

The United States Board of Mediation and Conciliation, meeting with respect to an impending strike of 400,000 railroad workers in August, 1916. From a report to Congress by the Board in 1916: "The next step in legislation relative to mediation and arbitration was the so-called Newlands law, approved July 13, 1913. It created the offices of Commissioner of Mediation and Conciliation and Assistant Commissioner of Mediation and Conciliation, and further provided that the President shall also 'designate not more than two other officials of the Government who have been appointed by and with the advice and consent of the Senate, who, together with the Commissioner of Mediation and Conciliation, shall constitute a board to be known as the United States Board of Mediation and Conciliation." In August, 1916, the board was increased to three members by the designation by the President of the Assistant Commissioner of Mediation and Conciliation as a member. " archive.org/stream/railroadlaborarb00unit#page/11/mode/1up William L. Chambers, en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Lea_Chambers, was Commissioner, G.W.W. Hangar, en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Wallace_William_Hanger, was named Assistant Commissioner on August 3rd by President Wilson. Judge Martin A. Knapp, en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Augustine_Knapp, was Chairman. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=FB0616FA355B17... The same group, apparently photographed in 1912 or 1913:

The Hotel Woodstock was a luxury hotel on 43rd St., just off Times Square. In August, 1916 it served as the headquarters for the railroad union leaders, like Garretson, who came to Manhattan to participate in talks aimed at averting a national rail strike. The hotel is still in operation, though now mainly as housing for the indigent. www.projectfind.org/woodstock ephemeralnewyork.wordpress.com/tag/woodstock-hotel-43rd-s... An account of the atmosphere at the labor negotiations: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=F40C15FC3E5D1A... The same spot, today: www.google.com/maps/@40.756173,-73.985184,3a,75y,51.29h,8...

Both the Shanghai-Nanking Railway and the Shanghai-Hangchow-Ningpo Railway were British concessions and I would expect them to use British locomotives (the railways did indeed order locomotives from Northern British in later years) but this is very definitely a French locomotive. Specifically, an État 3700 class 4 cylinder de Glehn compound 230. I wonder if this is really Shanghai? I looked at a few photos of the various Shanghai Train Stations from this period of virtualshanghai and they are all significantly larger than the building in the background. Wusong 1905, South Station 1908, North Station, 1908 The pilot (cow catcher) is similar to those fitted to locos in Indochina, which would make more sense for a French locomotive. This is a "ten wheeler", a 4-6-0 in American terms or a 230 under French classification, built in the first decade of the 20th century. schematic

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nanjing_University "In 1915 after the Republic of China replaced Qing Dynasty, the Nanking Higher Normal School (南京高等師範學校) was founded to replace Liangjiang Higher Normal School which was closed three years before due to Xinhai Revolution, Jiang Qian (江謙) was appointed as the president. The school established the China's first faculty of modern gymnastics (physical education) in 1916. The "China Science Society" (中國科學社), a major science organization in the modern history of China, founded its headquarters in the school in 1918."

yangziman.blog.com/2012/10/26/nanjings-historic-universit... indicates that there has been controversy associated with the Wikipedia page on Nanking University and that Nanking University was "one of the thirteen foreign-funded Christian universities which then [in 1949] existed in China." NYT of Feb 7, 1912 discusses fund-raising by a Dr. Williams for the University of Nanking at a meeting of the Pan-Presbyterian Alliance select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F6061FFB3C581373... NYT of April 6, 1912 indicates that Rev J. E. Williams is vice-president of Nanking University.
see also en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Nanking and en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nanjing_University

This fantastic house can be found peeking through some treas on Google streetview.  Curiously, the house is now red brick while this photo suggests the brick has been white washed....or it something about the exposure that makes the brick look white?

Someone probably whitewashed it.  This was often done as some people felt white brick provided a more formal look.  Now we have a preservation return to the original brick in many of these old mansions.  It's usually not hard to blast off the white wash.

This was a tricky one! What at first glance appears to be a church actually turns out to be a Masonic lodge. Viewing this image at high resolution reveals the symbol of Freemasonry, the Square and Compasses, visible directly above the doors. This turns out to be LaFayette Masonic Lodge No. 23 in Washington, Wilkes County, Georgia. This entry on Wikimapia offers a current view of the lodge and a marker in front identifying the building.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Annette_Kellerman "Annette Marie Sarah Kellerman (6 July 1886 – 6 November 1975) was an Australian professional swimmer, vaudeville star, film actress and writer. She was one of the first women to wear a one-piece bathing costume, instead of the then-accepted pantaloons, and inspired others to follow her example." A similar picture in her Wikipedia entry is captioned "Kellerman in nude scene from 'A Daughter of the Gods.' That movie came out in 1916. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A_Daughter_of_the_Gods

Annette Marie Sarah Kellerman (1886-1975) was an Australian competitive swimmer and entertainer. She was one of the earliest proponents/designers of the one-piece bathing suit for women, though, as seen here, she did not always wear one herself. This is a publicity still from the 1916 film A Daughter of the Gods, lost, but not forgotten for being the first onscreen nude scene by a major star. Dr. Dudley Sargent of Harvard declared her the "Perfect Woman" among thousands he examined as she most closely matched the measurements of the Venus de Milo. I think she has slightly longer arms, but I'm not a Harvard man. If you're wondering: 5' 4 1/2", 137lbs, 33-26-38 [https://www.flickr.com/photos/39782038@N02/4556330362]
Many of her colorful costumes are at the Powerhouse Museum (a Flickr Commons colleague), www.powerhousemuseum.com/collection/database/collection=A... -- Helena (LOC)

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Judson_Harmon "Judson Harmon (February 3, 1846 – February 22, 1927) was a Democratic politician from Ohio. He served as United States Attorney General under President Grover Cleveland and later served as the 45th Governor of Ohio."

The date on the sticker is 8/4/16. At that time, he was in the newspapers because he was a candidate for the nomination of the Democratic party for the Presidency of the United States four years ago, see e.g. The day book., August 09, 1916, LAST EDITION, Image 21, col. 1, chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045487/1916-08-09/ed-.... But this photo was used in 1911 already, see. e.g. the Aberdeen herald., June 26, 1911, Page THREE, chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn87093220/1911-06-26/ed-....

The photo was also used in The Sunday Oregonian. (Portland, Ore.) 1881-current, August 20, 1916, SECTION FIVE, Image 57 (oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83045782/1916-08-20/ed-1/se...) with the caption " It is reported in political circles that Judson Harmon, once Attorney-General of the United States, will be the next Senator from Ohio if the Democrats carry that state in November." Surprisingly it was not noted there that he was Governor of Ohio from 1909 to 1913.

George Reynolds McCubbin (1898 - 1944), 2nd Lieutenant of the Royal Flying Corps, he vanquished Lieutenant Immelmann and received the Distinguished Service Order, see the NYT, July 28, 1916, query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=F40815FD355B17.... S. also www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/29684/supplement/7428/d... at the end of col. 2. "George was eventually promoted to Major; he later became a well-known and highly respected businessman in Johannesburg." (from mccubbinfamily.info/dna-family-groups/dna-group-3/02-the-...)
Max Immelmann: www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/11871570215/ According to his German wikipedia entry, he was killed by friendly anti-aircraft fire. de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Max_Immelmann

"Captain George Reynolds McCubbin, born at Cape Town, and educated at King Edward VII School in Johannesburg, joined the RFC in 1916, and was commissioned in May of that year. He thereafter served with No. 25 Squadron, and only a month later was credited with shooting down the legendary German air-ace Max Immelman, on the 18 June 1916, being awarded the DSO for his exploit. It is rather ironic that Max Immelman’s death was attributed to a South - African as Immelman had spent part of his youth in Uitenhage, in the Eastern Cape part of South Africa. McCubbin was promoted captain in 1918, and returned to SA at the end of hostilities. " (from archive.today/sNaUr)

Another photo of him is in www.bridgemanart.com/en-GB/asset/407154/english-photograp..., the description suggests that he died in 1923, but according to www.espncricinfo.com/magazine/content/story/228199.html he died on May 9, 1944, aged 46. "'Fighting Parson' to be Pastor of Mr. Rockefeller's Church; The Rev. Charles F. Aked, Who Comes to the Fifth Avenue Baptist Church, Is a Radical English Non-Conformist -- Has Denounced the British Government. NEXT month the Rev. Charles F. Aked will leave Pembroke Chapel, Liverpool, England, to come to New York. A few weeks later he will be installed as the pastor of the Fifth Avenue Baptist Church, on Forty-sixth Street, near Fifth Avenue. "

From digitallibrary.imcpl.org/cdm/compoundobject/collection/mw... Aked, Charles F. (Charles Frederic), 1864-1941 "Aked was the Minister of the First Congregational Church of San Francisco from 1911 through 1915 when he left to be a part of the Henry Ford "Peace Ship", a good-will mission to Europe. " Salem (Oregon) Daily Capital Journal., July 26, 1916, STREET EDITION, Image 4 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn99063957/1916-07-26/ed-... reported that Aked had resigned from the Ford peace delegation. "Rev. Charles F. Aked, of San Francisco, who was with the Ford peace delegation and who, according to the dispatches at the time, stirred up trouble among the party and disagreed with everybody, has resigned, giving as a reason that he could not agree with Ford. In other words he is of such a disposition he quarrels with his meal ticket. He improved peace chances among the party greatly by resigning."

See also www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=85336003 He was born in Nottingham, England, came to the United States in 1907 and became a citizen of the U.S. in 1913 (according to the San Francisco Call, Volume 114, Number 15, 15 June 1913, cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SFC19130615.2.158).

The ship on the left is (I believe) the Hamburg America Line's SS Viktoria Luise. Built as the SS Deutschland for the North Atlantic run in 1900, she held -for a time- the Blue Riband for the fastest Atlantic Crossing. She was renamed/rebuilt in 1911 and converted to one of the earliest and finest Cruise Ships, where speed was not so important. I can't believe Google Street View doesn't cover Charlotte Amalie! Oh, well. Fortunately the 99 Steps, built from ballast stones in the 18th century when St. Thomas was Danish, remains a popular subject for Flickr photographers. (note: there actually 103 steps) [https://www.flickr.com/photos/bobindrums/2189715959]

(handwritten on the negative: "The famous 103 steps") There must be a story behind why they changed the name from 103 steps to 99... On August 4, 1916, the U.S. signed a treaty with Denmark to buy the Danish West Indies, now the U.S. Virgin Islands, for $25 million, motivated by concern that the Germans might sieze them as a submarine base. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Treaty_of_the_Danish_West_Indies This photo ran in The Sunday Oregonian. (Portland, Ore.), August 20, 1916, with the caption "103 Steps, St. Thomas One of the sights of Charlotte Amalie in the Danish West Indies is the flight of 103 steps" oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83045782/1916-08-20/ed-1/se...

What do you make of the publication date on this photo? The sticker seems to say "7/31/16," which fits well with the Oregonian newspaper publication. The year scratched on the negative is harder to decipher. But mostly, other negatives in this series seem to say 3/17/31 -- that's late for a Bain publication date. Did something happen in 1931 to cause re-publication, or; might the year be mismarked--should have been "3/31/17" for the purchase of the Danish Virgin Islands by the U.S.? It's risky to read too much into numbers, but Wikipedia gives the end-date for Danish Administration as 3/31/1917. Yes, the Islands went from U.S. Navy administration to civil administration on March 18, 1931, with the inauguration of a local government and governor. Republicans gathered in New York to officially notify C.E. Hughes on July 31, 1916 of his selection as their presidential candidate. Chairman of the committee was Ohio Senator Warren G. Harding, later to be president himself. I think that's him seated at center right with the white hair and black eyebrows. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F00B16FF355B1773... query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=FA0711FD355B17... The Times article mentions "two negroes, Henry Johnson of South Carolina and Dr. J.R. Levy of Georgia, who occupied prominent seats behind the nominees" The Times scrambled the facts a bit. I assume Levy and Johnson are the two African-Americans in the back row, at far right and sixth from right. Dr. James R. Levy (1861-1936) was a prominent physician, civic leader and civil rights activist from Florence, South Carolina. He was a delegate to 5 Republican conventions. The National Medical Association eulogized him here: pubmedcentralcanada.ca/picrender.cgi?accid=PMC2623648&... Based on a 1912 picture, I think Levy is 6th from right: digitalgallery.nypl.org/nypldigital/dgkeysearchdetail.cfm... Henry Lincoln Johnson was a delegate at large from Georgia. He was Washington, D.C. resident, now more famous as the husband of African-American poet and playwright Georgia Douglas Johnson, en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Georgia_Douglas_Johnson . He was an attorney and had moved to D.C. from Georgia in 1910 when President Taft appointed him as Recorder of Deeds for Washington, D.C. His entry at politicalgraveyard.com: politicalgraveyard.com/bio/johnson4.html A segment on Johnson from a history of Black Lawyers: books.google.com/books?id=1lOIjQUG4aoC&pg=PA195&l... I think that is Johnson at far right. LOC has 3 Harris & Ewing photos of him from 1914: www.loc.gov/pictures/search/?q=henry%20lincoln%20johnson%... The full list of committee members, of which this group is probably a subset, is here (note that Johnson is not listed as a member): books.google.com/books?id=Bi4GFJJT6AYC&pg=PA215&d...

This is a group of men at Port Washington , Long Island in July, 1916 who came to train at the aviation school there to become a unit of the Aerial Coast Patrol. The story from the New York Evening World., July 15, 1916: 90 H.P. FLYING BOAT SOLD TO F. T. DAVISON Young Aviator Gets First Unit of New Aerial Coast Patrol. The first step toward establishing an aerial coast patrol for this country was taken to-day when F.T. Davison ordered a ninety horsepower Curtlss flying boat, according to an announcement Issued by the Aero Club of America. Robert Lovett, Allen Ames, H. B. Sturtevant, G.D. Winan and Mr. Davison reported at the Wanamaker Aviation School, Port Washington, L.I. to begin training as aviators. The unit is to contain twelve men, four to act as pilots, four as observers and four as anti-aircraft gunmen. Two experts In wireless telegraphy also will be added. The full equipment of the body Is to include four seaplanes and a complement of motorboats and automobiles for anti aircraft work. President Wilson and the War and Navy Departments have given their consent to a plan for a coast patrol worked out by the Aero Club and a bill appropriating $1,500,000 for its maintenance was Introduced in the Senate a few days ago." chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030193/1916-07-15/ed-... Other sources reported that Davison was the son of H.P. Davison of J.P. Morgan & Co., and Robert Lovett as the son of Robert S. Lovett of the Union Pacific RR. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=F20B14FF355B17... The Brooklyn Daily Eagle of July 16, 1916 reported that David McCollough (note spelling, elsewhere it is David H. and D.H. McCulloch) was the aviator in charge of the school. fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%205/Brooklyn%20NY%20Daily%20E... This seminal early event in the history of American aviation is covered in Chapter 6 of "Millionaires' Unit: The Aristocratic Flyboys Who Fought the Great War and Invented American Air Power." by Marc Wortman. That book identifies these men more accurately: Robert Abercrombie Lovett (September 14, 1895 – May 7, 1986) was the fourth United States Secretary of Defense, en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_A._Lovett John Martin Vorys, later a Congressman from Ohio en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Martin_Vorys Rear Admiral Erl Clinton Barker Gould (1895-1968) www.millionairesunit.org/index.php?option=com_content&... Albert D. "Al" Sturtevant (1894-1918) en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albert_D._Sturtevant Frederick Trubee Davison (February 7, 1896 - November 14, 1974) was an American World War I aviator, Assistant US Secretary of War, Director of Personnel for the Central Intelligence Agency, and President of the American Museum of Natural History. Thanks, artolog, for providing all the information and resources. I haven't been able to get to the bottom of whether David H. was "McCulloch" or "McCullough." I  have also seen some "McCullough" on other sites, though Bain seems to have stuck with "McCulloch"--as in this close-up [https://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/8704882304/]
In any case, we'll add information when we next update the description.
McCullough again:

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/barbara_loc] Barbara, as Art has found, "McCullough" is frequently used as the spelling for the aviator in question. However, after spending (too much?) time connecting the dots, I am certain that "McCulloch" is the proper and correct spelling. David Hugh McCulloch, Sr. was born to parents William Turbett McCulloch and Lucretia J. McManigal in Pennsylvania on April 23, 1890, and he passed away on September 20, 1955. He was married to Helen Wheeler Fair, and the children I have been able to identify thus far are: Virginia Fair McCulloch (who would marry in 1946 (and divorce in 1956) Bertrand L. Taylor III, then marry (and later divorce) renown diver Peter Robin Gimbel (of Gimbel's Department Stores) in 1960; Alice Fair McCulloch (married to Frederick Hemsley Gillmore in August 1933); Helen Fair McCulloch, and David Hugh McCulloch, Jr. Although the preponderance of evidence points toward "McCulloch" as the proper spelling, that evidence comes primarily from (not necessarily accurate) newspaper society notices of impending marriages, noting "father David H. McCulloch" as the noted Naval aviator, with homes in both Port Washington, Long Island and Palm Beach, Florida. What settles the issue is the short life of David Jr. David Hugh McCulloch, Jr.'s birth is announced on Page 13 of the June 30, 1922 issue of The Evening News of Harrisburg, Pennsylvania (note, "Mrs. J. Emery Fleisher" is McCulloch, Sr.'s mother, Lucretia, who married Fleisher some time after her first husband William passed away at the age of 41 in 1894): Mrs. J. Emery Fleisher has received the announcement of the birth of a grandson, David Hugh McCulloch, Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. David Hugh McCulloch, of New York City, June 24. Mr. McCulloch, the father, is the famous aviator who was on the Ill-fated N-3 which floundered several years ago near the Asores on its trans-Atlantic flight If you go to Find-A-Grave, two headstones stand next to each other at Woodlawn Cemetery in Palm Beach, Florida. One is for David Hugh McCulloch, Jr. "June 24, 1922 - December 7, 1922" See: www.findagrave.net/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=96138161 The adjacent headstone is for David Hugh McCulloch, Sr. "April 23, 1890 - September 20, 1955" See: www.findagrave.net/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=96138063 It is curious and somewhat disheartening that there is no notation of his service (and achievements in aviation), nor of his family, other than the immediate proximity of the grave of his son who died at too young an age. Similarly, it is surprising that there isn't any information (obituaries, notices, etc.) reporting or noting his own passing in 1955 that can be located thus far (perhaps as more publications are digitized, this is will change?). However, with the knowledge that McCulloch was born in Pennsylvania (see also the story about the historic flight of the Curtiss NC Flying boats to the Azores on page 36 in the May 4, 1919 Brooklyn Eagle - "Lt. David H. McCulloch, considered one of the best pilots in the Naval Aviation Corps, has been in the Naval Reserve Flying Corps since 1917 when he was 27 years old, having been born in Pennsylvania in 1890."), combined with the notice of his son's birth, and the aforementioned grave site information, we can say for a certainty that the proper spelling of the name is "McCulloch", and for the first time as far as I am aware, we can say with a reasonable certainty that he was born on April 23, 1890 and passed on September 20, 1955.

Thanks, TVL1970, for all the research and deduction! I see that in the updated catalog record on our site ( www.loc.gov/pictures/item/ggb2005022296/ ) we favored "McCulloch" (with an alternative "McCullough" there for retrieval purposes, but with a question mark). Alas, we entered the wrong middle initial in the process. We'll adjust further, indicating that "McCulloch" is most likely the accurate spelling.

Current Steinway hall in Google Streetview Steinway Hall (109-111 W. 57th St) was built in 1925 and hosts the US headquarters of The Economist

I was presuming these were mid-1920's pictures, but the July 4, 1916 New York Times reported "The feature of yesterday's realty market, which opened unusually strong for a holiday week, was the purchase by Steinway Sons, piano manufacturers, of 109, 111, and 118 West Fifty-seventh Street and 114 West Fifty-eighth Street as a site for a ten-story building. Old Steinway Hall on West Fourteenth Street now occupied by the firm will be offered for sale on the completion of the new structure." select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F40713FC3B591673... 118 W. 57th could be a typo, as that was on the other side of the street. They may have meant 109-113, the three rightmost 4 story buildings to the left of the tall building (Which was the Freundschaft Club at 105 W. 57th, built in 1914). Now the question is why did it take 9 years to build the new Steinway Hall? 1916 street atlas: lt.images.nypl.org/lizardtech/iserv/calcrgn?cat=NYPL&...

According to www.neighborhoodpreservationcenter.org/db/bb_files/2001-S..., page 3f, Steinway found a site uptown to the music center developing on West57th Street near Carnegie Hall in July 1916. Steinway announced its intention to construct a new building with the purchase for nearly one million dollars. But at the same time, the City passed a Zoning Resolution, which in this instance prohibited businesses along that block of 58th Street because it was residential. Steinway rescinded its purchase agreements, and the sellers filed suits. Steinway lost and was obligated to proceed in taking title to the properties. Plans for a new building were further delayed due to the company's finances after a piano workers strike in 1919. A total of eight lots were officially conveyed to Steinway between August 1920 and January 1924. Construction began in June 1924 and was completed in April 1925.
Thanks for finding that.. Protracted litigation, that makes sense.

HUTCHINGS, HENRY (1865–1939). www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fhu49 Henry Hutchings, soldier, publisher, and politician, was born in Somersetshire, England, on August 17, 1865. He was brought to America by his parents in 1866. He became a private in the Iowa National Guard in 1882 and, after moving to Texas, joined the Texas National Guard in 1885. In 1890 he founded and published the Austin Evening News and, for a time, published the Austin Statesman (see AUSTIN AMERICAN-STATESMAN). He was adjutant general of Texas from 1911 to 1917, when he resigned to organize the Seventy-first Infantry Brigade; he commanded this brigade in the United States Army overseas during World War I. He was secretary of state under Governor Pat M. Neff in 1925. From January 18, 1933, to January 15, 1935, he served again as adjutant general. Hutchings married Wittie Brown in 1886. They had seven children. On March 9, 1935, he married Mrs. Hallie White of Dallas. He was a vestryman at St. David's Episcopalian Church in Austin for twenty years. He died at his home in Austin on July 27, 1939, survived by his widow and six children. At the time of his death he was executive officer in charge of the narcotics division of the Texas Department of Public Safety.

Possibly Mary Emily Foy (July 13, 1862 - February 21, 1962) en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mary_Foy San Francisco Call, Volume 112, Number 87, 26 August 1912 cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SFC19120826.2.62 (with what might be the same photo) reports that she was to address "Women Wilsonites." From a finding aid for her papers at www.oac.cdlib.org/findaid/ark:/13030/kt6x0nf47s/entire_text/ "Mary Emily Foy (1862-1962) was the daughter of Samuel Calvert Foy and Lucinda (Pet) Macy Foy, early Los Angeles pioneers. From 1880 to 1894, she served as the third Los Angeles City Librarian, the first woman to hold the position. She is particularly well known for her involvement in the California Woman's Suffrage Movement and her involvement with the Democratic Party. She was Vice President of the Political Equality League, Secretary of the Votes for Women Club, President of the California Woman's Democratic League, and a delegate to the Democratic National Convention in 1916 and 1920. In 1934, she ran unsuccessfully for Congress in the 15th Congressional District. Mary Foy's interests in history and archaeology lead her to organize the California Parlor of the Native Daughters of the American West, and to her involvement with the local chapter of the American Institute for Archaeology, and the Southwest Society. Foy was also founder of First Century Families, descendants of Los Angeles settlers during its first 100 years, and wrote for the Jeffersonian, Woman's Bulletin, and the Los Angeles Herald and Express. "

I hope she held on to the flags . . . 10 years later Sunshine Jarmon appeared on Broadway in Americana (www.newspapers.com/image/#57556765). By 1931, however, she had "married a wealthy Britisher".

Here's a drawing of her in "Americana" (1926). Most references to her seem to be as Sunshine Jarmann, with some as Sunshine Jarman and Jarrman as well. fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%2018/New%20York%20NY%20Sun/Ne... ibdb.com/person.php?id=46869 ibdb.com/person.php?id=478058

It's gratifying to see how well the references you each found add up. The Broadway sources mention Sunshine's 1915 appearance in the chorus of Hands Up--perhaps accounting for her flare, while other children look more serious (or dubious?), ibdb.com/production.php?id=7046. The word "peace" on Sunshine's banner fits well with the NYT coverage of the '1916 July 4th celebration as a flag-focused, city-wide, sane and safe (no fireworks) extravaganza. More from that article, which continues the Broadway theater connection: “... One of the children’s celebrations was in Times Square, where some 500 little ones listened to a patriotic address from Borough President Marcus M. Marks of Manhattan. After the exercises, the children were taken to the Globe Theatre, where a special performance was given for their benefit. Refreshments for the children were supplied by a number of firms in the vicinity and in response to a request from the committee having the arrangements in charge all the buildings in and adjoining Times Square were flag decked. The celebration was held under the auspices of the Broadway Association.”
See also www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=6406

It left Moscow on February 3, 1916 and arrived in Marseille on April 16 of the same year."

Name s/b MILAZZO for this and other photos in this series. SS Milazzo was an Italian bulk carrier built in 1916 and sunk during World War I. When she entered service, Milazzo was reported as the largest collier and also the largest cargo ship in the world. She was designed with a unique railcar and elevator system that helped to automate the discharge of cargo. [1]

Despite the spelling on the image, this was of SS Milazzo, an Italian bulk-carrier/collier. It was the largest cargo ship in the world at the time of its launch. It arrived in New York on its maiden voyage on 1 July 1916, which is likely around the time the photos in this series were taken. (This exact image appeared in a profile of the ship in “Popular Science” in Sept. 1916.) The ship was short-lived, being sunk by an Austro-Hungarian U-Boat in the Mediterranean on 29 Aug. 1917.

The New York Sun., June 19, 1916, page 1 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030272/1916-06-19/ed-... is almost entirely about the call for National Guards from all states to mobilize for possible service on the Mexican border and some details for New York National Guard. The entire NY guard was "expected at Camp Whitman as soon after noon today as possible." The evening world., June 27, 1916, Final Edition, page 1 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030193/1916-06-27/ed-... reports that the 7th regiment was one of the first to head for the Mexican border, starting its rail trip on June 27, 1916 The evening world., June 30, 1916, Final Edition, page 1, column 1 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030193/1916-06-30/ed-... indicates that NY guard troops would be based along a ten-mile stretch of the border between Harlingen and Sam Fordyce, Texas (about 30 miles west of Brownsville). New-York tribune., July 01, 1916, Page 2, col 6 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1916-07-01/ed-... indicates that details of troop movement were to be censored. The Sun and New York press., July 07, 1916, Page 3 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030430/1916-07-07/ed-... has a picture captioned "The Seventh gets a real rest on Texas soil." Given that this picture and a neighboring one seem to be of making camp, the date would likely be early July, 1916.
The Sun and New York press, July 05, 1916, Page 3 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030430/1916-07-05/ed-... suggests arrival by July 2 (Sunday).
Also in the Robert Runyon collection. There this is identified as the 14th NY Infantry

Interesting that the Runyon original is not blurry. Must have been a bad copy job by Bain. According to this regimental history of the 14th: "Mexican Border Service Their next call to duty was the Mexican Border Service on July 19, 1916. Their order was a ten day hike across the wastes of Hidalgo County, Texas. The conditions were harsh and often consisted of temperatures reaching 120 degrees with no shade to block them from the sun. In September they were ordered home and shortly thereafter mustered out of service." dmna.ny.gov/historic/reghist/numbered/14thReg.htm

I don't think one is any more or less blurry than the other,  but the increased contrast of all the Bain pix relative to the Runyon originals washes out a lot of detail.  

I don't know whether that's an unavoidable side effect of copying in the early 20th century or if it was done on purpose to make newspaper friendly halftones easier.
Thanks to all of you for your great research into the photograph as well as the regiment.  We'll add some of the information to both records the next time we update.

The official name of this group was the Active Service Auxiliary of the National Guard of New York, and they established headquarters in the 71st Regiment Armory in July, 1916, according to this newspaper article: rrlcnewspapers.org/lccn/sn84024315/1916-07-10/ed-1/seq-2/ A very similar picture was used in the New York Times story on the organization : query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9E03E6DD1E31E7... This picture was used in The Sunday Oregonian. (Portland, Ore.), July 23, 1916, with the caption: " Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt has organized a committee of women to look after the families of the militiamen who have gone to the border. Mrs. Colonel William Whitehead Ladd, Mrs. Edward Olmstead. Mrs. General John O'Ryan, Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, Mrs. Fred W. Waterbury, Mrs. O. B. Brldgeman, Mrs. F. E. Humphreys and Mrs. W. S. Terrikerry are among her assistants. " oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83045782/1916-07-23/ed-1/se...

Mrs. Lt. Colonel William Whitehead Ladd, Mrs. Capt. Edward D. Olmstead, Mrs. Gen. John F. O'Ryan, Mrs. Col. Cornelius Vanderbilt III, Mrs. Maj. Fred M. Waterbury, Mrs. Brig. Gen. Oliver B. Bridgeman, Mrs. Maj. Frederic M. Humphreys and Mrs. Lt. Col. Willam S. Terriberry were all wives of top division staff of the N.Y. National Guard units sent to the Mexican border in the June, 1916 callup. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9403E4DB1439E2... We've seen most of their husbands before in their military gear dmna.ny.gov/historic/reghist/mexBorder/mexBorder_history_...

As to the actual names of these women, Mrs. Vanderbilt was Grace Graham Wilson Vanderbilt (1870-1953). en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grace_Vanderbilt Mrs. Terriberry was Emilie Reinhart Terriberry (1876-1948) freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~fams/durrenber... Mrs. Humphreys was Myrtle Lee Humphreys (1888-1980) www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=111325043 Mr.s O'Ryan was Janet Holmes O'Ryan (1882-1958) www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=57752805 Mrs. Waterbury was Marty Blackmur Waterbury fultonhistory.com/newspaper%208/Schenectady%20NY%20Gazett...

Art Siegel: Thanks for tracking down the name of the organization and the similar photo published in the NY Times with identifications. Unfortunately, the two women at either end of the photo were cropped out. Any idea who they are? Probably Mrs. Ladd and Mrs. Terriberry?

Yes, the full photo and identification list, from left to right, is in the Sunday Oregonian link in my first post above, so the women cropped out by the NYT were Ladd and Terriberry.  I'll bet they were miffed.  I would also bet the photo was taken inside the 71st Regiment Armory.
She was American by birth, acording to The Cornell Daily Sun, Volume XXXVII, Number 27, 8 November 1916 (cdsun.library.cornell.edu/cgi-bin/cornell?a=d&d=CDS19...)

As a soprano, she disappeared from the newspapers from 1917. Loretta Tannert was obviously her original name; in 1921 she was bankrupt, according to the NYT, July 28, 1921, col. 1, "BANCRUPTCY DISCHARGES".

The modern Guardia Rural dates officially from 1926, but was an amalgamation of the local militias that sprang up in the wake of the Agrarian Land Decree of 1915. These fellows, mounted, with sabers and carbines and lots and lots of silver braid, definitely look more like the earlier Federal era Rurales. My only concern as to identification would be the uniform color. The Rurales uniforms had dove grey sombreros and bolo jackets, with tan leather chaps over gray trousers, red ties, red rank insignia, and lots of silver braid (if anybody wants to hand color this pic.) Do the jackets and sombreros seem of different color? Or just different weight? Of course, just because they were disbanded in 1914 doesn't mean they ceased to exist. I can definitely imagine this company of Rurales reforming under the auspices of Tamaulipas as a state guard force. In Los Rurales de México (www.scribd.com/doc/122062594/Los-rurales-de-Mexico-por-Jo...) Elias states that after disbandment, many Rurales were simply incorporated in the new army while others joined up with Pancho Villa or Zapata. (page 23) Francisco Medina, however, supports the State Guard possibility Soon, in various parts of the Mexican Republic, new groups were formed called "Civil Defense Corps" which battled all kinds of local banditry - these Corps were active as part of the "National Guard" under the state governments until 1947. (www.almomento.mx/la-negra-historia-de-la-policia-rural/, translation my own)

Samuel Stillman Pierce (1887-1973) from earlyaviators.com/epierces.htm : Samuel S. Pierce died August 4, 1973 at his home in Milton, Mass. where he was a teacher for many years at the Milton Academy. He was a grandson of Samuel S. Pierce, founder of the food chain that bears his name. He was born in Wellesley Hills, Mass. January 23, 1887 In 1910 he studied at the Louis Bleriot Flying School in France where he obtained a pilot's license. He made his first solo flight March 23, 1911. In 1916 he joined the New York Militia as Ensign and taught flying at Bayshore, N.Y. He and a student were seriously injured in the smash-up of a Burgess-Dunne seaplane, ending his flying career. The balance of World War I he spent at the Naval Aircraft Factory in Philadelphia, resigning as Lieutenant, USNRF in 1921 due to poor health. He is survived by his wife, Mary Sweitzer Pierce, a daughter, Mrs. Mary Pillsbury of Milton, Mass. and three grandchildren. Yes, that is a Burgess-Dunne Seaplane he's standing in front of.
See also comments under www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/14004100262/ Ensign Samuel Pierce is mentioned in the cited papers.

This photo is depicted in The sun., July 02, 1916, Page 7 with the caprtion: "Mrs. Vincent Astor christening the high power hydroaeroplane presented by a group of citizens of New York to the Second Battalion, New York Naval Militia. The ceremony took place at the headquarters, Fifty-second street and the bay, Brooklyn. Vincent Astor is standing to the left." (chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030272/1916-07-02/ed-...)
Another article about the event is in the NYT, July 2, 1916 (query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=F4091FF73A5B17...)

An additional article about the event in Aerial Age Weekly, Volume 3, July 10, 1916, page 503, Second Battalion N.M.N.Y. Seaplane Christened : books.google.com/books?id=FNRLAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA503&l... Note, that the Aerial Age story states that Charles L. Lawrance of the "citizens' committee which bought the seaplane," was also present. Lawrance is the very same person who would design the Lawrance J-1 radial engine, the direct predecessor to the Wright Whirlwind engine which would power countless historically significant flights, including that of Charles Lindbergh and the Spirit of St. Louis from New York to Paris. See photo of Lawrance below standing to the right side of the frame, next to Lindbergh at Curtiss Field prior to Lindbergh's solo transatlantic flight: [https://www.flickr.com/photos/sdasmarchives/6107336142/in/photolist-aiFGcd-aiFGg1-mLsXCm-6LcCfc-9EhxM6]

The photo in The Sun is of the same moment, but taken by a different photographer who stood to the right of Bain's photographer.  More from The Sun article cited above: "Then they swung a big derrick over and just as it had made fast Mrs. Astor stepped forward and cracked a bottle of champagne over the hull with the words: "I christen thee No. 1."
As It was swung over into the water everybody cheered, and then Ensign Astor, commanding a fleet of motor boats, towed it out to clear water, where Ensign Samuel Pierce climbed in. started the engines to roaring and after gliding over the water shot the plane up into the air for a twelve minute trip around Fort Hamilton and back.  Ensign Pierce brought the flying boat back without trouble and the crowd cheered again, aided in the noise making by all the whistles of craft that knew anything about it at all."
52d street pier in Brookyn, recent street view: maps.google.com/maps?q=52d+street,+brooklyn&ll=40.650...

Apparently another photo in the sequence of the Christening of the New York Naval Militia's Burgess-Dunne Seaplane at the foot of 52nd St. in Brooklyn in July 1916. The gentleman standing to the left, looming above a seemingly pensive and seated Vincent Astor (Astor's then-wife, Helen Dinsmore Huntington, with parasol and roses in hand, is seated to the right of Commodore Robert P. Forshew) is almost certainly Charles L. Lawrance. Lawrance would go on to play a vital role aviation (see below). Here's an article about the event in Aerial Age Weekly, Volume 3, July 10, 1916, page 503, Second Battalion N.M.N.Y. Seaplane Christened : books.google.com/books?id=FNRLAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA503&l... Note, that the Aerial Age story states that Charles L. Lawrance of the "citizens' committee which bought the seaplane," was also present. Lawrance is the very same person who would design the Lawrance J-1 radial engine, the direct predecessor to the Wright Whirlwind engine which would power countless historically significant flights, including that of Charles Lindbergh and the Spirit of St. Louis from New York to Paris. See a photo of Lawrance below standing to the right side of the frame, next to Lindbergh at Curtiss Field prior to Lindbergh's solo transatlantic flight in 1927: [https://www.flickr.com/photos/sdasmarchives/6107336142/in/photolist-aiFGcd-aiFGg1-mLsXCm-6LcCfc-9EhxM6] More about Lawrance: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Lawrance

Cavalry commander during the Villa Punitive Expedition: "Brigadier General William C. Brown, Regimental Commander, 10th Cavalry ------------ Brown Parade, the parade ground on the old main post at Fort Huachuca, is named after Brigadier General William Carey Brown who commanded the fort and the 10th U.S. Cavalry as a colonel from 1914 to 1916. The native of Traverse des Sioux, Minnesota, was born in 1854. Following graduation from the U.S. Military Academy at West Point in 1877, he was assigned to the 1st U.S. Cavalry at Fort Walla Walla, Washington, participating in the 1878 Bannock Indian Campaign in Washington, Oregon and Idaho. He was on detached service in 1879 at the Umatill Indian Agency, Oregon, in operations against Sheepeater and Bannock Indians. William Carey Brown commanded the 10th Cavalry and Fort Huachuca from 1914 to 1916, and led the regiment into Mexico during the Punitive Expedition, Later as a Brigadier General he would serve in Europe during World War 1. The parade field on Fort Huachuca's Old Post is named for him. He served as commanding officer of Troop C, 1st U.S. Cavalry, at Fort Assinniboine, Montana, in the winter campaign of 1890-91 against the Sioux. Other assignments took him to West Point and the World's Columbian Exposition in Chicago in 1893. His service included time as cavalry troop commander at Fort Grant and San Carlos, Arizona, in the 1880s. Brigadier General Brown's days as troop and field officer included chasing the renegade Apache Kid in Arizona and commanding a troop in the Battle of San Juan, Cuba. He was instrumental in the development of the U.S. Army emergency field ration, the introduction of aluminum to lighten U.S. Army equipment, and other important inventions to improve weapons and equipment. As colonel of cavalry he assumed command of the 10th U.S. Cavalry at Fort Huachuca on December 8, 1914, and deployed the regiment along the Mexican border to enforce U.S. neutrality laws during the revolution which then wracked Mexico. When Francisco "Pancho" Villa burned Columbus, New Mexico, on March 8, 1916, Brown led his regiment in the Mexican Punitive Expedition under General Pershing. There he distinguished himself in the last combat rides of the U.S. Cavalry, after rationing his men out of his own pocket. Most prominent of his exploits was a forced march of the 10th U.S. Cavalry, led by him, which rescued the 7th U.S. Cavalry from a siege of carranzistas, at Parral on April 12, 1916. Later as a brigadier general, he was sent to France during World War I as inspector, Quartermaster Corps, General Headquarters of the American Expeditionary Forces. There he saved the Army hundreds of thousands of dollars while supervising the receipt, storage, conservation, rehabilitation, and distribution of property and supplies, winning the Distinguished Service Medal and the Silver Star Medal for his work. Brig. Gen. Brown died at Denver, Colorado, on May 8, 1939." webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:http://www....

A North Carolina boy! While Gordon Johnston (1874-1934) was a Captain in the Regular Army, he held Colonel's rank when he was assigned to lead the 12th NY Infantry on the Mexican border (reverting to Captain when he left the 12th.) He eventually made colonel in the regular army - having achieved fame as "the rescuer of the Lost Battalion" in WWI (He had a good publicist) Like a true southerner, prickly about his pride, Johnston's fame during his stay with the 12th largely revolved around his resigning his commission when he felt that the 12th had been insulted when on parade in Texas. He'd have made a great Confederate Officer. To his credit, he had already won the Medal of Honor 10 years earlier. Interestingly, while this photograph of Johnston during his New York National Guard service is often used (though he is wearing Regular Army insignia,) his time with the 12th in Texas is largely ignored in most biographical sketches. Fuller bio: books.google.com/books?id=gejhoRgwLXwC&pg=PA302&d...

This is June 27, 1916, at the Pennsylvania Railroad ferry station at West and Desbrosses Streets in Manhattan, where the 7th boarded the ferry Chicago at 10:14 a.m. to Jersey City to board trains for McAllen,Texas. The New York Sun reported it by the minute: "For the sake of those who like their itineraries straight let It be said that the Seventh marched out of its armory at Sixty-sixth street and Park avenue at 8:20 o'clock yesterday morning, marched over to the Sixth avenue elevated, past the Governor of New York and uncountable other persons who weren't ashamed to be seen blinking in what the police would call a suspicious manner, rode in elevated trains down to Grand street, boarded the ferryboat Chicago at Desbrosses street at 10:14, started for Jersey City at 10:16, got there at 10:23 and were ready to entrain at 10:30. All this according to the watch of Lt.-Col. Cornelius Vanderbilt, who, detailed as inspector-general, clocked each phase. By a Sun reporter's watch, the first section of the special train started rolling at 1:27 p.m. and the second section at 1:45." chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030272/1916-06-28/ed-...

After retiring from public life, he served as the chancellor of Queen's University." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Borden

This was taken in Columbus Circle, in front of the Pabst Grand Circle Hotel (looking south down Broadway). Reischenweber's, in back of the hotel at 58th street, was a famous jazz club. The 12th marched from their armory at 63rd St. and Columbus Avenue at 4:45 p.m. on June 27, 1916 for their destination on the Mexican border. "The men of the Twelfth are mostly mechanics and other hard workers. Their relatives and friends - including many babies - were all around the armory. The police tried to keep the soldiers and their families separated, but through Sixty-third street and down to Columbus Circle the mass moved as one. "These people, said Col. Wadsworth, are going to get a chance to say good-by to the boys. Halt!" So the regiment halted while the kissing went right on. New York Sun, June 29, 1916. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030272/1916-06-29/ed-...

I think this might be a misspelling of Fr. James Nicholas Connolly (1864-1934). Connolly (for 10 years private secretary to the Archbishop, later Rector of Our Lady of Good Counsel Church) was first appointed Regimental Chaplain in 1901, having earlier served on a hospital ship during the Spanish American War. He went on to have a somewhat mixed record in France during WWI.

Guess I spoke too soon. We'll have to sort out the correct spelling of Father Connolly (or Conley)'s name before we update the record.

The sources confirm that the name of the chaplain of the 12th Regiment was indeed James Nicholas Connolly. A short article about his appointment is in The Sacred Heart Review, Volume 26, Number 11, 14 September 1901 (newspapers.bc.edu/cgi-bin/bostonsh?a=d&d=BOSTONSH1901...). An obituary of him is in the BROOKLYN DAILY EAGLE, NEW YORK, DECEMBER 7, 1934, col 6 (fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%205/Brooklyn%20NY%20Daily%20E...) and in the New York National Guardsman, January 1935, page 6 (dmna.ny.gov/historic/research/NY_National_Guardsman/NYNG1...). He was regimental chaplain for 18 years.
Oddly, the NYT called him "Conley" in other editions as well, e.g. on August 8, 1910 (query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=FA0D10F8395417...).

NYT can be quite inconsistent with their spellings. I think it's clear this fellow is J.N. Connolly. The regimental records support this. Also, here's a death notice, mentioning that he had served on the Mexican border as a military chaplain: news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1144&dat=19341207&... The June 25th New York times gets the spelling right, listing the Rev. James N. Connolly as Chaplain of the 12th. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=FB0915FA3F5D17...
Thanks for this confirmation artolog. We'll correct the spelling the next time we update the record.

That's the date recorded on the negative, indicating it wasn't taken before that date.  It can be a later date, such as when it went into the lab or was cataloged.  And sometimes there are multiple dates, years apart.

What does draw me into photographs like this is that a few moments before it was taken Col Bates was probably being asked to stand still and then a few seconds later he may have broken out into a smile and said "was that OK" or even "I haven't got time to stand around like this". When the 71st marched out of their armory at 34th and Lexington on June 27, 1916, bound for the Mexican border, they marched west to 5th Avenue with 45 pounds of equipment each, then uptown to 58th Street and west to 11th Avenue, and north to the New York Central rail yards at 60th St. (11th Ave. became West End Ave. at 59th Street). There, they boarded 46 wooden passenger cars for the 5 day trip. They arrived at the yards at 11:35 a.m. According to The Sun's account: "The train were all standing ready, the cars open and inviting looking, but the men had a roasting of fifty minutes in the sun before things were ready for them." This and the linked photo were taken on West End Avenue, looking North. The building at far right stood between 60th and 61st Streets. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030272/1916-06-28/ed-... digitalgallery.nypl.org/nypldigital/dgkeysearchdetail.cfm... query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=FA0C14FA3C5F13...

"Henry" Seimatsu (or Kiyomatsu) Kimura (1874 - 1958)  Japanese evangelist and congregationalist minister.

Sometimes referred to as "Hallelujah Kim" or "The Japanese Billy Sunday"

A cropped version of this photo ran in The Sunday Oregonian. (Portland, Ore.) August 06, 1916 with the caption: "Japan has an evangelist who Is known as "the Billy Sunday of Japan." He is Seimatsu Kimura, sometimes called "Hallelujah Kim." He had to leave home 25 years ago because of his espousal of the Christian religion, and he entered the Industrial Home and there earned an education. His monthly allowance was 25 cents. He devoted two-thirds of that and all of his spare time to a Sunday school for poor children. Two of his pupils there are now the wives of Christian missionaries in Hawaii and California. Kim came to America when still quite young, and at San Francisco pleaded with Dwight Moody, the evangelist, to help him get an education. He has been doing evangelistic work in Japan since 1901. He paid one visit to America during that period, especially to study the methods of Billy Sunday. He has used like methods in Japan and with great success. " oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83045782/1916-08-06/ed-1/se...

Charles H. Hitchcock, 1857-1934. In 1916, Brigadier General, 1st Infantry, N.Y. National Guard. His obituary from the December, 1934, issue of "The New York National Guardsman" magazine. "THE LATE BRIG. GEN. CHARLES H. HITCHCOCK By Lt. Col. Floyd D. McLean, Inf. Res. IF ever a man exemplified in his life the true attributes of an officer and a gentleman, that man was the late Brigadier General Charles H. Hitchcock, who answered the last roll call on October 30, 1934. An accomplished student of the classics and a translator of the works of Greek philosophers and historians, he was as much at home with Horace and Virgil as with Blackstone and Clausewits. He had several translations printed of the Greek plays among the last of which was Agamemnon of Aeschylus about five years ago and he wrote a number of articles for the service journals under his own name and also under the nom de plume of N. G. Miles which those who remember their Latin will recognise as National Guard Soldier. Born of pioneer stock in Binghamton on November 12, 1857, he was educated in the public schools and graduated from Hamilton Collège in 1879, later teaching school for a short period and then beginning the study of law in which he became distinguished, particularly in the branch of real estate and land titles. He became a partner in the law firm of Jenkins, Deyo and Hitchcock. Enlisting in the old 20th Separate Company in 1882 he came up through ail grades to Captain in 1897 and commanded Company H of the 1st New York Volunteers during the Spanish-American War when that désignation was given to the 20th Separate Company before the regiment went to the Hawaiian Islands where it remained until Christmas time in 1898. Thereafter General Hitchcock's advancement was rapid and he became Colonel, commanding the 1st New York Infantry in 1905, being breveted Brigadier General on July 19, 1910. At one time he was président of the National Guard Association of the State of New York and was later a member of the governor's military council. Standing over six feet tall with a fine military bearing, one would instantly recognise him as a soldier even in mufti. Because of ill health he went on the reserve list on March 5, 1917, but offered to the Government any service that he was able to render. He was detailed to active duty in the Adjutant Genera's office of New York State on April 18, 1917, where he served for several months. He was later given a commission in command of a company of the United States Guards on June 10, 1918, serving at Fort Niagara and later in the shipyard at Newburgh, New York. He was honorably discharged from United States service on February 1, 1919, with the same rank that he held at the end of the Spanish-American War although meantime he had successfully commanded a regiment of Infantry for more than 12 years. He was a member of the Thomas H. Barbour Camp, United Spanish War Vétérans; Army and Navy Club, New York City; a charter member of Binghamton Post 80, American Légion and a member of the Richard J. Hoyt Post 478, Vétérans of Foreign Wars. He had served his city as Commissioner of Health and was a member of the Court of Honor of the Boy Scouts of America up to the time of his death. In 1891 he married Miss Estelle Heath of Ithaca who survives. One of the last public functions that he attended was the review of the 10th Infantry and 104th Field Artillery during the Binghamton Centennial on October 9. The final military honors were in charge of the 10th Infantry. "Honor, Duty, Country" was his creed, and he lived up to it in his personal and public life, giving unselfish service to his community, state and nation. " dmna.ny.gov/historic/research/NY_National_Guardsman/NYNG1... See also

Actually Col. Willard C (for Clinton) Fisk.  Commander of the 7th Regiment (note "7" badge on cap) of the 27th Division (New York National Guard)

Fisk enlisted in the 7th as a private in 1874 and retired as a Lt. Colonel in 1915.  He was recalled in 1916 as a full colonel to command the 7th when the previous commander retired.  He led the regiment  (as the 107th Infantry) on the Western Front in 1918.

This is where the Charles Evans Hughes family lived in the Summer of 1916. The house, "Tremedden", was built in l878 in Bridgehampton, Long Island by Richard Esterbrook, heir to the Esterbrook Pen Company fortune. Rabbi Leon Harrison (1866, Liverpool, England - 1928, New York City) was a Reform rabbi, based in St. Louis at Temple Israel from 1890 until his death, but also a nationally known religious leader, author and thinker. "Rabbi Harrison was one of the first Reform rabbis in this country to conduct the services not only in Hebrew but also in English, having himself translated a number of the prayers into English. He also introduced Sunday morning services at Temple Israel, announcing that these services were open to Jews, Catholics and Protestants and anyone who cared to come within its doors." Read more: www.jta.org/1928/09/05/archive/many-mourn-rabbi-leon-harr...

Alexander B. C. Weel of Brooklyn, a similar photo is in The evening world., June 23, 1916, Final Edition, Page 10 with the caption "Hero of Ypres Resigns as British Captain To Go to Mexico for Uncle Sam as Private" (chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030193/1916-06-23/ed-...) The article says that the photo was taken in Van Cortlandt Park.

A cropped version of this photo, with a short account of Weel's war heroism, was on the front page of the Batavia, N.Y. Daily News. fultonhistory.com/newspaper%2010/Batavia%20NY%20Daily%20N... Apparently Weel was something of a con man and his widely reported tales of wartime exploits probably untrue. The following year, the Brooklyn Daily Eagle reported that he had been convicted of forgery, dishonorably discharged, and sentenced to 2 1/2 years at Leavenworth. His officers "generally discredited the stories he had told of his adventurous career abroad." He had been arrested in McAllen, Texas in August, 1916 and spent the rest of his military service imprisoned awaiting trial. www.newspapers.com/image/#53892723

Graham guardian., February 09, 1917, page 1 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn95060914/1917-02-09/ed-... has a picture of Prince Abdul Halim, Turkish crown prince -- in German uniform.
swanq: thanks for finding more information on Abdul Halim.  We'll update the record to include more information.

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/pete_loc] The Turkish royal succession looks very tangled. See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_sultans_of_the_Ottoman_Empi... And like popes they adopt different names at accession. I have not yet figured out whose sons these might be. I'm pretty certain this "crown prince" never ruled. There seem to have been family divisions over joining Germany and over treatment of foreigners. Looking at the name Halim: Confusingly, the Grand Vizier at this time was en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Said_Halim_Pasha and members of his family seem to have used the title "prince." See books.google.com/books?id=mjeexS2nZK0C&pg=PA90&lp... "HH Prince Said Halim (Young Turk and son of the late Halim Pasha, son of Mehemet Ali, Viceroy of Egypt)" and translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=tr&u=http... "Belonging to this family because of "Prince" was named." Note that Turkish grammar is very different from more common languages, and Google's Translate makes a hash of almost everything! I do find myself wondering whether this Abdul Halim is the son of Said Halim Pasha (the Grand Vizier at the time); if so, he would have been named after his grandfather, Prince Mehmet Abdülhalim Paşa who died in 1894 in Istanbul.

Another complication is that in 1915, when the Washington Herald (see above) described Prince Abdul Halim as heir to Turkish throne, he quite definitely wasn't. The heir at the time was en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yusuf_Izzettin_Efendi

web.archive.org/web/20080516115029/http://www.egy.com/P/r... shows ............. 3 [211] Moh. Saiid Halim b: January 18, 1865 in Shubra, Cairo d: December 06, 1921 in assassinated in Rome ................ +[212] Amina Indji Toussoun b: January 03, 1876 d: May 31, 1915 in Yenikoy, Istanbul .................... 4 [213] Moh. Abdel Halim b: 1896 in Istanbul .................... 4 [34] Omar Saiid Halim b: February 16, 1898 in Yenikoy, Turkey d: 1954 So Said Halim Pasha did indeed have two sons and the older might have been known by Abdul Halim. Another family tree is at members.iinet.net.au/~royalty/states/islamic/egypt.html

On the left is Louis Frederic Holbrook Betts. LFH was the son of Frederic Henry Betts, a NY patent attorney and, with his brother, one of the early developers of the Southampton summer colony. LFH played a bit of tennis and joined his father's law firm. Never married himself, he did serve as an usher at the first wedding of his friend . . . . . . Clarence Hungerford Mackay. Mackay was the son of Comstock Lode silver baron and telegraph mogul John W. Mackay. He also played a bit of tennis. In 1910 his wife ran off to Paris with the family doctor with divorce to follow in 1914. Mackay's company eventually became International Telephone & Telegraph (ITT)

" Louis Frederic Holbrook Betts, Born May 21, 1870, in New York City, Died June 29, 1926, in Campbellton, New Brunswick. B.A. Yale 1891, LL B. Harvard 1894. " Prominent patent lawyer. From LOC's summary of the 1916 convention: "Wilson had planned to showcase the theme of Americanism and national unity at the convention. Americanism was Wilson’s approach to the future role of the United States as a key world power. However, it was pacifism and Wilson’s commitment to keeping the United States out of the raging conflict in Europe that dominated the convention. By the second day, Wilson’s determined neutrality regarding the war became the theme of the convention, and the slogan “He kept us out of the war” became the battle cry of the delegates. The Democratic platform included a call for military preparedness and the progressive reforms made by the Wilson administration, particularly with respect to tariffs, banking, labor and agriculture. The only section of the platform brought to a floor vote was the plank on women’s suffrage. The majority plank favored extending the vote to women, while a minority plank advocated leaving the matter to the individual states. The minority plank was defeated by a vote of 888 ½ to 181 ½. The Democratic position on women’s suffrage contrasted with that of the Republicans, who proposed leaving the matter up to the individual states. " www.loc.gov/rr/main/democratic_conventions.pdf

One of a handful of Bain photos of wartime Lemberg. Lemberg is the German word for the city now known as Lviv, and which has also been known as Lvov and "Lwów". In 1914, it was in Austro-Hungary and was taken by the Russians. This picture is probably from after June, 1915, when the Austrians re-took the city, remaining in control until the end of the war. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lemberg en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Lviv

Dick See www.encyclopedia-titanica.org/mrs-john-j-astor-marry-w-k-... for a transcription of an NYT article from June 18, 1916, which reports, "Mrs. Madeleine Force Astor, widow of John Jacob Astor, who was lost on the Titanic, is to marry again. Tomorrow, reports say, at her estate in Bar Harbor, Me., she will become the wife of William K. Dick, member of an old and very wealthy Brooklyn family and a friend of her girlhood days."

He is identified as William Karl Dick in Madeleine's Wikipedia entry.  Very detailed genealogical information is given in the Vanderbilt Cup Races blog, including the following:                                           "William K. Dick (1888-1953)

William K. Dick was an American businessman, industrialist and banker. He served as chairman of the board of the National Sugar Refining Company, as well as a director of several large corporations, including Best Foods, Inc., Broadway Trust Company, Douglas Gibbons & Company, the Eastern States Corporation, the Norwood and St. Lawrence Railroad, the St. Regis Paper Company, the St. Regis Company Ltd. of Canada, and the St. Regis Timber Company.

His first wife, Madeleine Force Astor, was the widow of John Jacob Astor IV, multimillionaire businessman, inventor, writer and victim of the Titanic sinking. Their marriage ended in divorce in 1933. Dick's second wife, Virginia Conner, was a prominent interior designer and a furniture designer. His second son, John Henry Dick, was a renowned ornithologist, photographer, naturalist, conservationist, author, painter and bird illustrator. William K. Dick's grandfather, William Dick, was a pioneer in the founding of the sugar industry in America."http://www.vanderbiltcupraces.com/blog/article/six_degrees_of_separation_a_mystery_photo_the_1908_vanderbilt_cup_race_and_

I can't find a record of a Captain Hoppe, but this is French Capt. Maurice Happe on the right. His picture accompanies the following article: "This is the most well-known photo of Capitaine Maurice Happe (1882-1930), one of France’s most innovative bombing pioneers. He commanded Groupe de Bombardement 4 as well as Escadrille 29. One of his biographers described Happe in this way: His tall silhouette, all sinew and muscles, in a black artillery uniform without officer’s boards or decoration, stood out against the blue of the Vosges Mountains... He [was] obsessed with one concern: accomplishing everything that was his duty. His gaze softened or turned dark depending on his mood. He was subject to mood swings; there was something of the street Arab in his personality. But when he laughed, his brilliant white teeth reminded one of a wolf’s teeth." :La Guerre Aérienne Illustrée (LGAI)" www.crossandcockade.com/uploads/EscMF29_opt.pdf
Other Bain photos of Capt. Happe:

I don't think it's a Farman F40, which had a rounded nose, but it is a Farman model of some kind. Some sources mention that Happe flew a F11bis, and also that he made a lot of modifications. Here's another Flickr user's picture of what is identified as an F40bis. flic.kr/p/8WJoSB
This looks like the same model Farman, but no model number is given: flic.kr/p/8tAequ
Farman MF.11 bis of Escadrille 62, 1915

From a publication of a French military archive; "Fonds du lieutenant-colonel Félix, louis, maurice happe (1882-1930). saint-cyrien, détaché en 1912 sur sa demande au service aéronautique, il obtient son brevet militaire de pilote d’avion en février 1913. il est promu capitaine fin 1914, nommé commandant de l’escadrille mF 29 en mai 1915, puis du gB 4 début 1916. promu commandant, il est nommé inspecteur des écoles d’aviation en juin 1917, poste qu’il occupe pendant quatre mois avant de réintégrer l’infanterie à sa demande. il est alors affecté sur le front italien puis détaché à l’armée polonaise en France en janvier 1919. a la fin du mois de décembre de cette même année, il passe à la division militaire française en pologne. les opérations terminées, il y sera chargé de réorganiser l’armée polonaise. il rentre ensuite en France et mourra en service aérien commandé en Belgique en 1930." www.servicehistorique.sga.defense.gouv.fr/contenu/functio...

This photo appears  with the following caption on a French site devoted to squadron 29, which Happe commanded: "Cne Maurice Happe, à droite, commandant l'escadrille MF 29, présente un MF 11 bis de son unité à un visiteur. L'avion porte le premier insigne de l'unité, une Croix de Guerre, adoptée pour commémorer la citation à l'ordre de l'armée à l'occasion de la mort de cinq mécaniciens et de la blessure très grave du caporal Longueteau lors de l'explosion au sol d'un obus de 90, le 14 septembre 1915 - Photo SHD section Air de Vincennes - Photo n° B 88/3129 origine Maurice Happe."  Google translation: "Capt. Maurice Happe, right, commander of the squadron MF 29, MF 11a presents his unit to a visitor. The plane bears the insignia of the first unit, a Croix de Guerre, adopted to commemorate the quote to order the army during the deaths of five mechanics and the serious injury of Corporal during Longueteau the explosion of a shell floor 90, September 14, 1915 - Photo SHD Air section of Vincennes - Photo No. B 88/3129 Original Maurice Happe."
Thanks for all of this information! We'll correct Hoppe's name to Happe and add his dates to the catalog record next time we update.
