F. C. Robertson (Frederick C.) (b.1865) of Spokane, Washington, was a candidate in 1900 for U.S. Representative from Washington. He was an at-large delegate to both the 1912 and 1916 Democratic National Convention. In 1916 he was a member of the Platform and Resolutions Committee. [1] Norman Edward Mack (1858-1932) was editor and publisher of the Buffalo Daily Times. He was chairman of the Democratic National Committee from 1908 through 1912. [2] Hugh C. Wallace (Hugh Campbell), (1863-1931), of Tacoma, Washington. Wallace became one of the most influential financiers of the U.S. Northwest and was a leader of the Democratic party in the region. In 1916 he was a member of the Democratic National Committee. Wallace later served as American ambassador to France from 1919-1921. [3] Colonel J. I. Martin (John), (b.1848), of Saint Louis, was a long-serving sergeant-at-arms of the National Democratic conventions. He was a former Speaker of the Missouri House of Representatives. [4] [5]

August Lueders wrote an autobiography „Sixty Years in Chicago“, see archive.org/details/sixtyyearsinchic00lued (with photo). He was born on August 24, 1853 in Germany (page 5). His son was Dr. August Henry Lueders, who became the health commissioner. [m.flickr.com/#/photos/uicdigital/4771499556/] August Lueders (1853-1929). He died on December 18, 1929 at the home of his son in Hinsdale, Illinois.

Georges Thenault (1887-1948), commander of the Lafayette Escadrille - "the famed branch of the French air force in World War I composed of American volunteer pilots." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Georges_Thenault On Norman Prince (at right in photo): "Captain Georges Thenault, the Escadrille's commander, credits Norman for conceiving the idea of bringing together his countrymen with some of those of the French Foreign Legion in a squadron of flyers to be initially known as the Escadrille Américaine." A related group photo, with a negative date of 6/26/16. From Kiffin Yates Rockwell's (1892-1916) page at the Virginia Military Institute site: "Rockwell was accepted by the Service Aeronautique, began flight training in September 1915 and in April became one of the founding pilots in the squadron initially known as the Escadrille Americaine (later called the Lafayette Escadrille). In May 1916, while on patrol at the front, he became the first American pilot to down an enemy plane. Rockwell subsequently flew dozens of patrols and fought in many air battles, gaining fame for his skill and courage. His final combat took place on September 23, 1916, when his Nieuport was downed by the gunner in a German Albatross observation plane. Rockwell was first buried in the cemetery at Luxeuil-les-Bains, France, where there is still a marker; his remains were later moved to the Lafayette Escadrille Memorial at Marnes-la-Coquette." www.vmi.edu/archives.aspx?id=12371

archives.sps.edu/common/text.asp?Img=15197&Keyword=&a... says "David Wagstaff died June 15,- 1984, in Tuxedo Park, New York, at the age of seventy-four. New York Social Register, 1920 books.google.com/books?id=ek5IAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA766&l... identifies Mr and Mrs Henry D. Whitfield + Misses Louise and Fanny living in Tuxedo Park. And searching on Fanny Whitfield (as opposed to Frances Whitfield) with "Tuxedo Park" finds a girl winning at horse shows, for example in the NYT of June 10, 1917 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10811FF385F1B7A9...

The Saddle and Show Horse Chronicle, Volume 6 (January 1917) books.google.com/books?id=2EQ5AQAAMAAJ&pg=RA9-PA31&am... lists both Grace Wrenn (near top left of page 31) and Frances Whitfield (bottom right of page 30) competed in the Tuxedo Park Horse Show. On page 31, I find that Grace's pony was called Preston and Frances/Fanny's pony was Ginger.

Page 366 of 1915 notes from the Harvard Class of 1895 books.google.com/books?id=UDhOAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA367&l... reveals that Grace Dabney Wrenn is the daughter of Robert Duffield Wrenn and that her mother died the same year she was born (1906).

James J. Hill, railroad baron, and his son Louis W. Hill.

I wonder if this photo might not have been taken on North Oaks Farm, a project of both the father and son: "In 1883, railroad magnet [sic] James J. Hill purchased 3,500 acres of land in Moundsview and White Bear Townships from Charles D. Gilfillan. Hill named his property North Oaks Farm, and in the next few years purchased adjacent farms to increase his land ownership to about 5,500 acres. Hill's plan was to build a farm that would support his Great Northern Railway and the immigrant settlers the railroad brought to establish farms along its tracks. Hill saw his North Oaks Farm as an opportunity to improve both the agriculture and livestock and pass that knowledge on to the settlers to ensure their success, as well as supply them with seeds, supplies and livestock. As the farmers prospered, Hill theorized, so would the railroad. In its heyday, 400 men worked at the farm which had more than 40 buildings, some of which still stand and are part of the historic farm site and listed on the national registry. Louis Hill inherited the farm when James J. died in 1916. Upon Louis's death, his son, Louis Hill, Jr., took over the day-to-day operations of the farm, farming a portion of the land and keeping the rest as woodland." www.northoaks.com/history.htm

This appears to be the clay original of the Remington Centennial Trophy. "In 1916, the Remington Arms Company celebrated its 100th year in business, a major milestone for the gun maker. In the city of Ilion, New York, home of the company, a grand celebration was held lasting three days, from 29-31 August, featuring a poster contest, speeches by numerous dignitaries, a monument dedication, band music and a parade. Thousands of visitors crowded into the small village to enjoy the celebration. "To honor the achievement of 100 years in business The Centennial Commission of the Village of Ilion commissioned the noted sculptor, Albin Polasek (1879-1965), to produce a statue of the company's founder, Eliphalet Remington II. From the clay original were produced bronze statues, and one was sent to the Adjutant General of each state 'from the Village of Ilion.' "The letter, which accompanied each 40-pound statue, stated that its purpose was to encourage an interest in rifle practice and marksmanship by the 'organized militia' of each state. The details were left up to each state. The plaque on each statue states: 'Presented by Citizens of Ilion, New York to Organized Military of the U. S. for Perpetual Competition.' The donors suggested that each statue be awarded annually to the state military organization represented by the winning rifle team in a special match to be known as 'The Remington Centennial Trophy Match.' "Albin Polasek, Czech-American sculptor was born at Frenstat in Moravia, the Czech-Republic in 1879. He came to the U.S. in 1901, making his trade as a wood craver. In 1906 he studied at the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts. Subsequent to studies in Italy and Greece; he started his own studio in New York City. In 1916 he went to Chicago, where he was head of the Department of Sculpture at the Art Institute until 1943. In 1949, he purchased property on Lake Osceola in Winter Park, Florida and built his retirement home and studio. He continued to create his art until his death at the age of 86 on May 19, 1965. Today, the Albin Polasek Foundation operates his residence and studio in Winter Park, as the Albin Polasek Museum and Sculpture Gardens. "Eliphalet Remington II, (1793-1861) inventor, gunsmith, and arms manufacturer was born in Suffield, Connecticut. Remington was trained as a blacksmith, but turned to gunsmithing at an early age. With his father, he founded a smithy in upstate New York originally manufacturing farm tools. In 1816, Remington introduced a highly accurate rifle, the demand for which changed the focus of the business to firearms production. Upon his father’s death in 1828, Eliphalet took control of the business and established a rifle factory at Ilion, New York. ... On August 12, 1861, Eliphalet Remington died, and his son Philo took over the firm.” —National Guard History eMuseum and Remington Arms Museum

Photo was used in The Sunday Oregonian. (Portland, Ore.) June 25, 1916, SECTION FIVE, Image 62 with the caption: "Albin Polasek, a Bohemian sculptor of New York, is making a statue of Eliphalet Remington, the creator of the Remington rifle. Bronze replicas of this will be presented to each of the states, to be used as trophies for shooting competitions in the National Guard."
Very fine photo.  Thank you for sharing it.

According to freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~houghtonfamily... "Marian Arnot Haven was born on 9 February 1880 in New York City, NY, USA. She was the daughter of George Griswold Haven and Fanny Arnot. Marian Arnot Haven married Forsyth Wickes in 27 April 1905 at New York City, NY, USA. Children of Marian Arnot Haven and Forsyth Wickes: Fanny Haven Wickes Marian Forsyth Wickes Katherine Wickes Forsyth Wickes Jr." A 1924 picture of Fanny is at www.mfa.org/collections/object/miss-fanny-haven-wickes-ne... New England Families, Genealogical and Memorial: A Record of the Achievements of Her People in the Making of Commonwealths and the Founding of a Nation, Volume 2 books.google.com/books?id=ofcsAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA600&l... indicates that Fanny was born Feb 3, 1906 and Marion on Oct 1, 1907.
Marion died in 1965, according to her husband's 2000 obituary. archives.sps.edu/common/text.asp?Img=20368&Keyword=&a...

Parsons. fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%2018/New%20York%20NY%20Sun/Ne... A genealogical information page says Fanny W. Parsons was born on February 3, 1906 and died on August 28, 1987 at age 81. www.ancientfaces.com/person/fanny-w-parsons/10138986

This looks like the Abbie P. Morrison pictured in a 1918 newpaper appearing in a Junior League play benefiting war relief. One of 6 (so far posted) Bain photos of the Emergency Service Corps, which ran a 3 week training camp for 30 society girls in Pompton Lake, NJ, in June, 1916. It was a women's military training organization, meant to rival a similar "preparedness" camp for men in Plattsburgh, NY. (See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizens'_Military_Training_Camp). It was held on the estate of Edward Ringwood Hewitt, and run by his daughter, Candace Hewitt. See notes under
Thanks artolog, we will include some of the information you have uncovered on the records related to this training camp.

At the Emergency Service Corps training camp in June, 1916. An extremely wealthy and well-connected New York family. Edward Ringwood Hewitt (1866–1957), inventor, chemist and an early expert on fly-fishing. He published Telling on the Trout, among other books. He married Mary Ashley in 1892. www.ringwoodmanor.org/edward-ringwood-hewitt.html He was the son of Abram Hewitt, a mayor of New York but "best known for his work with the Cooper Union, which he aided Peter Cooper [his father-in-law) in founding in 1859, and for planning the financing and construction of the New York City subway, for which he is considered the "Father of the New York City Subway System"). en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abram_Hewitt. An illustrated newspaper article about the Hewitts and daughters Lucy and Candace appeared in the New York Sun and Herald in February, 1920, on the occasion of Lucy's engagement. It discusses the family's Wewappo Farm in Midvale, NJ, probably the site of this photo and the women's military training camp pictured. fultonhistory.com/newspaper%209/New%20York%20NY%20Sun/New... Acording to the Political Grvyard:
 William H. Reynolds (1868-1931) — of Long Beach, Nassau County, Long Island, N.Y. Born in Brooklyn, Kings County, N.Y., February 29, 1868. Republican. Builder; real estate developer; member of New York state senate 3rd District, 1894-95; indicted by a grand jury in August 1917 for perjury, over his 1912 expert testimony on the value of land sought by the city for a park; the grand jury alleged that he falsely denied any personal interest in the realty company which owned the property; also indicted in October 1917, with three others, for conspiracy defraud the city of $500,000 by inflating the appraisal; the indictments were dismissed in May 1920 over the prosecutor's delay of the trial; village president of Long Beach, New York, 1921-22; mayor of Long Beach, N.Y., 1922-24; removed 1924; defeated, 1925; indicted on May 1, 1924, along with the Long Beach city treasurer, for misappropriating city funds in connection with a bond issue; tried in June 1924, convicted, sentenced to six months in the county jail, and automatically removed from office as mayor; released pending appeal; the Appellate Division reversed the conviction in June 1925 and ordered a new trial; the indictment was dismissed in June 1927. English and Scotch-Irish ancestry. Member, Elks; Freemasons. Died, from heart disease, in Manhattan, New York County, N.Y., October 13, 1931 (age 63 years, 0 days). Interment at Green-Wood Cemetery, Brooklyn, N.Y.
  Relatives: Son of William Reynolds and Margaret (McChesney) Reynolds; married to Elise Guerrier.

NYT of Sept 17, 1916 select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F1061EF734551273... reports that in Brazil the development of rubber cultivation along plantation lines was still in an experimental stage, with one plantation of 50,000 trees, then three years old. The Sun and New York press., July 17, 1916, Image 5 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030430/1916-07-17/ed-... has an advertisement from B. F. Goodrich that indicates that rubber cultivation in plantations was a new development and hot topic (at least for Goodrich).

A detailed timeline for rubber at www.bouncing-balls.com/timeline/timeline4.htm indicates that in 1910: "Wild rubber production around 85,000 tons (50% Amazonian, 25% African, much of the rest from Mexico) and 11,000 tons of plantation rubber." And in 1913/14: "Cross over point! Plantation output of NR exceeds that of wild (ca. 55/75,000 tons plantation to 66/49,000 tons of wild)."

Jacques de Broglie (1878-1974), records.ancestry.com/Jacques_De_Broglie_records.ashx?pid=... Another photo of him is in The Register (Adelaide), 8 April 1926 He married Marie Antoinette Aussenac in 1925: (and divorced in 1933, see comments there)

The De Broglie family seems to have been quite a complicated one and I suspect that some of the attempts at genealogy that can be found on the web may be unreliable. But maisondebroglie.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/arbre-gene... looks official. Jacques, husband of Marguerite Wagram and Marie Antoinette (the latter not mentioned in the family tree) was a son of en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albert,_4th_duc_de_Broglie See NYT of August 3, 1901 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F40F11FE3A5414728... which has Prince Albert (born 1876) and Prince Jacques (born 1878) visiting the U.S. They are described as the sons of Prince Amédée, second son of the late Duc de Broglie, who died in January 1901. And trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/28030640?searchTerm=auss... indicates that he was in the United States in 1925. This might explain why Bain had a photo of him.

In the Richmond times-dispatch., December 06, 1914, Image 55, the woman on the same photo as in The Washington times of September 14, 1919 was described as Princess Jaques de Broglie. According to the text (col. 1), she was born Mlle. Berthier de Wagram, a member of the family descended from Napoleon's famous marshall. If so, she was Marguerite Berthier de Wagram (1887-1966), her husband was Jacques de Broglie (1878-1974), prince de Broglie (see fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marie_Say).

I now found out that the woman on the Bain photograph is Marie Antoinette Aussenac, a pianist, who was just married with Prince Jacques de Broglie in 1926, see The Register (Adelaide), 8 April 1926, with photos (date on the negative is 1926). They divorced in 1933 (The Sydney Morning Herald, 24 February 1933). According to records.ancestry.com/Antoinette_Aussenac_records.ashx?pid... she lived from 1883 to 1971. She was a student of Nikolai Obukhov and played also his "croix sonore" en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nikolai_Obukhov www.digplanet.com/wiki/Croix_Sonore Jaques de Broglie

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/66311327@N05] Your latest identification is likely the right one. And this might be one of the situations where Bain's filing got confused. There have been cases of pictures which must have been from the 1920s before. The De Broglie family seems to have been quite a complicated one and I suspect that some of the attempts at genealogy that can be found on the web may be unreliable. But maisondebroglie.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/arbre-gene... looks official. Jacques, husband of Marguerite Wagram and Jean, husband of Daisy (Marguerite Decazes) were cousins. Their fathers were sons of en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albert,_4th_duc_de_Broglie The family tree doesn't mention the marriage to Marie Antoinette Aussenac.
B-59 and swanq:  Thanks for all untangling the id of the mysterious princess here. We will update the description to include that the person depicted likely Aussenac.

Martha Stone Gay was engaged to George Clarke Whiting in March 1916, s. the NYT, March 18, 1916. They married on August 4, 1917 (New-York tribune., August 08, 1917, Page 7).

I have a positive ID of the occasion, a connection with Ms. Gay and a women's military training organization, the Emergency Service Corps, which ran a 3 week training camp for 30 society girls in Pompton Lake, NJ, in June, 1916. She is listed "among the thirty girl rookies" at the camp: fultonhistory.com/Newspapers%2021/Saratoga%20Springs%20NY... chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1916-06-02/ed-... Enhanced viewing of the hi-res version at LOC shows a lapel pin "ESC" on Ms. Gay's uniform. The camp was on the estate of Edward Ringwood Hewitt. More on the encampment: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=F60B17F63D5F13... A cropped version of this photo ran in the June 18, 1916 Sunday Oregonian with the caption: " Martha Gay. daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Gay, of New York, in common with many other society girls of Gotham, has joined in a camp at Midvale, N. J. This is a part of the preparedness wave sweeping the country. The society buds now at Midvale have hardly ever done anything more strenuous than swing a tennis racket before they joined the camp, which was established by Miss Candace Hewitt, of New York. Now they are drilling, policing camp and cooking." oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83045782/1916-06-18/ed-1/se...

"Lawrence Yates Sherman (November 8, 1858 – September 15, 1939) was a Republican politician from the State of Illinois. He served as United States Senator, the 28th Lieutenant Governor, and as Speaker of the Illinois House of Representatives. Sherman is best known for his role in preventing the ratification of the Treaty of Versailles, which kept the United States out of the League of Nations." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lawrence_Yates_Sherman In 1916 he was a possible candidate for the nomination for president of the United States (s. Mrs. Atwood is in the center of the neighboring photo of Women's Club delegates.

A Mrs. Agnes L. Atwood was the head of the women's department at the Minnesota State Employment Bureau. So, this might be her. See The labor world (Duluth, Minn.), June 17, 1916, Image 7, column 6, half-way down page chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn78000395/1916-06-17/ed-... But another possibility is the wife of ATWOOD, Clarence L. (b.1859), Hennepin Co., MN, the former Mary Elizabeth Crandall, a daughter of the Hon. Charles S. Crandall, senator from Owatonna, Minnesota. files.usgwarchives.net/mn/hennepin/bios/1923/atwoodcl.txt "The family are of the Unitarian faith and Mrs. Atwood is very active in church work. She has also been very prominent in women's club circles and was twice elected president of the Federation of Women's Clubs of Min­nesota, while in 1921 she was made a delegate to the international convention of Women's Clubs of the World held in Christiania, Norway. She is likewise widely known as a most entertaining and interesting public speaker, discussing many vital questions from the platform, and her presentation of a cause is always clear, logical and convincing."

The bulletin of the U.S. Bureau of Education books.google.com/books?id=vRE_AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA184&l... lists Mrs. Clarence L Atwood as the President of the Minnesota state federation of Women's Club for 1915-16. So this Bain photo is most likely of her.

"Lieutenant Alexander Blair Thaw, of the Aero Corps of the National Guard," is mentioned in the NYT of November 27, 1916. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10916FC395412738... which suggests that this picture may be related to the neighboring National Guard photos.

NYT of May 31, 1916 reports the crash at the Hempstead Aviation Field. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0F13FF3E5D1A72... Neither he, nor his cousin Elma McClintock, who was his passenger, was hurt.

The negative doesn't say N.Y. National Guard, and I think that is a captioning error. A June 25, 1916 N.Y. Times article reports on the mobilization of National Guard and civilian aviators for service with the Army, adding that the War Department had leased the Hempstead field near Garden City, Long Island for training aviators. The training camp was part of a federal, not state, effort, and wasn't a project of the N.Y. National Guard. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=F30D14FA3F5D17...

The tent flap looks like it says "2 S.C. NY," but that's where the tent came from and not necessarily the soldiers.  Given the mattressed bedstead and rug on the wooden floor, it wouldn't likely be a weekend maneuver encampment.

one of the fastest pre-dreadnoughts. Russell was steaming off Malta early on the morning of 27 April 1916 when she struck two sea mines that had been laid by the German submarine U-73. A fire broke out in the after part of the ship and the order to abandon ship was passed; after an explosion near the after 12-inch (305-mm) turret, she took on a dangerous list. However, she sank slowly, allowing most of her crew to escape. A total of 27 officers and 98 ratings were lost. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HMS_Russell_(1901)

NYT of May 30, 1916 lists several Memorial Day Parades in New York City, in Manhattan, in the Bronx, and in Brooklyn. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0A16F93A5B1773...

The account of the several 1916 Memorial Day parades in New York notes that the New York National Guard's First Armored Motor Battery would march in the Manhattan parade. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=FB0A16F93A5B17... Another picture of this armored car appears elsewhere on the web with this caption: "Mack armored car built for the New York National Guard in 1916. Three vehicles were completed, all on different chassis, but with similar armored body." www.warwheels.net/USAArmoredCarThesisHAUGHto1940.html www.warwheels.net/images/mack1916haugh.jpg The NGNY on the side of the car indicates it is from the National Guard of New York. Another photo from a 1916 parade, perhaps this one, shows 3 different NGNY armored cars: armoredcars-ww-one.blogspot.com/2011/11/new-york-national... www.macktrucks.com/default.aspx?pageid=481 (Identified as Mack Model AB armored car) Motor Age magazine from April, 1916, contains a complete description and photos of this vehicle. books.google.com/books?id=s1UfAQAAMAAJ&dq=mack%20Mode...
Note that this armored car has an unprotected crank starter in front.  I guess if it stalled in the face of the enemy you were SOL.
Another photo with description of the car is in the Evening public ledger., May 01, 1916, Night Extra, Image 18.

The name inscribed on the photo is spelled incorrectly. This is a photo of aviator Overton M. "Rusty" Bounds (b. 1895 - d. 1942). At the time this photo was taken, Bounds was an instructor at the Army Aviation School in Mineola, Long Island. Sadly, Overton Bounds would die in 1942 as a result of being fatally struck by a taxiing aircraft's propeller at Cimarron Field, near Oklahoma City. See: earlyaviators.com/ebounds.htm
This seems to be the same plane pictured on the earlyaviators.com page with the caption "Joseph Cato built this first stunt plane for Rusty Bounds, 1915-1916."

New-York tribune. (New York [N.Y.]), 17 May 1916, page 7 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1916-05-17/ed-... says that a flower market in aid of suffrage was to be held on May 27, 1916 on Fifth Avenue.
That distinctive building at upper left is on the corner of 17th and Park, the NE corner of Union Square: goo.gl/maps/pDmtf

This is the suffragist flower market held on May 27, 1916 in New York. 100 cars started from Union Square (stories before the event said Washington Square), then to drive off and sell flowers, with the women wearing white dresses with yellow and blue crepe paper hats and sashes. A picture very likely taken at the same occasion is in New-York Tribune., May 27, 1916, Page 3. The outfits are identical and Colonel Horton is carrying the same coat (presumably young Finley Shepard, Jr's). The event is the Governor's Island garden fete. She is named as Mrs. Finley Shepard. I assume her husband is en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Finley_Johnson_Shepard; in which case she is the former Helen Miller Gould. Since she and Shepard were married in 1913, it seems likely that young Finley is not her son. Indeed, in her Wikipedia entry (at en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helen_Miller_Gould), which is a lot fuller than her husband's, it is noted that they adopted three children. "The first of the adopted children, Finley Jay Shepard, was a three-year-old abandoned child who was found on the steps of Manhattan's St Patrick's Cathedral in 1914."

I 'd guess that Col. Horton is the Colonel William E. Horton who was awarded the Army Distinguished Service Medal in 1918. See projects.militarytimes.com/citations-medals-awards/recipi... He reached the rank of Brigadier General, retired in 1929, and died in 1935. He was buried in Arlington Cemetery. See www.arlingtoncemetery.net/wehorton.htm

The same picture (or a nearly identical one), cropped to just include Mrs. S. and her adopted son, is in a number of newspapers of the time, including these: chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84024827/1916-06-06/ed-... chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn86081889/1916-06-08/ed-...

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aerial_reconnaissance_in_World_War_I has a picture that shows how this might have been used, fixed to the side of the plane where the pilot could reach over the side to pull the trigger. But perhaps this one was designed for holding in two hands given the sighting apparatus. The Wikipedia article discusses cameras with several lenses and we seem to be seeing two lenses here, one facing forward and one at an oblique downward angle. The USGS has a history of its aerial photography, but it really starts after WWI. www.ngs.noaa.gov/web/about_ngs/history/camera_timeline_we... A fuller description of the beginning of aerial reconnaissance using photographs is at www.militaryhistoryonline.com/wwi/articles/airreconinwwi.... but it has only the same photograph as the Wikipedia article (which is of a British plane and camera).

www.theaerodrome.com/forum/other-wwi-aviation/54261-what-... has a discussion thread but focuses on the lenses rather than the housing. www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-11667251 shows some British WWI cameras and photography, including one of the photographer holding a camera in the way this one cold have been held.

Mundelein (Richmond times-dispatch., February 13, 1916, Image 1, col. 4, "MONSIGNOR KELLEY APPEARS, PALE AND WORN, AT CLUB". According to 'The Life and Times of Pancho Villa', by Friedrich Katz, he was the strongest lobbyist for Mexico's Catholic Church in the United States and advocated U.S. military intervention.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_M._Cohan

More confirming the context: This photo ran in the Sunday (Portland) Oregonian on July 9, 1916 with the caption: " George M. Cohan is the abbot of the Friars' organization, on Forty-eighth street, New York. The Friars marched from their old clubhouse to the new one Monday last May. They toured the Middle West and East with a big show intended to help pay for the new club. Mr. Cohan has won honors and wealth as actor, author and theatrical manager. It is now reported that he will retire from active business and devote himself to travel." oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83045782/1916-07-16/ed-1/se...

This might be from the Preparedness Parade, but possibly not. I don't think the parade route went up to Times Square, which is where this is. In the background are the Loews New York and Criterion theaters, which were both in 1916 part of one building that took up the Broadway frontage between 44th and 45th Streets. The Criterion Theater, seen in the background, was at 1514-16 Broadway at 44th St. cinematreasures.org/theaters/16481 cinematreasures.org/theaters/15178 The Mysteries of Myra, on Loew's marquee, was an 11 part serial released weekly between April24 and July 16, 1916. Here's an interesting site dedicated to restoring it: www.mysteriesofmyra.com/ The Friars Club opened their new clubhouse or "Monastery" on May 22, 1916, with Cohan leading the members in a march to the building on W. 48th Street. These marchers are heading in that direction, so it's apparent this and the previous picture depict those events. books.google.com/books?id=Hu3nNSmRjZ0C&lpg=PA197&...

Looking for details on Lota Robinson: According to The Amiable Baltimoreans by Francis F. Beirne, 1984 books.google.com/books?id=WNso9EnqfxcC&pg=PA114 one Alfred Jenkins Shriver left $800,000 to Johns Hopkins University in his will for the construction of a lecture hall on condition that on diplay in the hall would be portraits of ten Baltimore women he remembered as beautiful in his youth. Lota Robinson was among them, although some felt that her distinction was more her vivacity and the only one to remain unmarried. She appears quite often in the social columns, with her hats and other fashionable attire frequently mentioned. The Dispatch (Provo, Utah), May 27, 1891, page 3, bottom of column 3, with picture chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn86091037/1891-05-27/ed-... indicates, in a piece on Baltimore Beauties, that she is the daughter of Mrs. John Robinson, a Baltimore social leader. There were clearly rumors of engagements in the press, incluing one as early as 1902, in the Free press., November 22, 1902, page 2. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84029696/1902-11-22/ed-... I'm inclined to think she is the women in a dark outfit next to Mrs. Roosevelt. Some more family details are in the Harrisburg Telegraph, 2 June 1911, Page 4 www.newspapers.com/newspage/39834434/ "An engagement of much interest to society in Baltimore, New York, Philadelphia and York, Pa., announced today, is that of Mrs. Robinson Boykin, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Moncure Robinson, and John Messick Gross, son of Mr. and Mrs. John K. Gross, of York, Pa. "Mrs. Boykin, who was formerly Miss Mary Washington Robinson, is one of five attractive sisters, the others being Miss Lota Robinson, Mrs. Richard Morton, Mrs. George P. Mordecai and Mrs. Edward Crozer, of Philadelphia. Mrs. J. Ramsay Barry, another sister, died in 1901. "Mrs. Boykin's brothers are Moncure Robinson, of Philadelphia, and J. Randolph Robinson, of New York. The late Mrs. John M. Robinson, Mrs. Boykin's mother, was one of the leaders of the social life in Baltimore for many years and was noted for her charming and winsome manner and the success and originality of her entertainments."

Apparently this is the cabin where Lincoln is thought to have been born, or at least the closest we will come to ever seeing that cabin. The original cabin was already gone from its site by 1865, when Lincoln was not very popular in Kentucky, where he was born. The logs, which had supposedly gone into another cabin, were purchased and reassembled in 1895 for an event at the Lincoln farmstead. According to a National Park Service study, this photo is of the 1895 reconstruction. Their caption on the photo: "The "Davenport Cabin" as assembled by James W. Bingham in 1895." In July, 1916, President Wilson signed into law a bill creating the Abraham Lincoln National Park, where the reconstructed cabin is now displayed. www.nps.gov/abli/historyculture/upload/ABLI_Historic_Reso... This photo was also clearly the basis of the log cabin design for the back of the 2009 pennies put out by the Mint for the 100th anniversary of the Lincoln penny. Here's the design: www.usmint.gov/downloads/pressroom/2009LincolnCentR1.jpg

1920 New York Social Register at books.google.com/books?id=ek5IAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA631&l... suggests that Audrey is the daughter of Mrs. Sellar (Sybil W. Sherman) by a previous husband. They lived in Hewlett, Long Island.
New-York tribune., November 13, 1920, Page 11 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1920-11-13/ed-... has a picture of Audrey and caption that confirms she is the daughter of Mrs. Norrie Sellar.

NYT of Dec 14, 1904 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F50F11FD3A5C12738... reports on the marriage of Mrs. Sybil W Sherman Hoffman and Mr Sellar. According to the research of curators of a portrait at the New-York Historical Society, "Sybil Katherine Sherman was the daughter of W. Watts Sherman (d. 1912) and Annie Derby Rogers Wetmore, daughter of William Shepard Wetmore and niece of Governor George Peabody Wetmore of Rhode Island. She was the first of three wives of John Ellis Hoffman; they were divorced in 1904 and a year later the subject was married to Norrie Sellar (d. 1932), a prominent London and New York cotton broker." They give her dates as circa 1875-1955.

The younger girl will likely be Iris (Sellar) Veeder (1908-1983) See Scope and Content in www.rihs.org/mssinv/MSS1078.htm (finding aid for family papers of Sybil's family) An 1931 engagement picture is at fultonhistory.com/newspaper%2011/New%20York%20Evening%20P...

A court case from 1969 relating to a will, law.justia.com/cases/rhode-island/supreme-court/1969/252-... suggests that Audrey Hoffman Clinton, Iris Sellar Veeder and Norrie Sherman Sellar were siblings. This indicates that Audrey married a Clinton, which in turn suggests that the 1915 debutante picture of "Audrey Hoffman, mother of Audrey Clinton" on fashionhistorian.net/blog/2013/11/21/more-holiday-gift-bo... is the same Audrey Hoffman as in this Bain picture. Audrey's 1975 death was reported in the Newport Mercury on May 9, 1975 -- www.newspapers.com/newspage/16223265/

Hsuan-t'ung is the Wade-Giles spelling of Xuantong, a title of the Emperor of China. So this would be a wife of the Last Emperor of China, en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Puyi. It looks as though he had primary and secondary wives in the 1920s: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Empress_Wanrong and en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wenxiu www.beijing-forbiddencity.com/royalty/royalty-concubines.... has a picture with image title wanrong-wenxiu.jpg which is probably of them both. Unfortunately there is no indication of which is which.

Lady Gobulo, Empress Xiaokemin (Lady Gobulo, Empress Hsiao-ko-min; 13 November 1906 – 20 June 1946), better known as Empress Wanrong (Empress Wan-jung), was the empress of Puyi, the last Emperor of China and final ruler of the Qing Dynasty. She became empress of the puppet state of Manchukuo when Puyi was installed as its nominal ruler during the Second Sino-Japanese War. Her English name is Elizabeth.

"Aisin-Gioro Puyi (7 February 1906 – 17 October 1967), of the Manchu Aisin Gioro clan, commonly known mononymously as Puyi, was the last Emperor of China and the twelfth and final ruler of the Qing Dynasty. Still a child, he ruled as the Xuantong Emperor from 1908 until his abdication on 12 February 1912, after the successful Xinhai Revolution." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Puyi

I didn't find a lot on Billy Chandler: Billy (W.W) Chandler1890 Illinois28 Jul 1924 (1914-1916)Also a mechanic to Ralph Mulford and was a car builder. A former cab driver, he was later manager of Crawford cars, and assistant manager at Hudson. Believed to have died in a crash. Also listed as W W Chandler. ==== "William Chandler, a well-known mid-west Duesenberg pilot and mechanic, was hired by the factory to campaign their factory racecars at a handful of high-profile AAA National Championship Trail events during the 1916 racing season. The March 30, 1916 issue of The Automobile included the following item: “Four Entries for Sheepshead Bay May 13 Races “New York City, March 28—Ralph Mulford has entered his Peugeot in the 150-mile Metropolitan Trophy race to be run at the Sheepshead Bay Speedway on May 13. Three Crawford specials have also been entered. These will be campaigned this year by William Chandler. The cars are equipped with sixteen-valve Duesenberg four-cylinder motors. The dimensions are 3 ¾ by 6 ¾ in. Chandler will drive one and the others will be handled by Dave Lewis and Art Johnson.” The May 18, 1916 issue of The Automobile yielded Chandler’s disappointing results: “Chandler Out on First Lap “Bill Chandler in the Crawford Special was another one whose ill fortunes came early. Chandler completed just one lap in the first event and was no longer a factor in the day's program. A piston seized and broken at the very start ended all the activities of this favorite of the speed world until he pilots his mount in the events at Indianapolis.” www.coachbuilt.com/bui/m/moller_mp/moller_mp.htm

Two brothers: Perry Belmont (December 28, 1851 – May 25, 1947), American politician and diplomat en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perry_Belmont and August Belmont, Jr. (February 18, 1853 – December 10, 1924), American financier, builder of New York's Belmont Park racetrack, and major owner/breeder of thoroughbred racehorses en.wikipedia.org/wiki/August_Belmont,_Jr

A photo of Mrs. Perry Belmont in the same outfit illustrates a New York Herald story on the May 13, 1916 opening races of the Belmont Park Terminal Course season. The Terminal Course was a second, smaller track on the Belmont Park grounds for steeplechase events. Perry Belmont was president of the United Hunts Racing Association, which sponsored the event. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belmont_Park The race start was delayed until 3 pm on account of the massive Preparedness Parade that day in Manhattan. I don't think it's going out on a limb to guess that Mrs. P. Belmont would not wear the same haute couture outfit to multiple society horse racing events, so it's safe to assume that this, and surrounding photos, were taken at Belmont Park Terminal on 5/13/16. Her distinctive tricorne black straw hat with an ostrich frond pompom on top is also described in the article. fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%2014/New%20York%20NY%20Herald... More notes on Mrs. P. Joseph Hodges Choate (January 24, 1832 – May 14, 1917), American lawyer and diplomat. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Hodges_Choate The photo was taken most likely at the Citizen's Preparedness Parade of May 13, 1916; The evening world., May 13, 1916, Final Edition, Image 1 (at the bottom of the last column) reported that the crowd gave an ovation to Joseph H. Choate.

New York's Citizen's Preparedness Parade of May 13, 1916, in which 135,000 marched. The parade began around City Hall, moved uptown to where there was a reviewing stand in Madison Square, then up to around 57th Street. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F20A15FD3F5D1773...
The neighborhood has changed a bit: goo.gl/maps/c1G21

Really, perhaps just the original New York Times building, in back of the Franklin statue, is all that's left. I think the group in silk hats and cutaways in this picture and in one nearby is the "Mayor's Escort", which was made up of one representative of each of the 74 trade groups that marched that day. Presumably, the carriage behind them is the one with Mayor Mitchel and Col. Barbour, also seen in another picture. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10B11FD3A5B1773...
grace!

The Citizen's Preparedness Parade, at Union Square, in front of the Everett Building, marching west on on E. 17th St. near Park Avenue South. The soldiers that led each division of trades and occupations where the "Plattsburg enrolled men", which I assume is the New York National Guard. In this photo, the Silk Industry and Allied Interests Division, numbering 5,194 men. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F50C11FD3F5D1773... This location today: maps.google.com/maps?q=everett+building,+nyc&ll=40.73... More on the history of the Everett Building:
grace!

This photo is looking south at Petrosino Square in Manhattan (it was known as Kenmare Square at the time of the parade).  The parade is marching up Lafayette St.   Cleveland Place is the street that angles off to the left for a couple of blocks before turning into Centre St.

Petrosino Square is named after police officer Joseph Petrosino, who was a pioneer in the fight against organized crime and who was assassinated by the Sicilian Mafia while in Palermo.

We've seen Kenmare/Petrosino Square before in the Bain photos, twice in 1915. The Italian Consulate was in the building on the far right, and there are photos from the demonstrations when Italy entered the war, as well as when, about 6 months before this parade, a bomb exploded.
grace!

The Grand Marshal of the Citizen's Preparedness Parade was Charles H. Sherrill (1867-1936), eventually a Brigadier General in the U.S. Army, U.S. Ambassador to Argentina and Turkey, and later a top Olympics official who protested holding the Olympics in Germany in 1936 over the treatment of Jews. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_H._Sherrill_(ambassador) books.google.com/books?id=s5ntIQv0W5IC&pg=PA47&lp...
grace!

The 135,000 strong Citizen's Preparedness Parade of May 13th, 1916. New York's Mayor John P. Mitchel (1879-1918), along with the president of the parade committee, Col William L. Barbour (1857-1917) , New Jersey based Republican politician and owner of a textile manufacturing company. That day, he was serving as president of the Parade Association. The other men in the carriage are Theodore Rousseau, the mayor's secretary, and Roger W. Allen, executive secretary of the Parade Association. It looks like they are in front of City Hall. www.nycago.org/Organs/NYC/html/ResBarbourW.html en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Purroy_Mitchel select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F50C11FD3F5D1773... en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_City_Hall

Art Smith (1890-1926) was a pioneer aviator. Aerial Age Weekly refers to demonstration flights he made in Japan in 1916, and the article also mentions Yukiteru Ozaki, son of the Minister of Justice in Japan, a member of the Imperial Aero association and a promising young aviator, so this is likely him. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art_Smith_(pilot) books.google.com/books?id=FNRLAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA507&l... Ozaki (1888-1964) went on to hold political office and become chairman of Japan Airlines and Honkyu Airlines. books.google.com/books?id=QjS03oqmcFwC&pg=PA129&l...
Documenting the process of technology transfer.
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/artolog] Thanks so much for these citations!

He was considered to be the most daring American aviator, see e.g. The day book., July 29, 1915, NOON EDITION, Image 11 (with a photo of obviously the same plane). On his tour in Japan he was amazingly not only in danger of crashing, but also of being stoned by an angry mob (Honolulu star-bulletin., May 18, 1916, 3:30 Edition, SPORTS CLASSIFIED AND SHIPPING SECTION, Page THIRTEEN, col. 3, "JAPANESE PRESS HEARS ART SMITH NEAR TO DEATH".
According to www.gettyimages.com, Ozaki is Yukio Ozaki, the 2nd Mayor of Tokyo, which would be this man: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yukio_Ozaki. The man on the photo seems to be younger, though.

I found the photo in The Sunday Oregonian. (Portland, Ore.) 1881-current, May 28, 1916, SECTION FIVE, Image 68. The text says that Mr. Ozaki was an amateur aviator, which indicates that it was rather Yukiteru Ozaki.

Obregon is presumably en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Álvaro_Obregón General Álvaro Obregón Salido (Spanish pronunciation: [ˈalβaɾo oβɾeˈɣon]; February 19, 1880 – July 17, 1928) who became President of Mexico in 1920. Notice the short empty sleeve. He lost his right arm in the battle of Trinidad in the spring of 1915, in which his forces defeated Pancho Villa.
clearly on the same occasion, is captioned as in El Paso, which is strong evidence for the occasion.

This photo is depicted in El Paso herald., May 05, 1916, HOME EDITION, Image 1. LOC note error in the caption: it's not "Col. L.A. Saenz", but "Col. A. Saenz" (Aarón Sáenz Garza, at that time private secretary or chief of staff of General Álvaro Obregón, see es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aar%C3%B3n_S%C3%A1enz); and it's not "Capt. A. Gaziola", but "Capt. A. Gaxiola" (perhaps a relative of Macario Gaxiola Urías). According to www.nevadaobserver.com/Mexican%20Revolution%20-%20People/..., the photo was taken on May 4, 1916 at Ciudad Juárez (likely on the occasion of the preparation of the meeting with General Scott in the nearby El Paso, see El Paso herald., May 05, 1916, HOME EDITION, Page 2, co. 3, "SCOTT, OBREGON ABOUT TO MEET").

Obregon's arm was apparently kept in formaldehyde and not disposed of until 1989: www.nytimes.com/1989/12/10/world/a-mexican-relic-is-burie... The El Paso Herald article cited by B-59 has the men identified, left to right (but the man standing between Garcia and Obregon is not identified), as: (1) Maj. Alberto G. Montano; (2) Maj. Rafael T. Villagran; (3), Baldomero A. Almada, Agente General Sria. de Guerra; (4) Maj. J. M. Carpio; (5) A.G. Garcia, Mexican Consul at EI Paso; (6) Gen. Alvaro Obregon, (7) Capt A. de Saracho; (8) Capt. A. Gaxiola; (9) Gen. F. R. Serrano; (10) Col. Aaron Saenz.

This Bain picture, and probably many others of the border war and Villa expedition, was taken by Walter H Horne (1883-1921) an El Paso, Texas photographer who sold his images as postcards and to newspapers. Horne No. 3055. www.nevadaobserver.com/Mexican%20Revolution%20-%20People/... The story of Horne's war photographs here: www.scribd.com/doc/29139793/The-Mexican-Revolution-Postca... A November, 1915 newspaper story mentions Capt. Arturo de Saracho, a member of Obregon's staff. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn88084272/1915-11-18/ed-...

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Angier_Buchanan_Duke was the brother of Mrs. A. J. Biddle Jr. The "Happiest Millionaire" was Anthony Joseph Drexel Biddle, Sr., whose daughter Cordelia was Angier Buchanan Duke's wife. That's all according to Wikipedia. So that suggests that brother and sister Duke married sister and brother Biddle.

www.newyorksocialdiary.com/node/1902757/print reckons that the Bain captions have the people wrongly ordered. A copy of the same photo is captioned: L to R: Angier Buchanan Duke, his wife Cordelia Biddle Duke, his sister Mary Duke Biddle, and her husband (and Cordelia Duke's brother) Anthony J. Drexel Biddle.

likely taken at the same event also claims to include Cordelia, Mrs. A. B. Duke. If so, then she is second from the left in the Bain picture of the foursome. If I look carefully at the right arm of the guy at left, the sleeve looks empty. Angier Buchanan Duke had an accident in 1905. "In an accident in 1905 he had lost a hand and part of his arm." So I think he is at the left, next to his wife. That seems to imply that I agree with the identification by newyorksocialdiary.com.

We have seen Florence Gilbert before, first with her mother at another sporting event in 1912: Then as a cast member of the "suffrage opera" performed in February, 1916: and in a formal portrait: According to notes by Pixel Wrangler and Pennylrichardsca, "Miss Florence Gilbert, a débutante daughter of Mrs. Cyril (Lilla Brokaw) Dugmore (1870-1939), and her first husband, the late Harry Bramhall Gilbert (1861-1911), was introduced to society in January, 1916, at a tea and dance for 1,000 at Sherry's. She married Sergeant Russell Evans Tucker, Jr., O.R.C. in 1918. As an aside, Florence Gilbert was a bridesmaid and Russell Tucker, Jr., an usher, at the wedding of Mary Duke and Anthony Biddle in July, 1915."

The wikipedia entry of Anthony Joseph Drexel Biddle, Jr.: "Anthony Joseph Drexel Biddle, Jr. (1897–1961), also known as A. J. Drexel Biddle, Jr. or Tony Biddle, was a wealthy socialite who became a diplomat of the United States, and served in the United States Army during World War I and after World War II, reaching the rank of major general." A photo of the marriage of Anthony Joseph Drexel Biddle, Jr. and his wife in The Washington times., June 22, 1915, HOME EDITION, Page 9 and a photo of Anger Duke and his wife (and their baby) in the Evening public ledger., June 03, 1916, Night Extra, Image 1 prove that swanq's classification is correct.

I've removed my erroneous ID of AJD Biddle, Jr. as his father. He didn't look like an 18 year old to me. But there he is, a teenager, with his much older wife. To round things out, Cordelia Duke (an even younger teen than AJDB, Jr. in this photo) was also much younger than her husband. Cordelia and Angier's wedding was April 28, 1915 and their son was born on November 13, 1915, so perhaps the couple got a small headstart on things? en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Angier_Biddle_Duke The date on this photo, 6/18/21, is the date Cordelia's divorce petition was reported, so it's likely this older photo was pulled for use at that time: "MRS. ANGIER B. DUKE ASKS FOR A DIVORCE; Suit Is Filed at Philadelphia, but Attorneys and Family Refuse to Discuss It.COUPLE SEPARATED IN 1918 Marriage of Miss Cordelia Biddle at Age of 17 Was an Outstanding Society Event of 1915." query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F00A17F63D551A738... Here's how their wedding and the immediate announcement of the engagement of the other brother and sister were reported: "DOUBLE ALLIANCE OF DUKES AND BIDDLES; Cordelia Biddle's Marriage to Angier B. Duke Followed by Mary Duke's Engagement TO BROTHER OF THE BRIDE 1,200 Attend Ceremony in Holy Trinity, Philadelphia -- Bride Receives Jewels Worth $200,000." query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F50F1EFB3E5D16738...

I think this is Mrs. Julien Stevens Ulman, the former Gertrude Oldfield Barclay, wife of a wealthy leather merchant. They lived in a very grand house at 24 E. 81st St. A blogger's account of the history of that house gives quite a bit of information about the Ulmans. The name is spelled a number of ways in sources, including different ways in the same source, but I think Ulman is accurate. A great-grandson gives the following information: "Gertrude Oldfield Barclay (b Short Hills NJ Jul 25 1874, d New York City 1961" boards.ancestrylibrary.com/surnames.ulman/11/mb.ashx daytoninmanhattan.blogspot.com/2013/02/the-1902-j-s-uhlma... Another description of the house includes this information: "Home of leather exporter and Special Deputy Police Commissioner Julien Stevens Ulman (1865–1920) and Gertrude Oldfield Barclay (b. 1874). We have previously seen one of their children, Rutgers Ulman, born 1911 At the time of her death in 1961, she was the widow of Gen. J. William Kilbreth. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0C13FE3F5B147A... Further genealogical information: wc.rootsweb.ancestry.com/cgi-bin/igm.cgi?op=GET&db=73...

A photo of her husband is in the New-York tribune., November 23, 1919, Page 11, Image 61 (at the bottom) A report about the Ulman-Barclay wedding: NYT, April 30, 1901 Ulman was vice president and treasurer of the Amalgamated Leather Companies, Inc. (according to invention.smithsonian.org/resources/mind_repository_detai...) His obituary: NYT, May 8, 1920

On the other hand, the woman on the Bain photo looks like the former Mrs. "Jack" Gallatin (Pauline Cory Gallatin), who married Joseph. S. Ulman in 1904. Joseph S. Ulman, a Wall street broker, was a brother of J. Stevens Ulman, see article with photo in The evening world., January 11, 1904, Night Edition, Page 8. The NYT-report about the Ullman-Gallatin wedding, published March 8, 1904: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=FB0814F83B5F13... See also fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%2018/New%20York%20NY%20Globe%..., col. 1. About her and her previous husband: wc.rootsweb.ancestry.com/cgi-bin/igm.cgi?op=GET&db=br...

"Charles Evans Hughes, Sr. (April 11, 1862 – August 27, 1948) was an American statesman, lawyer and Republican politician from New York. He served as the 36th Governor of New York (1907–1910), Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States (1910–1916), United States Secretary of State (1921–1925), a judge on the Court of International Justice (1928–1930), and the 11th Chief Justice of the United States (1930–1941). From www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/648267/World-Court-League "World Court League, an organization that carried on an intensive campaign for an international court" The same paragraph states that John Jays Hammond organized the League and was chair for 1914-1915. I think he is in the center, seated in this group portrait. The United States and the Origins of the World Court by David S. Patterson. Political Science Quarterly. Vol. 91, No. 2 (Summer, 1976), pp. 279-295 www.jstor.org/stable/2148413 (requires registration) describes the "World's Court League" as a "loosely organized, and rather ineffective group" but does not name the members. But NYT of January 13, 1917 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB091EFE3E5C1B728... does list members in an article reporting that ex-President Taft was resigning. As well as Hammond, they include Dr. Samuel T. Dutton, Emerson McMillin, Theodore Marburg, Jacob M. Dickinson, Coleman du Pont, Oscar S. Straus, Charles Nagel, James Speyer, Georg T. Wilson, Henry Clews, Alton B. Parker, Charles L. Pack, Bainbridge Colby and D.D. Woodmansee. The article reports new positions in the organization for Nicholas Murray Butler (Columbia University) and Dr. Albert Shaw.

NYT of April 19, 1916 select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F70F16FA3D5F1373... reports that plans for a congress to be held at the Hotel Biltmore on May 2, 3, and 4 were complete. John Hays Hammond is described as the President of the organization. Many speakers are mentioned.

This photo is from that Congress, per the ribbons on 2 of the men. I don't know if this is the same as, or successor to, the American Society for the Judicial Settlement of International Disputes (which had an identical goal), but Theodore Marburg, wealthy Baltimore peace activist and U.S. Minister to Belgium (coincidentally the father of the injured aviator pictured in this week's batch of Bain photos) was also involved in that, along with Taft and John Hays Hammond. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Society_for_the_Judicial_S... www.jstor.org/stable/2186808
www.phy.ilstu.edu/~wenning/McMillin/McMillin.html suggests that the man seated on our left as we look at the picture is Emerson Mcmillin.

The nightdress as banner probably means that these are among the garment-workers who participated in the 1916 May Day Parade in New York City.  See neighboring pictures.

I agree. Puritan Underwear Company was among the largest manufacturers of nightgowns and underwear, called "white goods" in the trade. The women are members of Local 62 of the White Goods Workers Union, an affiliate of the ILGWU chartered in 1909, one of many Jewish immigrant garment worker unions in New York. Two of the women wear ribbons identifying them as Shop Chairladies. An account of the history of Local 62, written in 1940 (by then the Local's name was the Undergarment and Negligee Workers Union) is online at babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.b3987891;view=1up;seq=9
Thanks for the background information.  We may update the record.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/artolog/]   Artolog, Thanks for flagging this image as one of your top favorites in the LOC photostream. 

You wrote, "The identification of this as a group shot of leaders of White Goods Workers Union Local 62 was particularly gratifying, as well as learning about the history of this and the other Jewish immigrant garment worker unions. This photo is May Day, 1916. The Triangle Shirtwaist fire is a recent living memory to these women.. They look happy to be marching, but they are resolute as well. The union was not entirely Jewish, especially as the years progressed, but the executive minutes were kept in Yiddish until the early30's."

We appreciate your many, many regular contributions to identifying the photographs in the Bain News Service collection and enriching their stories. Your selection now appears in the new set, [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/sets/72157640980107725/]

Happy Valentine's Day!  -- Helena, on behalf of LOC

This photo, printed in reverse, ran in the Sunday (Portland) Oregonian on July 23, 1916 with the caption: "Professor James Sturgis Pray, president of the American Society of Landscape Artists, received a message from Belgium recently saying the people of that stricken country wanted the aid of American architects when the day arrived when they could begin the reconstruction of their cities. Mr. Pray sent word that he knew every member of his society would be proud to help. " oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83045782/1916-07-23/ed-1/se...

James Sturgis Pray (1871-1929)
VIAF ID: 71104605

The name of Professor James Sturgis Pray was probably significant to a very small percentage of the student body of Harvard. Although for twenty years the Chairman of the School of Landscape Architecture, his work was not of a nature to make him widely known among the men outside his department and its real importance might easily be overlooked. There were few honors in his profession that Professor Pray had not attained at one stage or another of his career. The list of institutes and societies of which he was an active member is world-wide in its scope and includes as perhaps his greatest distinction the American Academy in Rome, of which he was for five years trustee and executive member. Professor Pray also took a prominent part in the development of the science of city planning that has grown to such importance during recent years. Much as his students in the Architectural School will miss the leadership of Professor Pray, they are but the least to regret his loss. A whole profession is the poorer for his passing. (Source: The Harvard Crimson; February 25, 1929)

Redmond's DSO in the London Gazette and found that he had been appointed as Staff Capt. while serving as Temporary Major with the Quebec Regt. www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/30984/supplements/12860 and again on 27th July 1916 he was appointed to the "personal" staff per www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/29686/supplements/7457 He was temporarily seconded for duty as a "Staff Learner" on 13th October 1917 as per www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/30782/supplements/8021 Despite extensive searches I have been unable to locate his award of the DSO which would have been a significant award at any time! "It would appear that Shaughnessy was the son of Thomas W. Shaughnessy:
American-born Canadian railway administrator who rose from modest beginnings as a clerk and bookkeeper for the Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad (a predecessor of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad) to become the president of the Canadian Pacific Railway, serving in that capacity from 1899 to 1918. In recognition of his stewardship of the CPR and its contributions to the war effort during the Great War, Shaughnessy was elevated to the Peerage of the United Kingdom on 1 January 1916 as Baron Shaughnessy, of the City of Montreal in the Dominion of Canada and of Ashford in the County of Limerick". According to my Debrett's of 1944 and Cracroft's Peerage the 1st Lord Shaughnessy's younger son was Captain the Hon Alfred Thomas Shaughnessy b. 1887 kia 31st March 1916. He was serving in the Canadian Expeditionary Force. He had two sons Thomas and Alfred who was born posthumously. The present baron, Charles 5th Lord, is the son of Alfred, he is an actor.
OK.  So it's likely that he went by "Fred" and some journalists assumed his name was "Frederick."  But it was actually "Alfred."

Charles Shaughnessy wrote: "In honour of Veterans Day: My Grandfather, Capt. Alfred Thomas Shaughnessy. Killed 1916 at Vimy Ridge in France. There is no greater sacrifice." (www.pinterest.com/pin/266134659203404328/)

Surprisingly, he lacks a Wikipedia entry. This is Frederic Thompson (1873-1919), probably most famous for his design of major amusement parks of his era, including Luna Park at Coney Island. He also designed the huge Hippodrome Theater in Manhattan. His tombstone in the Bronx reads "Sacred to the memory of Frederic Thompson, Creator of Joy For Millions, The Hippodrome, Luna Park, Toyland. A Poet, A Painter, Philosopher, An Architect, A Kindergarten Preacher in Toys." Toyland was an amusement park in San Francisco's Panama Pacific International Exposition in 1915. In the photo above, he is in his studio, which in 1916 was at 449 W. 23rd St. in Manhattan, surrounded by his posters, designs and drawings for Toyland. He copyrighted these drawings in 1913. www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?GRid=7689997&page=gr www.fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%205/Brooklyn%20NY%20Daily... A 1919 detailed obituary: www.fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%209/New%20York%20NY%20Sun... 1913 copyrights on his Toyland drawings: books.google.com/books?id=CD8hAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA456&l...

"Lieutenant Theodore Marburg, Jr., the young Baltimore aviator, who suffered the loss of his right leg as the result of an accident while flying in the service of the British Aviation Corps, arrived yesterday [April 23, 1916] on the American liner St. Louis on his way to his home, where he will remain until September." The story identifies his wife as the Baroness Giselle de Bivario, a Belgian. They had with them an "aviation hound", a dog resembling a dachshund/Irish Terrier mix and trained to guard hangars and bark when hostile aircraft approached as well as fly with the pilots and bring them tools while they repaired the planes. An earlier Times story about their engagement identified her as Baroness Gesselle de Vavario. Apparently, Lt. (later Capt.) Marburg killed himself in 1922. www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=8964380 select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10E1EFF355B1373... select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F00F1FFF3D5F1373...

Robert Treat founded Newark, New Jersey in 1666, and 250 years later the city held a pageant to commemorate that anniversary. Snell played Treat in the show. Some contemporary words from a local booster about this giant undertaking: "This wondrously beautiful spectacle has been conceived in words, scenes and music impossible to describe. You must—indeed, it is your duty as a citizen—to witness the pageant and have every member of your household witness it. It will never be re-enacted. Once the curtain has rung down on Newark’s Historic Pageant, it will have become irrevocable history, and your neighbor will know you as a loyal and intelligent citizen by the fact that you have seen the pageant and made its gorgeous spectacle your own ineradicable memory. The citizen who has not seen it will not have the hardihood to admit his unpardonable neglect. He will slink away with something akin to shame. His position will be unfortunate. So that every citizen in Newark may see this instructive and entertaining event during at least one of its four evening performances, the Committee has provided for 40,000 seats, half of which are free, the other half reserved. If you wish to learn something of the beauty and historic phase of the Pageant, you should attend the weekly mass meetings being held in various parts of the city for the purpose of recruiting volunteers for its cast, chorus or other departments. This is a Newark pageant, composed of Newark citizens of all ages, nations and degrees. There is room for every volunteer. Seven thousand persons will be trained for the parts and those who work in shops are as essential as those who play in society. It is to be a very democratic pageant in which all the people shall participate either as actors, singers, dancers, mob units, helpers, or as skilled mechanics and craftsmen." books.google.com/books?id=6e0-AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA104&f... en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Treat archive.org/details/bookofwordspagea00stev See also:

USS New York (BB-34) was a United States Navy battleship, the lead ship of her class. Named for New York State, she was designed as the first ship to carry the 14 inch/45 caliber (356 mm) gun. Entering service in 1914, she was part of the U.S. Navy force which was sent to reinforce the British Grand Fleet in the North Sea near the end of World War I. During that time, she was involved in at least two incidents with German U-Boats, and is believed to have been the only U.S. ship to have sunk one, during an accidental collision in October 1918. Following the war, she was sent on a litany of training exercises and cruises in both the Atlantic and the Pacific, and saw several overhauls to increase her armament. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USS_New_York_(BB-34)

I love these historical pictures, they always get me looking things up and learning something. In this instance, it's that King Albert here took personal command of the Belgian army during the First World War, fighting with his troops, while his wife, Queen Elisabeth, worked as a nurse, also on the front line. There were rumours that German troops never actually shot at Albert -- the Kaiser was his uncle. He was so appalled by the carnage on the battlefields and the damage to Belgium that he tried to negotiate an end to the war, on a "no victor, no vanquished" basis, but the other countries were determined to win, whatever the cost. I don't remember learning any of that in school, it's very interesting.
en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albert_I_of_Belgium

In addition, she was a champion squash player, and prominent in other sports; she's considered one of the leading all-round women athletes of the first half of the 20th century. ... Sears was the daughter of Boston businessman Frederick Richard Sears, a cousin of Henry Cabot Lodge, and a great-granddaughter of Thomas Jefferson." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eleonora_Sears
The same woman:

Other Bain photos of her: The picture on the right is embossed by the same photographer as this one, Harold A. Taylor, Coronado, and Ms. Sears is wearing the same clothes. see also www.nwhm.org/education-resources/biography/biographies/el... Taylor was a photographer in Coronado, California. contentdm.califa.org/cdm4/results.php?CISOOP1=all&CIS... Looks like this may have been taken in Coronado, California on March 3, 1915, during polo matches there. A contemporary account mentions all the women in the group picture: "In the ladies' game Miss Eleonora R . Sears, of Boston, and Mrs. C. C. Rumsey, formerly Miss Mary Harriman, daughter of the late railroad magnate, E . H . Harriman, appeared on one side . On the other were Miss Kathryn Steele, of New York, sister of Mrs . Devereux Milburn, and Miss Louise Fleischmann, niece of Colonel Max Fleischmann, captain of the Cincinnati polo team. Miss Sears ' side won by a score of 3 goals to 2 goals, the winning goal being registered by herself in the last few minutes of play. The teams in the round-robin were nominated by Mrs . Devereux Milburn, Mrs . J. Watson Webb, Mrs. C . C. Rumsey and Mrs . Max Fleischmann . Mrs. Rumsey's team won the match, and C . Perry Beadleston, a member of her team, made the highest individual score with 6 goals . " www.hpa-polo.co.uk/yearbooks/1915 Mar - 1915 Aug.pdf Here are some accounts of Sears at polo pony races at the Coronado Country Club in 1912: "Miss Eleonora Sears, the athletic "bachelor maid" of Boston, rode Joe Ross to victory in a quarter-mile dash on the Coronado track to-day." query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F00F1FFD3F5813738... Another account describes how she raced in men's attire while her opponent wore a riding skirt. cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SFC19120312.2.112.8# cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SFC19120310.2.96 A modern assessment of her life: www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2012/06/22/the-mother-of-t... and see

The Seattle star., May 07, 1915, Page 11 reported that she got a new polo pony for the Coronado tournament (she was shaking dice at Coronado Beach and won the pony); the corresponding photo shows her obviously with the same pony as on the Bain photograph (and with the same depicted in www.hpa-polo.co.uk/yearbooks/1915 Mar - 1915 Aug.pdf, page 33), and with the same clothes.

Some clever baseball-related advertising: A sign on the right field wall reads "In 1915, Burns, N.Y. Caught 278 Flies, Tanglefoot Grand Rapids" (bottom cut off). Tanglefoot was (still is) a brand of flypaper. George Burns was the N.Y. Giants right fielder in 1915. Tanglefoot had a similar ad on the outfield wall at Brooklyn's Ebbets Field, referring to their outfielder Zack Wheat: "In 1915 Wheat, Brooklyn, caught 345 flies. Tanglefoot caught 50,000,000,000 flies." www.ndsu.nodak.edu/ndsu/rider/bugtiques/Flypaper/Flypaper... www.baseball-almanac.com/players/player.php?p=burnsge01 www.net54baseball.com/showthread.php?t=156200 And that ad spawned a great baseball story. Giants owner Harry Hempstead jokingly (but officially) put in a draft bid for "Tanglefoot of Grand Rapids", the greatest fly catcher of all time. news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1985&dat=19171009&...

Sam Rice, in his second year of Major League Baseball, with the Washington Senators of the American League. Babler was Republican National Committeeman from Missouri, see e.g. The weekly tribune and the Cape County herald., August 11, 1916, Image 1, col. 6, "HUGHES VISIT TO CAPE NOT CERTAIN - Mr. Babler Informs Tribune Nominee Cannot be Here on Present Tour." Babler and his younger brother Henry Babler gave 868 acres of land to the State of Missouri, to be named the Dr. Edmund A. Babler Memorial State park, see www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=107232185 and en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Babler_State_Park. In the park is a statue of Edmund A. Babler, which has has great similarities with the person on the Bain photo IMO, see my.opera.com/musickna/blog/2009/11/10/dr-edmund-a-babler-....

Y’all remember ‘Screaming' Howard Dean     -- former Governor of Vermont and one-time Presidential hopeful? Well, this petite, pretty débutante, Sylvia Wigglesworth, (1897-1957) (standing), is the future grandmother of Howard Dean. [1] Sylvia was the daughter of Mr. Henry Wigglesworth and Mrs. Olive Belden Wigglesworth of Garden City, Long Island, and New York. In 1919, she married Joseph Manley (Chase) Mellen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Chase Mellen, also of New York and Garden City.  Chase was a 1917 graduate of Harvard and had recently returned from France where he served with the A.E.F., while Sylvia had been active in war relief activities. [2] [3] They divorced in 1926. [4]   — Flickr photo of Howard Dean by drummajorinstitute.

"Max Immelmann (21 September 1890 – 18 June 1916) was the first German World War I flying ace. He was a great pioneer in fighter aviation and is often mistakenly credited with the first aerial victory using a synchronized gun. He was the first aviator to win the Pour le Merite, and was awarded it at the same time as Oswald Boelcke. His name has become attached to a common flying tactic, the Immelmann turn, and remains a byword in aviation. He is credited with 15 aerial victories." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Max_Immelmann This photo is printed in New-York tribune., July 02, 1916, Image 55, reporting his death. See also article in The sun., June 22, 1916, Page 5, "LIEUT. IMMELMANN, NOTED GERMAN AVIATOR, KILLED", with photo.
On April 12,1916 (date on sticker: 4/13/16) was an article in the NYT "BRITISH AVIATORS LAUD IMMELMANN" (query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=FA0D12FF3A5B17...)

November 16] 1829 – November 20 [O.S. November 8] 1894) was a Russian pianist, composer and conductor who became a pivotal figure in Russian culture when he founded the Saint Petersburg Conservatory. Elizabeth L. Garmong brought a suit in Maine for breach of a 1910 promise of marriage against John B. Henderson "a man of present and prospective wealth." There were two trials, the second in the April, 1916 term of the court, but ultimately Henderson won in a decision by the Maine Supreme Court in November, 1916, which sets out all the facts. The court did suggest that he was the father of the child, born in November, 1910. books.google.com/books?id=ScbzAAAAMAAJ&lpg=PA177&...

Elizabeth Leona Garmong was a former social favorite in Des Moines, Iowa. In the first trial she was awarded a verdict for $116,000 in her breach of promise suit (The evening world., January 29, 1915, Final Edition, Image 3, with picture). According to Omaha daily bee., February 21, 1915, EDITORIAL SOCIETY, Image 17 (with photo), this was a record sum for such a case at that time. The article also says that John Brooks Henderson, Jr. was the son of the multi-millionnaire U.S. Senator from Missouri.

This photo obviously refers to a German day at the Tea Garden (part of a Fower Show at Grand Central Palace) with Mrs. Hugo Reisinger as Chairmann of the committee, Mrs. Josef Stransky as member and Count von Bernsdorff (German ambassador to the U.S.) as guest, see The New York Times, April 9, 1916. A Mme. Hauge is also mentioned in this article.
Mrs. Hugo Reisinger (Edmee Busch Reisinger): Josef Stransky & wife: See also comments there.

A "Mme. Christian Hauge" appears very frequently in the newspapers of that time, it's the same woman as "Mrs. C. Hauge" on the photo. She was the wife of Hjalmar Christian Hauge, Norway's minister to the United States. (no.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hjalmar_Christian_Hauge). An article with photo about her is in the San Francisco Call, Volume 98, Number 182, 29 November 1905 . After the death of her husband in 1907, "Mrs. Hauge ... lived in the new residence (of Norway) on Massachusetts Avenue (in Washington). Thus, the intended legation "became instead the home of Madame Hauge during the years of her social prominence, and the scene of much of Washington's most brilliant entertaining". (The Mayflower's Log, October 1927)." She died in 1927. (www.historic-structures.com/washington_dc/dc/hauge_house.php). According to this source she was the sister of James Ross Todd of Louisville, Kentucky.

New York Times, August 4, 1915 "CAPTURE 24 FILIBUSTERS.; Mexicans Seized at Border Thought to be of Huerta-Orozco Party. WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- Major Gen. Frederick Funston, commanding the United States Army patrol along the Mexican frontier, today notified the War Department that a filibustering expedition had been captured while trying to cross into Mexico, about ten miles west of Fort Hancock, the first important military post east of El Paso, Texas." The article mentions that among the captured was Colonel Ricardo Aguilar, affiliated with the Orozco cause. The War Department suggested that the men were planning to join the Orozco-Huerta counter-revolution. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F40912FF385B1773... The El Paso Herald covered the trial of 18 of these men, including Ricardo Aguilar, who were convicted on October 18, 1915 of conspiring to take a military expedition into Mexico. The names of the men, who are presumably among the prisoners in this photo, are in the article. Testifying at the trial were Capt. Thomas F. Ryan, presumably the Capt. Ryan mentioned in the writing at the bottom of the negative, and Corporal Arthur Warrington. Presumably both of them are in this picture. texashistory.unt.edu/ark:/67531/metapth137471/m1/4/?q=%22... Capt. Thomas F. Ryan 1868-1919, is buried in Arlington National Cemetery www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GSln=ryan&a...; books.google.com/books?id=smc_o0HDYx0C&lpg=PA152&... discovere.emory.edu/primo_library/libweb/action/dlSearch....

The NYT, November 26, 1913, col.3 mentions a "Mrs. David Crompton, daughter of Mrs. Sheridan". In 1919, David Crompton was President of the Booth Steamship Line (NYT, January 27, 1919, col. 2). David's older brother Paul Crompton was among the victims of the Lusitania (see www.rmslusitania.info/people/saloon/paul-crompton/, with more informations about the Crompton family). He had worked for the Booth Group as well. See also www.encyclopedia-titanica.org/print/lest-we-forget-the-lu.... The Washington times., February 09, 1918, FINAL EDITION, Page 8, col. 2 reported that Mr. and Mrs. David Crompton were guests of Pres. Wilson at the White House. In 1952 she was a widow and married Senator Charles W. Tobey (Spartanburg Herald, July 3, 1952, page 3, col. 4, en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_W._Tobey). A photo of her in 1961 is in www.jfklibrary.org/Asset-Viewer/Archives/JFKWHP-KN-17647....

The Mummers Parade is held each New Year's Day in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, USA. It is believed to be the oldest folk festival in the United States. Great renaissance of the ancient Cornish & Celtic tradition of Mummers Day .There is some confusion what mid winter day celebrates nowadays with more recent migrants. The US parade traces back to at least the mid-17th-century roots, blending elements from Swedish, Finnish, Irish, English, German, and other European heritages, as well as African heritage.The parade is related to the Mummers Play tradition from Celtic Cornwall in England, Ireland, Scotland and Wales. Revivals of this tradition are still celebrated annually in South Gloucestershire, England on Boxing Day and in parts of Ireland on St. Stephen's Day and also in the Canadian province of Newfoundland and Labrador around Christmas. Swedes, Philadelphia's first settlers, brought the custom of visiting neighbours on "Second Day Christmas" (December 26) with them to Tinicum. This was soon extended through New Year's Day with costumed celebrants loudly parading through the city. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mummers_Parade en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mummer%27s_Day An ancient Cornish midwinter celebration that occurs every year in Padstow and was originally part of the pagan heritage of midwinter celebrations that were regularly celebrated all over Cornwall where people would guise dance and disguise themselves by dressing up, darkening or blackening up their faces or wearing masks". It was nothing to do with 'black' people (few had ever been seen in Cornwall or Kernow at the time this tradition started many years BC). Though there's is a story it re-began when an English slave ship entered Padstow , Cornwall after a storm ,the towns ship rights refused to carry out the work on the ship , until they had taken the 'cargo' of slaves off and allowed them to feed and offer them warmth and a brief freedom .The slaves had nothing to give but their songs and dances.

USS Wainwright (Destroyer No. 62/DD-62) was a Tucker-class destroyer built for the United States Navy prior to the American entry into World War I. The ship was the first U.S. Navy vessel named in honor of U.S. Navy officers Jonathan Wainwright, his cousin, Commander Richard Wainwright, and his son, Jonathan Wainwright, Jr..

Fantastic image. There's a rather nice Wikipedia entry here: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USS_Wainwright_(DD-62) Other than that...she was launched in 1915 and decommissioned in 1922. Then, from 1926 to 1934 she worked for the US Coastguard before returning to the Navy for a bit. Then, finally, in 1934, she was sold for scrapping.
A photo of the launch of the USS Wainwright: Evelyn Wainwright Turpin, who christened the ship:
