Blackfeet Digital Library has a photo of him, identified as Stabs By Mistake, with this biographical sketch, "Father: Sitting With Back Sticking Out Mother: Dives to the Shore Wife: Steal In The Day Time Father: Mountain Chief (Big Brave) Mother: Bird Sailing This Way Children: Peter Stabs by Mistake, Thomas Stabs by Mistake. Stabs by mistake was a Beaver Man. He was one of the last Aamskaapiipikuni to take part in the Dove Society. The was a member of the Black Tail Deer Society. He took a Crow Water bundle around the same time that he had joined the Black Tail Deer Society. Stabs by Mistake was buried with a War Pipe that was given to him by Mountain Chief. He was a drummer for many Medicine Pipe openings because he knew the songs however; he never had one transferred to him. Stabs by Mistake was transferred the Top Knot and a necklace from one of the Medicine Pipe holders. Stabs my Mistake drowned in the Four Horns Lake." blackfootdigitallibrary.com/bla/asset/stabs-mistake-photo... en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theodore_Roosevelt_Dam

Theodore Roosevelt Dam is a dam on the Salt River located northeast of Phoenix, Arizona. The dam is 357 feet (109 m) high and forms Theodore Roosevelt Lake as it impounds the Salt River. Originally built between 1905 and 1911, the dam was renovated and expanded in 1989-1996. The dam is named after then-President Theodore Roosevelt. Serving mainly for irrigation water supply and flood control, the dam also has a hydroelectric generating capacity of 36 megawatts.

Bush Terminal, now known as Industry City, is a historic intermodal shipping, warehousing, and manufacturing complex on the waterfront in the Greenwood Heights neighborhood of Brooklyn, New York City. Bush Terminal was the first facility of its kind in New York and the largest multi-tenant industrial property in the United States. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bush_Terminal_%E2%80%93_Industry_City

Does this negative set some sort of Bain record for most stains and fingerprints? These 5 German ships and their crews were "interned" in U.S. ports in the years between the time when WWI started in Europe and 1917, when the U.S. entered the war. I think the caption on this one, indicating that S.S. Vaterland is in the photo is wrong. The Vaterland, shown in the next Bain photo docked at Hamburg-American Pier 1, was a ship of the Hamburg-American Line. These ships are at the North German Line (Norddeutscher Lloyd, or NDL) piers, also in Hoboken. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norddeutscher_Lloyd " In 1914, the Vaterland was caught in port at Hoboken, New Jersey at the outbreak of World War I and interned by the United States. She was seized, renamed Leviathan after the declaration of war on Germany in 1917, and served for the duration and beyond as a troopship." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamburg_America_Line
Are these impounded ships?

A large number of German ships were "interned" in American ports at the outbreak of WWI in Europe. The ships and their crews were not seized, but could not leave due to the hostilities. When the U.S. entered the war in 1917, they were then seized and used in the U.S. war effort. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F00E13F83E5C13738... This October, 1915 newpaper article tells of 4 Hamburg-American line steamers being moved from a pier in Brooklyn to a new pier at the foot of 135th Street on the Hudson River. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F30B1FFA395D1673...

This is most likely the Indra, a German cargo ship, which arrived seeking shelter in the neutral port New York on November 8, 1914, after a stranger-than-fiction voyage of 13,000 miles in 160 days. She left Taltal, Chile with a cargo of nitrate of soda bound for Dunkirk. En route, her captain discovered war had broken out and escaped some trickery off the coast of Ireland intended to coerce her to proceed toward Dunkirk and be seized by the British. Instead, she raced to New York, where she tied up at Stapleton, Staten Island. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=F40713FC3C5C13... Indra remained at Stapleton until July 6, 1916 when she was towed to Erie Basin, at the foot of Brooklyn's Gowanus Canal, and her cargo, which had multiplied in value due to the war, was unloaded and sold. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F40710FA3C5F1373... The placement of this photo near several others of interned German ships is one clue. If it is the Indra, the photo's date indicates that it would be at the Stapleton docks, though the sign for J&F Kelly is for a dock construction contractor near the Gowanus Canal. Photos of the Indra at other times in her career (she was seized in 1917 and renamed by the First Lady as the Tonawonda, one of many Indian names she gave to seized ships) also suggest this is the same ship. repositories.tdl.org/ttu-ir/handle/2346/47406 repositories.tdl.org/ttu-ir/bitstream/handle/2346/47406/t... www.clydeships.co.uk/view.php?ref=19888#v www.clydeships.co.uk/files/201308230919430.Indria%20ex%20... www.clydeships.co.uk/files/201303191927110.Tonawanda%20ex... The bark Matador was the only other interned German sailing ship in New York (docked at Hoboken, N.J), according to this April, 1916 account. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FA0B17FA3D5F1373... There is illegible writing on the side of the ship in this photo, but it doesn't seem to say Indra. Tonawonda ended her days after a voyage from Seattle to Australia in 1927, another colorful trip: www.angelfire.com/or/petermarsh/Tonawanda.htm

The sun., February 02, 1917, Page 3, upper left chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030431/1917-02-02/ed-... has a list which describes Indra as a "steel ship" and Matador as an "oak bark." The largest sail on the aft mast should be square for a ship and fore-and-aft for a bark. I think I see a boom on the aft mast, which might argue that this is the Matador, if the choice is between the two.

Jess Willard successfully defended the heavyweight championship against Frank Moran on 25 March 1916. There's some film footage of the fight that's been put into a news reel format on YouTube.
Amazing! Thank you jschumacher for finding this footage. Beginning of the video shows off the spectacular architecture of the 1890 structure built by architect Stanford White.

According to the New York Times:   
On March 25, 1916, prizefighters Jess Willard and Frank Moran duked it out at Madison Square Garden. Six days later, a multi-reel filmed record of the bout was shipped out to theaters all over New York State. Though Willard was not at peak form, he managed to win the fight in a TKO after ten full rounds. The outcome of the fight was subject for debate, but the film clearly showed that Willard won fair and square. Over 13,000 spectators saw the Willard-Moran fight "live," but many times that number were able to witness the bout from the comfort of their movie-theater seats.

This is the second Madison Square Garden, the last of the four Gardens to actually be on Madison Square, at the intersection of Fifth Avenue and Broadway at 23rd Street in New York. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madison_Square_Garden_(1890).

A March 17, 1916 newspaper account, accompanied by a photo of a much younger Mrs. Elsie French Vanderbilt: "HIGHWAY ENTHRALLS NEW YORK SOCIETY Mrs. Alfred G. Vanderbilt Is Member of Motor Party Over Scenic Route. RETURN VISIT PROMISED Prominent Banker Declares Mediterranean Vistas Are Eclipsed and All Express Desire to See Summer Foliage. Charmed by a trip over the Columbia River Highway yesterday. Mrs. Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt. Mr. and Mrs. Amos Tuck French, Lawrence Perkins, and Miss Hazel J. Titus, all of New York City, and members of the smartest set of Gotham, became enamored of Oregon scenery and resolved to return here this Summer." Howard and La Velle Charlton are mentioned as being on the trip, as well as Mr. and Mrs. A.D. Charlton and John Yeon. "Miss Hazel J. Titus" could be a mistaken identification of Hazen J. Titus, or it could be a woman in the second car. oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83025138/1916-03-17/ed-1/se... A short entry on Elsie French Vanderbilt: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alfred_Gwynne_Vanderbilt_I#Elsie_Fr... Mrs. Amos French is holding an oblong object that says Northern Pacific on it. According to the caption of the photo on another site, "Portland citizen John Yeon is driving the first car (an air-cooled Franklin) with his passenger Mrs. French Vanderbilt. Some of her relatives and friends join the party. Yeon, a wealthy lumberman, had a special interest in the highway. He volunteered as Multnomah County's road master for $1 a year to supervise its construction." www.oldoregonphotos.com/subject/canyons-gorges-valleys/ne...
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/66311327@N05] Not sure, but I believe the Ellen French who married the Astor was a niece of the woman in the photo.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/artolog] You are right. That Elsie Tuck French Vanderbilt would be the later Mrs. Astor is written in www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=81626749, but is mistaken. Obviously somebody mashed her up with Ellen Tuck "Tucky" French (December 10, 1915 — September 5, 1974), who married John Jacob Astor VI in 1934 and who was a granddaughter of Amos Tuck French (according to www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=94178655). The later husband of Elsie French Vanderbilt was Paul Fitzsimons, they married in 1919, see The Washington times., April 20, 1919, NATIONAL EDITION, The American Weekly Section, Image 23. And the Morning Oregonian confused the photo in its issue of March 17, 1916 (oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83025138/1916-03-17/ed-1/se...). The woman shown there is not Elsie French Vanderbilt, but Margaret Emerson Vanderbilt, the second wife of Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt. The same photo is depicted in The Spokesman-Review - 27. Juni 1915 with the correct caption (and with a photo of Elsie French Vanderbilt on the same page). See also the two women in the Bismarck daily tribune., September 02, 1913, Image 6.

Lindley Murray gave another demonstration of his brilliant tennis play on the board courts of the Seventh Regiment Armory yesterday afternoon when he triumphed without difficulty over Dr. A.W. Waite, the senior metropolitan indoor champion, in the fourth round of the national indoor singles championship. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F20613FC345C13738...

Dr. Arthur Warren Waite, a dentist and well kown as tennis player. In March 1916, he poisoned his father-in-law, John E. Peck, a millionnaire drug manufacturer of Grand Rapids, Mich., see The Day book., March 25, 1916, LAST EDITION, Image 7, with photo Omaha daily bee., March 30, 1916, Page 2, with photo Keowee courier., March 29, 1916, Image 3, col. 3 Later it was revealed that he had murdered his mother-in-law as well. The case is described in murderpedia.org/male.W/w/waite-arthur-warren.htm and www.executedtoday.com/2008/05/24/1917-dr-arthur-waite-pla... Mrs. John E. Peck (Hannah Peck):

Bey after the name is the Turkish form of address equivalent to Mr. in English or -san in Japanese. At this time, Turks would have used arabic script, and so any name in latin script will be a transliteration.

This is no doubt connected to the meeting of a group of Hungarian American citizens, with President Wilson at the White House on February 23, 1916, under the leadership of Alexander Konta (photo, front center). They were to present him with a petition swearing loyalty to the U.S., signed by several thousand American citizens born in Hungary. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F60B17F93E5E1373... The Times listed those who planned to attend: Alexander Konta Rev. John Froelich, St. Stephens Roman Catholic Church of New York, Rev. Stephen F. Chernitzky, Bridgeport, Connecticut Rev. Lajos de Kovacs, Youngstown, Ohio Rev. Dr. Zoltan Kuthy, Pastor, First Magyar Reformed Church, Julius Volgyi, "secretary of a society of more than 14,000 members" Dr. Frank I. Horn, Chief Surgeon at St. Mark's Hospital, Dr. Morris Cukor, attorney, Geza D. Berko, owner of the Hungarian daily newspaper Nepszava Geza Kende, editorial writer Josef Haan, St. Regis Hotel The pictured group is mostly the same, assuming Y.D. Kende is Geza Kende. The four women are likely the wives of Haan, Berko, Cukor and Horn. Missing from the Times group is Rev. Dr. Zoltan Kuthy. Pictured, but not in the Times description, are Rev. Harsanyi and Rev. Szabo. An account of what transpired at the meeting with Wilson: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A05E2D9103FE233A... More on Alexander Konta under A biographical sketch of Morris Cukor: www.sk-szeged.hu/statikus_html/vasvary/newsletter/10dec/m...

"Charlotte Oelschlägel, aka Charlotte Hayward (August 14, 1898 in Berlin - November 14, 1984 in Berlin) was a German professional skater. For most of her life, she used only her first name as her stage name. She invented the death spiral and the charlotte spiral, named after her." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charlotte_Oelschlagel Another photos of her is in The Day book., February 17, 1917, LAST EDITION, Image 27. She appeared in the ice show Hip-Hip-Hooray! at the New York Hippodrome. See also The Day book., January 16, 1917, LAST EDITION, Image 13.

The sheet music in the photo leads to a hit musical extravaganza, "Hip Hip Hooray" which played at New York's 5,200 seat Hippodrome Theatre between 9/30/15 and 6/3/16. A performer named only Charlotte (Oelschlägel) is depicted ice skating on the cover, and mention of her skating is made in this New York Times article from May 2, 1916. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10D17F93D5F13738... The story of 17 year old Charlotte's rise to stardom in the production, as well as photos of the ice-skating extravaganza in Hip Hip Hooray is told and illustrated (in part by a full color reproduction of the sheet music in this picture) on a page devoted to her at icestagearchive.com. www.icestagearchive.com/images/scan0004.jpg www.icestagearchive.com/charlotte.html A 1926 biographical sketch select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10716F73E5D1373... More detailed biographical sketch from the 1990's: www.iceskatingintnl.com/SkatingScene/SScHistoricalIcons.htm
Thanks for finding the beautifully illustrated page on the career of this skater artolog. We' ll some of the information to the record the next time we update.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pierre_Roques "Pierre Auguste Roques (28 December 1856 – 26 February 1920) was a French general and creator of the French air force." "At the outbreak of World War I, he was the commanding general of the 12th Corps. By January 1915 he had become the commander of the First Army, and then became the Minister of War from January to December 1916, following Gallieni and preceding Lyautey. Subsequently, he served briefly as the commander of the Fourth Army and then as the Inspector General of Works and Organization for the French Army until February 1919."
